title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Restaurants
description: Having survived the monthlong gastronomic gantlet, punctuated by a surfeit of bubbly and a shortage of sleep, you may seek a meal this weekend that is as soothing and restorative as an hourlong massage. One dish that always brings me back to life is shepherd's pie, an Irish concoction that combines many of nature's most effective balms: mashed potatoes, ground meat (beef or lamb) and root vegetables. Steaming hot, snow-capped with gratineed potatoes and requiring little masticatory effort, it is quintessential mom food.

title: Final Huddle in Denver For Reeves and Elway
description: The stormy 10-year relationship between JOHN ELWAY and DAN REEVES has ended on a respectful note, with a handshake and wishes of good luck for the future.

title: Art in Review
description: Lillian Bassman Howard Greenberg Gallery 120 Wooster Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through Jan. 16

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Wednesday about that evening's CBS telecast of "The Kennedy Center Honors" misidentified the Broadway musical in which one a participant, Jodi Benson, appears. It is "Crazy for You."

title: What's the Good of a Liberal Education Without Philosophy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns vs. Talk: U.N. Is Pressing for Talks in Bosnia
description: By rejecting insistent Bosnian demands today that the United Nations either send soldiers to defend Sarajevo or let the Muslims there buy arms freely to do the job themselves, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has upped the stakes for his organization in its efforts to resolve the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Dance
description: In dance lovers' minds, there is no substitute for live performance. But at least one unusual exhibition can bring back fond memories about the dancegoing experience and also offer special insights into the field.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAMPBELL SOUP CO. cleared a hurdle in its takeover bid for Arnotts Ltd. yesterday when a court in Australia decided against limiting its voting power in that country's largest cookie maker.

title: Brasilia Journal; A Slaying Stuns Brazil: It's Right Out of the Soaps
description: As political history was being written here this week by the impeachment trial and resignation of President Fernando Collor de Mello, the process was almost upstaged by another drama: A beautiful soap opera actress was killed on Monday night and the man who plays her jealous boyfriend in the series confessed to the killing.

title: Lebanon Presses for the Return Of Deported Palestinians to Israel
description: The Lebanese Government said today that it would not allow the 415 Palestinians expelled by Israel two weeks ago to remain in southern Lebanon and rejected a French proposal that they be placed under the protection of United Nations peacekeepers in the area.

title: Police Speed Investigation Of Officers
description: Complaints of police misconduct included in civil lawsuits will be investigated immediately by the New York City Police Department as part of the expanded duties of the new Internal Affairs Bureau, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday.

title: German Violence Worries Investors
description: The wave of violence against foreigners in Germany is beginning to affect the economy, scaring away investors and tourists and endangering Berlin's bid to attract the Olympic Games in 2000, business leaders say.

title: Timothy S. Healy, 69, Dies; President of Public Library
description: The Rev. Timothy S. Healy, a Jesuit priest who straddled the religious and secular life in a career that included the presidency of Georgetown University and finally leadership of the New York Public Library, died on Wednesday night after he collapsed at Newark International Airport. He was 69.

title: A Call for the Jurors to Take Bigger Roles in Trials
description: Jurors should be allowed to question witnesses and take notes, be kept better informed of trial developments and become much more active and appreciated participants in the legal process, according to a newly published study of the civil jury system.

title: Now Bowing Out, a Busy, Busy Bush
description: After 1,450 seamless days of state dinners, brush-fire wars, telephone diplomacy and global jet excursions, George Bush's Presidency is now rapidly winding down. The same cannot be said of George Bush.

title: Adele Bowers, Writer And a Publisher, 78
description: Adele Bowers, a short-story writer and publisher, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78 years old.

title: A Benefit 'Barber'
description: The soprano Patricia Sayre Gray will sing the role of Rosina in the Amato Opera Theater's production of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at the company's theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village. The performance is a benefit for the Children's Organ Transplant Association, and proceeds will help cover the expenses of a heart transplant for Ms. Gray's 9-month-old son, who was born with cardiac defects. Tickets are $20 and are tax deductible. The opera will also be performed tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. and Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Tickets to regular performances are $16. Information: (212) 228-8200.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Theater
description: For millions of out-of-towners, not to mention those New Yorkers who grew up out of town, holiday season on Broadway means a night at a completely escapist hit musical with great songs, bravura dancing, lavish sets and costumes, a handsome cast and gags broad enough to penetrate even an alcoholic buzz. That bill could hardly be better filled than it is by "Crazy for You," the new-old Gershwin show in which a stage-struck Manhattan swell (Harry Groener) of the Depression era travels to Dead rock, Nev., to relight a dark theater and, not so incidentally, to win the girl (Jodi Benson) of his dreams.

title:
With Respect to the New;
Withdrawn
description: The river had already been named.Was mine to leave for her

title: Constance Carpenter, 87, Actress In 'The King and I' on Broadway
description: Constance Carpenter, an actress whose roles included a starring performance opposite Yul Brynner in the original Broadway production of "The King and I," died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Economic Pulse: The Washington Region; Once-Booming Megalopolis Is Struggling With Harder Times
description: At first glance, it could be the good old days all over again, just the way things were a couple of years back, before the recession hit this little rural patch sandwiched between the suburbs of Baltimore and Washington.

title:
With Respect to the New;
I Have Been Living
description: I have been living

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Smart Money magazine referred imprecisely to the attitude of Norman Pearlstine, an editorial director of the magazine, toward a competitor, Money magazine. Mr. Pearlstine said Smart Money, produced jointly by Dow Jones & Company and the Hearst Corporation, did not intend to pursue the same audience as Money.

title: Another Record Year for Wall St. Underwriters
description: The mergers were meager; the Dow Jones was dowdy; the trading was treacherous. It was a mixed year for many parts of Wall Street. Yet in its classic business of raising capital for companies, the underwritings were unbelievable.

title: The Art Market
description: Busy at the Guggenheim

title: A Railroad's Legacy: Land Rich and Cash Poor
description: In the 1860's, the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad Company, which had gorged on Federal land grants, was particularly aggressive -- and fanciful -- in marketing land abutting its line. One advertisement likened land along the Santa Fe Trail to a tropical banana tree, "known by its fruits."

title: Forecast of Snow on Plains Brings Jump in Cattle Prices
description: Cattle futures prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as meteorologists forecast snow in the Great Plains, which analysts said could disrupt livestock feeding and shipping.

title: No Headline
description: I was glad for Jean. But I was wondering when is it going to be my turn. Jean had an awful lot of publicity behind her, but the rest of us -- we're out of sight, out of mind. -- ARLENE CARIS, who, like Jean S. Harris, is in a New York prison for killing her lover. [ A1:3. ]

title: American Students Trail Japanese and Taiwanese in Math Scores
description: A decade after American schools began efforts to improve math education in public schools, students still lag significantly behind their peers in Japan and Taiwan, according to a study in today's issue of Science magazine.

title: Judge Calls a Meeting to Try to Settle the N.F.L.'s Latest Labor Dispute
description: United States District Judge David Doty has asked representatives of the National Football League's owners and its players to meet with him Tuesday morning in Minneapolis in an attempt to settle the differences that have kept them from reaching a new labor agreement.

title: 2 Men Arrested In Fatal Shooting Of Bronx Grocer
description: Two suspects were arrested last night in the fatal shooting of a bodega owner who was accosted in the lobby of his Bronx apartment house Dec. 22, then forced into his apartment where he was mortally wounded protecting his family and resisting a robbery, the police reported.

title: LECHTER'S SHARES UP 11% ON STRONG DECEMBER SALES
description: Lechter's Inc. shares vaulted more than 11% yesterday, after the household-products retailer reported stronger-than-expected December sales. Sales at stores open at least a year, called same-store sales, rose 6.4 percent. The company had expected same-store sales to rise 1 percent to 2 percent during the month, Dana Telsey, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence, said. In December, sales rose 29 percent, to $70.4 million, from $54.5 million in the year-earlier month. Lechter's rose $2.125, to $19.875, on volume of 324,100 shares, nearly quadruple the daily average for the last three months. Ms. Telsey, who rates the stock a "hold," is maintaining her earnings estimates of 65 cents to 67 cents a share for the fourth quarter and 85 cents to 90 cents for fiscal 1993, ending in January.

title: Quixotic Grammarian
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children Dulcie Leimbach
description: 'Science Friday' National Public Radio (In New York, WNYC 820 AM and 93.9 FM) Recommended ages: 6 and up Today

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Television
description: People planning to spend New Year's Day in bed, pondering resolutions already broken, might consider the advantages of the television remote.

title: Barry M. Canterna, A Sculptor, Dies at 41
description: Barry Movsessian Canterna, a sculptor whose work has been shown at galleries in New York, San Francisco, Pittsburgh and Belgium, died on Wednesday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 41 years old.

title: Czechoslovakia Breaks in Two, To Wide Regret
description: Against the wishes of many of its 15 million citizens, Czechoslovakia today split into two countries: Slovakia and the Czech Republic.

title: Europe's Road to Unity
description: A "single market" takes effect in Western Europe today, linking 345 million people in the European Community's 12 nations by eliminating tariff and customs barriers.

title: Restaurants
description: If you find yourself on New Year's Day holding a vexing amount of surplus cash that you had intended to dispose of the night before, there's still hope. Try dinner soon at Parioli, Romanissimo, New York City's priciest pasta house, where you can burn up close to $100 a person while drinking house wine.

title: Judge Cites Trade Accord In Ending Zenith Contract
description: In ordering the Air Force to terminate a $740 million contract awarded to the Zenith Data Systems Corporation for desktop computers, an administrative judge agreed with the losing bidders that Zenith's bid did not comply with the Trade Agreements Act of 1979, as required by the contract.

title: Often Mammography Doesn't Tell the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Gates Orders a Revamping Of the C.I.A.'s File System
description: Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, has ordered a sweeping overhaul of how the C.I.A. maintains its vast store of files, Government officials said today.

title: Finding an Economic System for a New Century
description: To the Editor:

title: A Midlife Run Into a Roadblock
description: Happy New Year, Bonnie Frankel. This could be your decade.

title: Holiday Storms Bring Hope of Drought Relief in Northern California
description: The Northern California mountains were blanketed with large amounts of snow again today, the second of two major winter storms in a week that have stranded thousands of holiday travelers and brought some hope of drought relief to California's usually grim water officials.

title: The Islanders Go Meekly Into the Night
description: Blues 5, Islanders 1

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Village Bistro Reopens

title: BUSH SEES VICTIMS OF SOMALI FAMINE
description: President Bush today had his first glimpse of the Somali famine that he has sent troops to ease when he visited a feeding center and toured a small hospital with sick and malnourished patients near the capital.

title: Here Come the Legends
description: CONNIE HAWKINS, a 1991 inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame, will be among the big names participating in the fourth-annual Knicks Legends game, which will take place tomorrow afternoon at Madison Square Garden after the Knicks take on the Clippers.

title: Art in Review
description: Timothy Hawkesworth Littlejohn-Sternau Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through tomorrow

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ukraine, Stumbling Block at End of Nuclear Race
description: As President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia prepare to sign a treaty cutting deep into their nuclear arsenals, Ukraine has been tugging at their sleeves with an awkward and unwelcome question: How much will it cost to get rid of weapons of mass destruction, and who is going to foot the bill?

title: TV Weekend; A 'Tosca' Performed On Actual Location
description: Opera is bigger than life. It is lavish, if not excessive. Doubters are urged to watch the PBS "Great Performances" presentation of Giacomo Puccini's "Tosca," which will be broadcast on Channel 13 this afternoon at 12:30 and Sunday at 10 P.M. The production was conceived and produced by Andrea Andermann.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the television program listings scheduled for page B15 yesterday were omitted from some copies, and a duplicate of page D2 appeared in their place. The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers.

title:
Housing for the Elderly;
Long Island Nuns Build 266-Unit Rental Project
description: A Roman Catholic order of nuns, the sponsor and developer of a 266-unit rental project for the elderly, is building it in the belief that most older people, given some physical help, can live independently without ever needing nursing-home care. The idea has caught on nationally but not too extensively yet in the New York area.

title: Parking in New York City; When the Rules Change in 1993
description: In addiiton to the days listed below, alternate-side rules are suspended every Wednesday and Saturday. ALTERNATE-SIDE RULES SUSPENDED

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Film
description: "The Distinguished Gentleman" has a lot more credibility than most fish-out-of-water comedies, since it actually bothers to explain how a con man could find his way to Congress. The facts add up, and they're funny, too. Brisk direction by Jonathan Lynn and a savvy screenplay by Marty Kaplan give this a lot more snap than the average cookie-cutter comedy. What's more, Eddie Murphy is back at the top of his form, and he's not being raw, either. This film has some mildly raunchy moments, but by and large it's a holiday comedy that works for both adults and children.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Architecture
description: New Year's Eve is for old acquaintance. For New Year's Day, toast the shock of the new. Startle yourself. Pop a cork on the unfamiliar. Cross a line. Go to a part of New York City you've never visited before. Spread out a subway map, close your eyes and point. Take any bus to the end of the line. Pretend you're going to the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park for a cultural experience; then go to Inwood or Washington Heights and have a real one. Finally take a ride on the Roosevelt Island tramway. Buy a round-trip ticket to Newark just for the pleasure of gazing from the train window at a remarkable landscape: a De-Central Park of factories, cranes and highways rusting gracefully in New Jersey's corroded industrial wetlands.

title: Fireworks, Tears and Doubt in Slovakia
description: The crackle and whistling of fireworks heralded the birth of Europe's newest state today in the same town square where, three years ago, Slovak demonstrators bade farewell to Communism.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Caribbean Female Power

title: Art in Review
description: Luis Gordillo Malborough Gallery 40 West 57th Street Manhattan Through tomorrow

title: Series of Crimes Brings Fear to Brooklyn Project
description: As Lucia Charles got into an elevator at the Sumner Housing project on a cold December morning, a man followed her. Quickly, he put on a ski mask, took out a long knife and demanded money and jewelry. She begged him not to kill her.

title: Pair Who Left Children Home Alone Are Freed
description: The suburban couple who left their young children home alone while they vacationed in Mexico were released from jail today, and their lawyer met with reporters but offered no clues to explain their startling behavior.

title: DON'T GET TOO FULL: THE SUGAR IS FOR DESSERT
description: A national champion at last, one without debate? College football faces that prospect on New Year's Day in the Sugar Bowl match-up of Miami and Alabama, the consensus No. 1 and 2 teams in the nation.

title: Robert S. Lundberg, Architect, 77
description: Robert S. Lundberg, a partner in the New York City architectural and engineering firm of Haines Lundberg Wachler, died on Tuesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Bronxville.

title:
With Respect to the New;
When the Enemy Is Illiterate
description: You must speak as St. Francis more than spoketo the birds -- with your hands out, upturnedto show you mean no harm. And, borrowinga little wisdom from the trees, receiveeverything that comes -- strange nestings,exorbitant winds, blind syllables of lightning,tormented lovers carving their namesin the rough tablet of your lap.Thus you will be obedient not to speech alone,which is only the crude horizon upon which a mighty castlewas put to the torch and consumedin a paralysis of over-exuberant, yet too solemn light.Uncontending, you must yield intention so fullythat the template behind speech will soundlike a resplendent gongabove the aggrieved yet expectant face -- itsclosed radiance as the New Year confetti piles upon your shoulders.Finally, make yourself the site of purposeful failureto decipher harm in the frenzied economyof any message. Remember virtue's unspoken strategy --that we are put on earth as seriously as dreams,as night and silence. The first star of the yearis always over our shoulders.Take the splendid never-again pathwhich allows each clamped beak to divineits surround of feathers.Oh glad and fearful signs of bravest welcome.

title: New Year's Day
description: NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed.

title: Books of The Times; A Novelist's Posthumous Meditation
description: The Furies By Janet Hobhouse 293 pages. Doubleday. $22.50.

title: RAYTHEON GETS AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL PACT FROM INDIA
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that it received an $80 million contract from India's National Airports Authority to modernize air traffic control systems at the Bombay and Delhi airports. Under the agreement, final terms of which are to be negotiated in January, Raytheon said it would provide radars, navigational aids, displays and air traffic automation systems.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Pop and Jazz
description: Strumming guitars and pouring out their hearts, songwriters who sing haven't changed that much since the 1960's. Or have they? The newer guitar-strumming songwriters don't think earnestness is its own reward; they bring humor, ferocity and a touch of post-punk irony to their work.

title: From Tea Leaves to Tarot Cards
description: THE Gypsy Tea Kettle, a short flight of stairs above Lexington Avenue at 56th Street, reigns like a dowager empress over a block lined with discount electronics stores. The sign in its window advertising "Tea Leaves Read Gratis" adds a singular note of quaint, faintly archaic gentility to the hurdy-gurdy drone of the surrounding tawdry commerce.

title: Abroad at Home; New Year Resolution
description: American policy toward Yugoslavia has taken a crucial turn. As reported this week by David Binder of The New York Times, President Bush has warned Serbian leaders that if they extend their Bosnian onslaught to the mainly Albanian province of Kosovo, the United States will intervene.

title: No Harm, No Foul? Oakley Is Fined $10,000
description: A $10,000 fine was levied yesterday against Charles Oakley by the National Basketball Association, infuriating Dave Checketts, the Knicks' president, who contended that the fine was unwarranted and unfair and suggested that the league was out to get Oakley.

title: '93 Bowls: Divide and Sponsor
description: Tonight's game between Miami and Alabama for the putative national championship is the most significant Sugar Bowl since 1983, when second-ranked Penn State defeated top-ranked Georgia, 27-23.

title: Sports of The Times; Highlight Of the Suns' Honeymoon
description: MENTION the Phoenix Suns, and my mind immediately zooms back to Friday, June 4, 1976, at Boston Garden. Game 5 of the National Basketball Association championship series between Boston and Phoenix, the series tied at two games each.

title: The Ball Drops and So Do Rangers
description: John Vanbiesbrouck's unsuccessful outings against the Buffalo Sabres reached a pinnacle tonight, when he allowed 5 goals on 12 shots and was pulled before the second period was 7 minutes old.

title: Today's TV Listings And Dining Reviews
description: Some features ordinarily found in Weekend appear today in section A. Restaurant reviews and advertising are on pages A22-23. Television listings are on page A28.

title: A Debut at Daytona
description: Indianapolis 500 winner AL UNSER JR. plans to make his Nascar Winston Cup Series debut in the Daytona 500 in Florida on Feb. 14. The former Indy-car champion is scheduled to drive a Chevrolet Lumina fielded by Hendrick Motorsports in the season-opening classic at Daytona International Speedway. Only two drivers have won both the Daytona 500 and the Indianapolis 500: A. J. FOYT and MARIO ANDRETTI. (AP)

title: 'Now, Coach Coughlin, About the Bowl Game'
description: When Boston College defeated Penn State on Oct. 17, it was only the second victory by the Eagles in the two schools' 19-game series and thus a milestone in their ambitious program.

title: Chronicle
description: Since he doesn't play golf or tennis, Senator WILLIAM S. COHEN, Republican of Maine, writes. His eighth book and first mystery, "Murder in the Senate," published by Nan A. Talese/ Doubleday, appears today. "Murder" is all about abuse of power, greed and cover-up on Capitol Hill. Its co-author is THOMAS B. ALLEN, a former senior book editor for the National Geographic Society.

title: Boathouse Regulars Wonder Just Who Travis Really Was
description: Travis may have been his name. Travis Something, or Something Travis. Nobody knows for sure.

title: Here Comes Conway
description: CURTIS CONWAY, a wide receiver and kick returner for Southern Cal, will forgo his senior year to make himself available for the National Football League draft. (AP)

title: Review/Photography; Portraits of a People As Seen by Outsiders
description: What's most striking about "400 Years of Native-American Portraits," the richly informative show at the New York Public Library, is the sheer variety of pictures it includes. Many of these are familiar, from the earliest published images of American Indians, by the 16th-century Flemish engraver Johann Theodor de Bry, to the photographs made by Edward S. Curtis in the early years of this century. Taken together, they offer an opportunity to trace how the popular image of Indians has changed over the years.

title: Brazil's New President to Push Job Growth
description: Two days after assuming office, Brazil's new President, Itamar Franco, unveiled his economic program today, a package that probably will slow the country's move toward open, deregulated markets and an economy based on a low inflation rate.

title: Sarajevans Jeer As U.N. Leader Urges Restraint
description: The United Nations Secretary General was jeered in the streets here today when he flew in to press his appeal to the Government not to open a military offensive to break the siege of Sarajevo.

title: Hundreds Block Greenwich Village Street
description: A group of holiday revelers estimated at between 200 and 300 people poured into the street in Greenwich Village early this morning, flinging bottles and blocking traffic in what police described as one of the few major disorderly incidents marking New Year's. Two people were arrested for disorderly conduct, the police said, and parts of Bleecker Street were left covered in a sheet of shattered glass.

title: Looking Backward and Forward
description: Here it is, New Year's Day 1993. A time to look backward and forward, which may be what your head feels like it's doing, simultaneously, right now. A time to predict and prognosticate. A time to dig out last year's predictions and prognostications.

title: Schott Asks for Time
description: Cincinnati Reds owner MARGE SCHOTT has asked baseball to give her until Jan. 25 to respond to preliminary findings in its investigation of the racial and ethnic slurs attributed to her, her lawyer said yesterday.

title:
With Respect to the New;
Little Clown My Heart
description: Little clown my heart,Spangled again and lopsided,

title: To Help Celebrate the Bright New Year
description: Here is a sampling of holiday events, including seasonal music, this weekend in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). New Year's Day

title: Feud Between Top Dinkins Aides Is Seen Hurting Social Programs
description: A feud between two of the Dinkins administration's top officials has become so bitter that it has undermined the city's ability to forge coherent strategies on social issues like homelessness, say advocates for the poor, union leaders and some city officials.

title: INSIDE
description: Overwhelming Underwriting

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-14 SARAJEVANS JEER U.N. CHIEF

title: And a Heck of an Engineer
description: Bobby Ross stores two items in his pocket: a rosary and scrap paper. The rosary, which he will jingle in his palm like spare change, reminds him of the people he has lost. And, on the paper, he will scribble notes to himself, either about a football nuance or whether to stop at an all-night convenience store for milk.

title: Kotite Can Rest Easy
description: NORMAN BRAMAN, owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, isn't going to be impatient getting to what he calls the "next plateau" for his team.

title: Art in Review
description: 'New Housing in Vienna' Parsons School of Design 2 West 13th Street Greenwich Village Through Jan. 15

title: Clinton's Challenge; Starting the Decade -- at Last
description: The Nineties begin today. That it is possible to say this three years after the advent of the decade serves as a sad monument to President Bush's indifference to the nation's social and economic vitality. The statement also defines the task before Bill Clinton, a man of untested promise who has the opportunity and the obligation to shape the ethos of a decade.

title: British Drug Shares Get Lift
description: British pharmaceutical shares got a big year-end lift from decisions this week by the United States Food and Drug Administration to approve various drugs for sale in the world's biggest health-care market.

title: Review/Music; A Mournful but Thunderous Trombone Concerto
description: Christopher Rouse's Trombone Concerto, which received its world premiere in a performance by Leonard Slatkin leading the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall, is an obsessive work. The trombone, an instrument typically associated with slides and energy and swing, with sudden moves and blasts, is here turned into an almost introspective isolate: lyrically mourning, then raging and mourning again. At the beginning, it sings a low, two-note sigh that is almost a groan. Slowly, as if through accumulated grief, that motif grows, supported by shimmers in the orchestra and given energy by roiling percussive thunder.

title: Loans Trickle to Residents After Heavy Storm Damage
description: Almost three weeks after a ferocious rainstorm swept the region, Federal loans and grants have begun to trickle out to residents whose homes and property were damaged. But the largest source of help so far has been private charity.

title: Article 452493 -- No Title
description: More than a third of New York City's schools still burn coal, roofs are leaking and toilets are clogged in hundreds of others, and some buildings are dilapidated wrecks dating to the 19th century, according to a new report.

title:
With Respect to the New;
In the Chemistry Of This Century's Youth
description: In the chemistry of this century's youth,the elements were naked, more changed

title: Girl's Mother Was Warned About Sitter
description: Almost a year before a 9-year-old girl disappeared from the care of John Esposito at a Long Island video arcade, her mother was warned by an official of the local Big Brothers organization that Mr. Esposito's behavior sounded suspicious.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Video
description: Can't find a cab? Stay home and rent Jim Jarmusch's "Night on Earth" (newly released on video by New Line), a 1991 film of five droll, often hilarious vignettes set in and around taxis. As these unconnected stories head east, from high-powered Los Angeles to frigid, boozy Helsinki, they display Mr. Jarmusch's unmistakable wit, warmth and intelligence.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Art
description: In 1992, it was Jeff Koons's giant sculpture of a puppy made of flowers. The front-runner for 1993 Art Pet of the Year may not be as flashy, but it's at least as charming: a 2,000-year-old granite crocodile from Egypt. One of the latest acquisitions by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, it has been installed in a corner of the pool that surrounds the Temple of Dendur, as if floating on the water, waiting to chomp the wayward visitor. The sculpture was made around the same time as the temple, which was dedicated to two young warriors who traditionally are thought to have drowned in the Nile River and may have been devoured by the crocodiles that populated it. There's another connection between sculpture and architecture: in Ptolemaic and Roman Egypt, crocodiles were associated with Isis, to whom the temple is also dedicated.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL SELLS COAL RESERVES AND A MINE
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it sold most of its coal reserves and a coal mine to the Rochester and Pittsburgh Coal Company for $56 million, as it continues to focus on making steel. Rochester and Pittsburgh bought Bethlehem's coal mine near Washington, Pa., with 175 million tons of high quality metallurgical and steam coal reserves. The mine shipped 1.7 million tons of coal in 1991. Bethlehem said last year it wanted to limit its business to making rolled steel used in cars and appliances and making other profitable steel products. The companies agreed on the deal in July.

title: Charter Medical and Texas Settle a Case
description: The Charter Medical Corporation and the Attorney General of Texas disclosed a settlement yesterday growing out of a state investigation of practices in the private psychiatric hospital industry.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: VANCE HEARTENED ON EVE OF PARLEY
description: As he prepared for the first full-scale conference since August of the belligerent parties in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Cyrus R. Vance, a co-chairman of the international peace initiative based here, said he was heartened by several recent diplomatic developments, but he warned that the process "could blow up tomorrow."

title: Chloethiel Woodard Smith, Architect, 82
description: Chloethiel Woodard Smith, a Washington architect who worked on the urban renewal of Southwest Washington and the creation of the new town of Reston, Va., in the 1960's, died on Wednesday at her home in Washington. She was 82.

title: Skiing in the East Need Not Apologize
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: The names on QUEEN ELIZABETH II's New Year's Honor List are familiar in many necks of the woods. Among them: the Oscar-winning actor ANTHONY HOPKINS, the political interviewer DAVID FROST and SHIRLEY WILLIAMS, a former Labor Party cabinet minister.

title: Review/Theater; An Animal Nativity Of Puppets
description: For 30 years, the Bread and Puppet Theater has been enlightening audiences about timeless political issues. Peter Schumann's anniversary show, "Nativity 1992," at Theater for the New City, is one of the troupe's more playful efforts. This animal fable is an exemplar of performance folk art. It reaffirms the fact that Bread and Puppet is entertaining as well as uplifting. This time the message comes in a bright holiday wrapping.

title: A Single Market for Consumers Takes Effect Today in Europe
description: Today is the day a single market goes into effect in Western Europe, linking 345 million people in the 12 nations of the European Community by eliminating tariff and customs barriers. Most steps to reach this goal have been taken gradually over the past five years, so it will be hard for most people to tell what has changed, and indeed, much has not changed. Despite a European Parliament and an executive commission in Brussels, there is nothing resembling a European federal government, and a "United States of Europe" still seems a long way off. What's Good for Business

title: Review/Art; Homelessness Explored At El Museo del Barrio
description: "House of Fire," 1 of the 12 installations by the Puerto Rican artist Antonio Martorell currently at El Museo del Barrio, is a skeletal structure of half-burned furniture parts and wooden planks charred black. The nearby "White House" is fashioned entirely from sheets of pristine Japanese paper decorated with cut-out patterns that suggest both the lace of a communion dress and a popular childhood handicraft raised to a level of grandeur.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Classical Music
description: If the new year can continue to offer performances of the quality of Leonie Rysanek's (she can be seen in Janacek's "Jenufa" at the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow night), it will be a rare year indeed. Ms. Rysanek gives the central role of the stepmother an empathetic grimness: she murders an infant; we feel compassion. Her scenes with Gabriela Benackova as Jenufa turn the gargantuan hall of the Met into a chamber-opera theater.

title: Sports of The Times; Funky Jacket Holds Hurricane Traditions
description: THE green jacket is back in Miami, no doubt offending all the other clothing in the closet with its aroma of six years' worth of defensive end.

title: First-Time Jobless Claims Decline by 28,000
description: First-time claims for unemployment benefits tumbled 28,000 in the most recent four-week reporting period, Labor Department figures indicated today. The average number of claims for the period fell to the lowest level since late 1989.

title:
With Respect to the New;
Home Movies
description: The stiffly-wound celluloidbreaks when we try to uncoil it.

title: Back to the Farm to Seek a Future
description: MANY of Allyn Hurlburt Jr.'s memories of high school in rural Connecticut during World War II revolve around Clarke B. Wood: how Mr. Wood took the vo-ag classes on field trips in his old car, barreling over the hills, and how he'd bring students home for dinner with his family.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows, performances and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that are to close soon. If hours are not listed for today, the shows are closed for New Year's Day. Closing This Weekend

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League CINCINNATI REDS -- Named Davey Johnson, major league consultant and Bobby Valentine, advance scout and advisor for player personnel. Basketball National Basketball Association ATLANTA HAWKS -- Waived Morlon Wiley, guard. Signed Alex Stivrins, forward.

title: A Sort of Neighbor Remembers Shawn
description: To the Editor:

title: William H. Oldendorf, 67, Dies; Developed X-Ray Imaging Device
description: Dr. William H. Oldendorf, a medical researcher whose work helped lead to the development of the CAT scan and magnetic resonance imaging technology, died in a Los Angeles hospital on Dec. 14. He was 67 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Saving on Dining
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Peter Cain Matthew Marks Gallery 980 Madison Avenue (near 78th Street) Through Jan. 28

title: On Stage, and Off
description: All in the Viewpoint

title: Burtt Has Place to Play
description: Former N.B.A. guard STEVE BURTT, who played college ball at Iona, has joined the Oklahoma City Cavalry of the Continental Basketball Association after being banned for life from the Greek basketball league.

title: At the Bar; From Football Glory, a Step Up to Bench
description: The Minnesota Vikings and the Minnesota Supreme Court play their respective games in different parts of the Twin Cities. But the gap will close next week when Alan Page completes a remarkable migration from the gridiron to the bench.

title: Year on Frozen Pond: Ch, Ch, Ch, Changes
description: In 1992, Eric Lindros refused to join the Quebec Nordiques, played in the Olympics for Canada, was traded to two teams on the same day, was the subject of lengthy arbitration dispute, signed with the Philadelphia Flyers for $3.5 million, got off to a good start, got heckled in Quebec by fans wearing baby diapers, suffered a knee injury, got accused of spitting beer at a woman in a bar called Koo-Koo Bananas, got arrested, got healthy and got injured again.

title: A Disappointing 1992 for Many Global Investors
description: For most international investors, particularly those who placed their money in big, liquid foreign stock markets, 1992 promised much more than it delivered. For the third straight year, home -- not East or West -- was mostly best for American investors.

title: Laura Dubman Fratti, Pianist, Is Dead at 69
description: Laura Dubman Fratti, a child prodigy whose expertise as a classical pianist won her critical acclaim in the 1930's and 40's in San Francisco, New York and Paris, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 69.

title: Art in Review
description: Frank Majore Holly Solomon Gallery 724 Fifth Avenue (near 57th Street) Through tomorrow

title: The Spoken Word
description: POETRY READING, Nuyorican Poets Cafe, 236 East Third Street, East Village. A reading by the Downtown Divas, a group of 12 poets. Tonight at 10. Admission: $5. Information: (212) 505-8183.

title: Chinese Opera Troupe
description: The Wei Hai-ming Chinese Theater Troupe will perform as part of Lincoln Center and Con Edison's Community Holiday Festival tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. The troupe, accompanied by the Renaissance and Wen Chow Chinese Opera Societies, will present "Farewell to the King," a traditional Chinese opera based on the overthrow of the tyrannical Emperor Chin at the end of the Chin Dynasty (221-206 B. C.). The performance is free but tickets are required. Information: (212) 431-9740.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Reverses Ruling in Law Firm Bias Case
description: A Federal appeals court ruled Wednesday that a Philadelephia law firm did not engage in sex discrimination when it denied partnership to a woman in 1989.

title: Last-Minute Slide Hits Dow But Nasdaq Rises to Record
description: The Nasdaq average marched to a third straight daily record yesterday while the Dow Jones industrial average fell under a last-minute barrage of program trading.

title: The Giants Set Their Sights on Coughlin
description: The Giants have set no timetable, but they do know whom they want as their next head coach. Tom Coughlin is the No. 1 candidate. Dave Wannstedt is No. 2 and Bill Parcells is probably out of the picture.

title: Clemency Given Jean Harris Leaves 3 Others Wondering
description: Like Jean S. Harris, Arlene Caris, a 64-year-old grandmother with white hair and pink cheeks, is a cooperative prisoner at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility. And like Mrs. Harris, she was a hard worker with no criminal record until she shot and killed the man whose abuse she said she had endured for 14 years.

title: Finding an Economic System for a New Century; Never Better
description: To the Editor:

title: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS GRANTED HUGE RISE IN NEW YORK RATES
description: The Cuomo administration today granted a huge rate increase to Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the state's largest health insurer, presenting 1.4 million New Yorkers with rises in premiums that will average 25.5 percent.

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Books
description: With the advent of a new year, with a new Administration in Washington and with developments abroad that raise new questions about America's place in the world, it seems an apt time to read (or reread) Alexis de Tocqueville's masterpiece, "Democracy in America" (Cloth: Alfred A. Knopf; two volumes, $50. Paper: Vintage Books, Vol. I and Vol. II, $7.95 each).

title: Article 087193 -- No Title
description: Where will Richard Krause turn up next?

title: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93; Recordings
description: Some compact-disk collectors find it odd, even unseemly, to tie up a CD player with recordings made in the days of 78-rpm shellacs. If you are among those puzzled by others' fascination with old recordings, perhaps it's time to append a line to your New Year's resolution list. Promising yourself a few hours to compare the relative merits of modern, mainstream performances, captured in pristine digital sound, with those of original, insightful and often audacious interpretations from decades past, however sonically tarnished they may seem.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: JEAN HARRIS IS ONE, BUT MANY REMAIN

title: Talent, Mouth and Tradition, Not to Mention No. 1 and No. 2
description: Surrounded by the futuristic setting of the Louisiana Superdome, the two highest-ranked college football teams in the nation will attempt to win an unofficial national championship Friday night. Their outlooks will be fashioned by old-style defensive priorities, but they will execute plays with the speed and complexity of the modern game.

title: Fortunate in Hard Times, Many Remember Neediest
description: The recession that has clung to the New York area wrought some of the more disturbing images of 1992: the newly unemployed lining up at soup kitchens, children packed into homeless shelters, more mentally ill people wandering the streets because of cuts in government aid.

title: The First Tastes Of Vintage '93
description: PUTTING a year to bed is somewhat like finishing a fine old bottle of Bordeaux: you are happy to have savored the experience, even more grateful that another waits on the shelf. In New York City's cultural world, this weekend offers a first sip of the new vintage.

title: Surgery for Jennings
description: World cross-country champion LYNN JENNINGS of the United States underwent emergency surgery yesterday in Durham, England, for removal of her appendix.

title: The Top 10 Mutual Funds for Ginnie Maes
description: Ginnie Mae funds own securities issued by the Government National Mortgage Association, which buys mortgages from lenders, pools them and then sells shares to investors, who receive their proportionate part of the homeowners' monthly principal and interest payments.

title: Shouts and Murmurs in Free Slovakia
description: It's not clear that most Czechs or Slovaks really favored the velvet divorce that became final on New Year's Day. But Czechoslovakia, once the model democracy in middle Europe, is no more. Knocking on wood, and with a nervous glance at the disintegrating Balkans, Americans can only join the celebrants and wish a prosperous life to the new Slovak Republic and the new Czech Republic.

title: In a Striving Section of the Bronx, The Races Mix, but Don't Mingle
description: Joe Kraus tries not to think about race, but being retired, he's got time on his hands. The other day, as he sat near two other elderly white men playing cards in a Bronx social club, Mr. Kraus allowed himself this simple proposition: People can live together peaceably, more or less.

title: Sports of The Times; Country Boys Win Big One In Big City
description: THEY grew tired of being called country cousins. That wasn't why Alabama won the national championship with a 34-13 whupping of Miami in the Sugar Bowl late last night. But they did grow tired of being called country cousins.

title: Police Trace Call by Missing Girl to Pay Phone
description: The Suffolk County Police today continued their search for the 10-year-old Mastic, L.I., girl missing since Monday, checking telephone records of her friends and relatives and tracing to a pay phone a frantic call she apparently made after she disappeared.

title: Riley Has 10,000 Reasons Why the N.B.A. Is Out of Bounds
description: Both Charles Oakley and Coach Pat Riley remained upset today about the $10,000 fine that was levied on Thursday against the Knicks forward by the National Basketball Association for an incident Wednesday night against Indiana in which Oakley was not even charged with a foul.

title: Tapping Your Home to Lift Your Income
description: Older homeowners who spent decades writing monthly mortgage checks are increasingly tapping that investment to bolster retirement income with reverse mortgages.

title: Ban Lifted on Blood Donations From Gulf Veterans
description: The American Association of Blood Banks and the Department of Defense have lifted the ban on blood donations by military personnel who served in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Moi Well Ahead in Kenya, but Most in Cabinet Lose
description: Citing what they said was across-the-board cheating and vote rigging, leaders of Kenya's three strongest opposition parties announced today that they would not accept the outcome of this week's elections, which appear to have returned President Daniel arap Moi to office with the prospect of a majority in Parliament.

title: Women Explore a Percussive Path of Expression
description: When she first laid a hand on an African drum at a music festival three years ago, Penny Gnesin set off, with a gentle thud, on a complex journey through rhythm and consciousness.

title: Bewildered in Buffalo, Rangers Look for Answers
description: The Rangers were so bewildered after their humiliating loss to the Sabres in Buffalo on Thursday night that they were at a loss for words afterward as they tried to explain their worst thrashing since 1985.

title: MSI Electronic reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Calder's Playful 'Big Crinkly' To Winter in Manhattan Park
description: The gardens of Bryant Park will be brighter beginning in mid-January when "Big Crinkly," a 1971 work by Alexander Calder, takes up temporary residence.

title: Wake for Timothy Healy
description: A wake for the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, the Jesuit priest who was the president of the New York Public Library and former president of Georgetown University, will be held tomorrow and Monday, from 2 to 5 P.M. and 7 to 9 P.M., at America House, 106 West 56th Street. The funeral will be on Tuesday at 10 A.M. at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue and 84th Street. Father Healy, 69, had a fatal heart attack on Wednesday night at Newark International Airport.

title: Q & A
description: Converting Savings Bonds

title: High Court to Consider Rules On Use of Scientific Evidence
description: Jason Daubert, of San Diego, was born 19 years ago with only two fingers on his right hand and without a lower bone on his right arm. Eric Schuller, 12, also of San Diego, was born without a left hand and with one leg shorter than the other.

title: Learn to Walk, Learn to Fly
description: The Op-Ed Page asked students in two New York City school districts, District 9 in the South Bronx and District 28 in Bayside, Queens, to write about their hopes and fears. Here are excerpts from their essays. Charisse Rice 4th grade, (Mount Hope) P.S. 28 Tremont, the Bronx

title: The Guns of Virginia
description: It's common lore on the sidewalks of New York: If you want a gun, go to Virginia, where weak laws and willing dealers allow almost anyone to acquire firearms.

title: Cintas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain from culumative effect in accounting principle change for income taxes of $ 2,705,000, or 6 cents a share.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Ashikaga Journal; A Festival That Permits Japanese to Be Impolite
description: The life of a typical Japanese -- working endless hours, enduring long commutes on packed trains and adhering to rigid rules of behavior -- would drive many Americans to the brink of rage. But Japanese seem to bottle up any anger and maintain their world-famous politeness.

title: Dresser Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 18,600,000 and $ 35,300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, an extraordinary charge of $ 2,600,000 and $ 6,300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, for debt reduction, which included an after-tax charge of $ 41 million for restructuring and the year also included a charge of $ 393,800,000 from an accounting adjustment.c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $ 6,800,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9,200,000, or 7 cents a share, in the year, and an extraordinary credit of $ 2,600,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 5,600,000, or 4 cents a share, for the year, for debt reduction, which both included an after-tax charge of $ 41 million for restructuring.In the latest results prior quarters have been restated for effects of accounting changes and additional discontinued operations.Latest income from continuing operations of $ 16,700,000, or 13 cents a share, and $ 69,900,000, or 52 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, included charges of $ 41 million for the quarter and $ 71 million for the year, for restructuring and accounting changes.Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: Devils' Year Begins Like Day-Old Bubbly
description: From the coaches to the goaltender to the last player on the fourth line, nothing went right for the New Jersey Devils this afternoon as they were routed, 9-2, by Washington here at the Capital Centre.

title: For the Do-It-Yourself Financial Planner, Software to the Rescue
description: People who keep careful financial records, tracking how much they have spent and comparing the outflow with their budgets, are apt to spend less and save more than people who simply buy now and pay later.

title: No Headline
description: Word is out that Federal and state law prohibits pregnancy discrimination, so employers are typically more devious and couch discrimination in other terms. During an economic downturn, employers can mask pregnancy discrimination as layoffs and downsizing, which makes it harder to prove the underlying discriminatory motivation. -- SALLY GOLDFARB, a lawyer for the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund. [ 1:2. ]

title: On Lonely Mission, Robot Starts Descent Into Volcano
description: The robot Dante stepped into the inferno today as it started down into an Antarctic volcano on a mission that could be a prelude to robotic exploration of the Moon and other planets, scientists said.

title: Czechs and Slovaks Are Hoping to Find Prosperity in a New Independence
description: The Kaucuk factory has survived for 30 years turning out synthetic rubber, plastics and refined petroleum mostly for the domestic Czechoslovak market. With the demise of Czechoslovakia this morning, the future of this company, and many others like it in the Czech Republic, are now tied to the uncertain fortunes of a foreign country: Slovakia.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 ARMS PACT IS TEST FOR YELTSIN

title: Freedom Under Arrest -- A special report; Burmese Loosen Up; Outsiders Are Skeptical
description: Late last fall, a dark sedan carrying a group of olive-uniformed army officers raced down University Avenue in Yangon toward the home of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the dissident who won the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize for her campaign to bring democracy to Myanmar, the nation once called Burma.

title: Roll Tide! Alabama Dethrones No. 1 Miami
description: Gene Stallings went for the ride of his life tonight.

title: Critic's Notebook; Grove Opera Dictionary Can Make Experts Of Dilettante and Pro
description: Before buying the New Grove Dictionary of Opera, make sure your back is sound enough to lift it. Next, check the sag factor in your bookcase. These are four bruising volumes, not a row of paperbacks.

title: Liberty State Park Is Set To Open Science Center
description: On a knoll here in a far corner of Liberty State Park sits a glistening new $67 million science center, getting ready for a grand opening on Jan. 24. Its motto is "Science = Fun," and it is chock-full of exhibits for inquisitive kids of all ages.

title: Policies for Covering Cost of Long-Term Care
description: MORE and more Americans are becoming aware of the possibility that at some point in their lives they will require extended care in a nursing home or their own homes because of a prolonged illness or disability. As a result, purchases of long-term-care insurance policies, intended to cover part of the increasingly high costs of such care, are rapidly increasing.

title: Hmm, Haven't We Met Somewhere Before? Yes, in Regular Season
description: New meets old in today's two National Football League playoff match ups.

title: History or Heresy? Churchill's War Role Attacked
description: With a sudden ferocity, scholars, amateur historians and even politicians here have joined an emotional debate that seems as strange as it is inflammatory. Would Britain be better off today had Churchill been more willing in World War II to negotiate an earlier end to the fighting with Germany?

title: Schwinn Ready to Sell Most Assets
description: After 97 years of family ownership, the Schwinn Bicycle Company plans to ask a Federal bankruptcy judge here on Tuesday for permission to sell most of its assets, including its name, to the Zell-Chilmark Fund, an investment partnership that specializes in acquiring financially strapped businesses, and Scott U.S.A., a company in Sun Valley, Idaho, that makes ski equipment and bicycles.

title: Using Garage Sales to Help Save a Swamp
description: For years, civilization has been nibbling at the Dismal Swamp, more than 400 acres of marshland where generations of boys have caught frogs and snakes and older hunters have stalked pheasants and deer without fear of bullets going astray in someone's backyard.

title: Another Opening, Another Year; Curtain Is Raised on '93 With Readings, Football, Food and Icy Plunges
description: New Year's Day is a peculiar holiday -- a day, unlike other holidays, without any religious or political significance for most people, a holiday just because a new year has begun and some day has to be first.

title: Etymology of Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexander Neuwirth, Investment Banker, 60
description: Alexander Neuwirth, an investment banker who opened the first Tokyo office for Burnham & Company, died on Thursday at New Milford Hospital in New Milford, Conn. He was 60 and lived in Manhattan.

title: On the Couch on Bowl Day: Send in the Clowns
description: Woke up for New Year's Bowl Day Georgia Bulldog-tired. Stayed up late with "Nick at Nite" to watch Chuckles the Clown die again on "The Mary Tyler Moore Show." Fatigue is a bad when there are eight bowls to watch. In the beginning at 11 A.M. there was the Hall of Fame Bowl, which begat the Cotton, Citrus and Blockbuster Bowls, leading to a long day's journey into Sugar:

title: 3 Crossing Queens Blvd. Hit and Killed
description: Three pedestrians were struck and killed on Queens Boulevard in Kew Gardens last night by a driver who was charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Paradise Loses Visitors

title: Ponder Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 28,000 from operating loss carryforward.c-Net loss

title: Vatican's Secular Treasures On View
description: Legend has it that the love letters of Henry VIII to Anne Boleyn wound up in the Vatican Library when a mischievous clerk slipped them into the pages of the King's "Defense of the Seven Sacraments," an orthodox defense of Roman Catholic doctrine by a monarch soon to break from Rome.

title: Car-Animal Accidents Raise Concern
description: Here in the suburbs where the car is king, the merging of man and nature has led to concern over how to prevent the collisions that every year kill thousands of animals, large and small.

title: Dewey Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II celebrated the New Year yesterday with special prayers for an end to the conflict in the republics of the former Yugoslavia, the Reuters news agency reported. He also condemned violence in Africa and the Middle East.

title: No End to the Mexican Kidnap Case
description: A judge's dismissal of murder charges against Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain has not stilled the anger -- on both sides of the border -- over the torture-killing of a U.S. drug agent and the abduction of Dr. Alvarez in Mexico for his trial in Los Angeles. Mexico still voices outrage. A brazen State Department belatedly calls on Mexico to try the doctor for the crime.

title: Orange Find Footing to Beat Buffaloes
description: Colorado hadn't played on grass all season; Syracuse hadn't played on it since September, and neither team had played on anything like this: sand, mixed with dirt and grass, reduced to clay by frequent rain during the last five days at Sun Devil Stadium.

title: Slight Dip in Homicides In New York City in 1992
description: The number of reported homicides in New York City dipped slightly last year, continuing a drop that police officials say could be attributed to factors ranging from shifts in personal behavior to demographics to community policing.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, the Jesuit priest who was president of the New York Public Library and former president of Georgetown University, misstated the dates of his wake. It will be held tomorrow and Monday -- not today -- from 2 to 5 P.M. and from 7 to 9 P.M., at America House, 106 West 56th Street in Manhattan.

title: Truck With Missiles Crashes in Louisiana
description: A truck carrying Army antiaircraft missiles swerved across an interstate highway and crashed late Thursday. As a precaution, the authorities closed three miles of the road and evacuated about 1,000 people, barring them from their homes overnight.

title: Orr Out of Hospital
description: Iowa State's basketball coach, JOHNNY ORR, was resting at home yesterday in Ames, Iowa, after an overnight stay at the hospital.

title: Simms and Hostetler Eye the Door
description: The Giants without Phil Simms? Without Jeff Hostetler? Brace yourself, because next season, no matter who replaces Ray Handley as the head coach, one of those veteran quarterbacks is likely to be gone.

title: President Visits Center of Crisis In Somali Town
description: As United States troops blocked roads and posted armed lookouts on rooftops, President Bush ventured today into the epicenter of the Somalia famine, praising the American forces that had successfully escorted food convoys but pledging that when the time comes, "we'll do what I told the American people we'll do -- we'll leave."

title: Kettle Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a gain of $ 57,000 related to the repurchase of debentures.c-Included a gain of $ 1,446,000 from workers' compensation premiums refunded due to the successful appeal of a 1990 rate modification.

title: Who Killed Jeffrey Harden?
description: Jeffrey Harden, who died last January at the age of 5 months, was a victim of abuse and neglect -- by his family and by New York City.

title: PCC Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary items of $ 1,226,000, or 55 cents a share, in the quarter and year.

title: Seminoles' Bowl Victory Turns Into Dreary Event
description: Relegated to a side stage for national title consideration, Florida State still made a strong statement tonight in the Orange Bowl game.

title: Violence Disrupted Exemplary College
description: To the Editor:

title: Resolutions to Resolve Old Resolution Conflicts
description: TYPICALLY for this time of year, the Old Guy was morose. Once again lofty intentions lay threatened by chronically weak and seasonally dyspeptic willpower. The hope-frustration-guilt-cycle loomed, as it had every year for decades. Ever since gray hairs were first sighted, the phases of the cycle have been accelerating annually. In 1992, the first piece of chocolate was consumed before New Year's lunch, the unwritten novel had been fully abandoned by Groundhog Day and the possibility of moral regeneration rejected before the spring thaw.

title: Eagles Lose, but Will Giants Gain?
description: Following the victory by Tennessee in the Hall of Fame Bowl game here today, the losing coach, Tom Coughlin of Boston College, refused to address his future as a candidate for the position of head coach of the New York Giants. Coughlin was angry, which was completely understandable because his Eagles played so poorly in losing to the Volunteers, 38-23.

title: Rescue by Valenzuela
description: Jockey PATRICK VALENZUELA rescued a 9-year-old boy from a burning motor home on Wednesday night in Arcadia, Calif., it was learned Thursday. Valenzuela, one of the nation's leading riders, was on his way to dinner with friends when the incident took place.

title: Lost Bowl, and then Coach, at Southern Cal
description: The University of Southern California, which was routed by Fresno State in the Freedom Bowl earlier this week, today announced that Larry Smith had resigned as its head football coach.

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial institutions around the world were closed yesterday for the New Year's holiday.

title: Pasadena Journal; Seeing Too Much of One Color in the Tournament of Roses
description: The last thing the image makers want is a sullied picture. Pasadena, which throws the biggest, most lavish bash in the country every New Year's Day, has worked hard to maintain its imperturbable, all-American front, the illusion that nothing can go wrong in a place so perfect.

title: An Increase in Bias Is Seen Against Pregnant Workers
description: Five weeks after giving birth to triplets last year, Joan Levine received a phone call from the head of FCB/Leber Katz Partners, the advertising agency in New York where she had worked for 12 years. He called to say another woman would get a chance at her job.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Romeo Muller Jr., 64, Writer for Animation
description: Romeo Muller Jr., a television writer who created family Christmas favorites including "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer," "Frosty the Snowman," "The Little Drummer Boy" and "Santa Claus Is Coming to Town," died on Wednesday at his home in High Falls, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: Phillips Re-signs With the Tigers
description: The Detroit Tigers have agreed on a $10.6 million, three-year contract with TONY PHILLIPS, avoiding salary arbitration with their do-it-all leadoff hitter. The 33-year-old Phillips, who signed the contract on Thursday, has been an everyday player without an everyday position since coming to Detroit as a free agent from Oakland after the 1989 season.

title: Uncertain Future for Last Baths on Lower East Side;
description: The 10th Street Russian and Turkish baths are the last survivor of the sort of Eastern European-style public baths that once dotted the Lower East Side. Their searing Russian room, ice-cold pool, vigorous massages and fresh-squeezed fruit and vegetable juices have attracted the likes of John Belushi, Mick Jagger, Frank Sinatra and John F. Kennedy Jr. Alexander Frish, the ringmaster of the Moscow Circus, hangs out there when he is in town.

title: YELTSIN RECEIVING CRITICISM OF FOES ON NUCLEAR TREATY
description: On the eve of President Bush's arrival here to sign a nuclear arms reduction treaty, President Boris N. Yeltsin is being criticized for pushing through an accord that some say serves American interests and confirms Russia's subordinate status in a post-Communist world.

title: Paraguay Raises Its Profile As a Center for Investment
description: For decades, the only press Paraguay received was a bad press: a stereotyped Latin American dictatorship where unrepentant Nazis mingled with fugitive heroin dealers and homegrown cigarette smugglers.

title: Let's Scrap the Council of Economic Advisers
description: To the Editor:

title: Toll Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: A Business Guide to the New Europe
description: The new year brings new rules to the European Community, which hoped to create a single market for its 345 million people. AIRLINES

title: Hawaii Is Rethinking Its Dependency on Tourism
description: When final figures are in, 1992 will show the worst reversal for Hawaii tourism since the state converted its economy from plantation agriculture to world-class resort a generation ago. Odd as it seems, many Hawaiians are not sure if that is good or bad.

title: Clinton, Off and Running, Sees the Sun Rise on '93
description: Most Americans spend New Year's Day as coach potatoes, loafing before the ball games on the tube, resting from the rigors of the year and the night before.

title: Let's Scrap the Council of Economic Advisers; Room for Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Neediest Cases Assists Victim of Mental Illness
description: When William K. lived alone in the mid-1980's, he said, he would hallucinate that the Mafia and the Government were after him.

title: Israelis Wonder if Expulsions Aren't More Than an Image Problem
description: When the Government expelled 415 Palestinians from the occupied territories two weeks ago, many Israelis justified the move as a necessary response to a surge of killings by Islamic militants. But as the exiles remain stranded in southern Lebanon, a public debate has developed here over whether the deportation has tarnished both Israel's image abroad and its values at home.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: The Irish Leave A&M Feeling 100% Rotten
description: They came seeking solace and left in shame. This was not a new experience for the Aggies of Texas A&M.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY WHERE RACES MIX BUT DON'T MINGLE

title: Bridge
description: New Laws of Bridge, for social games as distinct from duplicate competition, came into force yesterday. One feature is a softening of the two-trick revoke penalty, which becomes one trick unless the revoker personally wins the revoke trick or if the card he should have played later takes a trick.

title: Some Highs and Lows Of Buying on Margin
description: IN September, John Appley, a businessman in Clearwater, Fla., sued his broker at Paine Webber, Robert Magnan, for losses from what he said were unauthorized trades of stocks and mutual funds in brokerage accounts worth more than half a million dollars. Mr. Appley seeks to recover $145,000 in portfolio losses plus $16,000 in interest that had accrued on nearly $375,000 in margin loans that Mr. Appley said he had not approved.

title: Prenuptial Agreements, Despite Challenges, Stand Up in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Teamwork Concept Faces Challenge
description: There is a certain indisputable logic to the ubiquitous management approach that travels under many rubrics, including employee participation, involvement or empowerment programs, quality circles or work teams.

title: King Back With Bullets
description: Washington Bullets forward BERNARD KING, who has been out of action for more than a year because of knee problems, has returned to the team, the Bullets' owner, ABE POLLIN, said yesterday.

title: In Hartford, Data Portray Schools in Crisis of Poverty
description: Reduced to charts and graphs, the state of Hartford's schools was vividly displayed in Superior Court here this week as civil-rights lawyers presented crucial evidence in a lawsuit seeking to integrate the capital city's schools with those of its suburbs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Citing bad publicity from his recent arrest on drug charges, the actor TODD BRIDGES has resigned as head of a youth center he founded, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Bridges, 27, told about 20 people at the center, the Todd Bridges Youth Foundation, that he was leaving because he didn't want its work to suffer.

title: Gretzky Sets a Date
description: WAYNE GRETZKY, sidelined since training camp by a back condition that threatened his career, hopes to return to the Los Angeles Kings for a Jan. 16 game against Winnipeg.

title: Michigan on Top When See-Saw Stops
description: Coming in, the 79th Rose Bowl had been difficult to market. Michigan may have been undefeated this season, but it also had a decade worth of ties -- three. Washington may have been the defending national champion, but in the fall it had undergone a decade worth of internal investigation. So, there was only enough intrigue today to attract a crowd of 94,236, the smallest Rose Bowl gathering in 38 years.

title: El Salvador Warned on Purge Deadline
description: The United Nations Secretary General warned President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador today that he appeared to have violated the agreement last month ending the 12-year civil war in his country by not meeting the deadline for the purge of army officers accused of human-rights abuses.

title: The New Reverse Mortgage
description: Some older homeowners may obtain one to help meet expenses: This couple pledged their $145,000 home as collateral for monthly payments of $277 for life. Page 35. [ Photo ]

title: Ross Bass, Ex-Senator; Tennessean Was 75
description: Ross Bass, who represented Tennessee in Congress from 1954 to 1966, died today at his home in North Miami, Fla. He was 75.

title: Gasoline Tax Plan Is Reviving
description: President-elect Bill Clinton, who repeatedly criticized Paul Tsongas and Ross Perot in the Presidential campaign for supporting an increase in Federal gasoline taxes, is hearing from a lot of his advisers that it is not such a bad idea after all, and he seems to be warming to the idea.

title: Jean Mayer, 72, Nutritionist Who Led Tufts, Dies
description: Dr. Jean Mayer, the Chancellor and former president of Tufts University whose work as a nutritionist helped clarify the nature of hunger and obesity and expanded the Federal food stamp and school lunch programs, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., where he was vacationing. He was 72 and lived in Boston.

title: Before You Pity the Russians in Estonia
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; A New Year's Eve Party With an American Accent
description: It was inevitable that someone would eventually challenge the moldy and not entirely explainable tradition of surrendering New Year's Eve concerts to parades of frothy, 19th-century Viennese ballroom music. Leonard Slatkin, who conducted the New York Philharmonic's New Year's Eve concert on Thursday evening, has been toying with that tradition lately.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Very Crafty, Indeed Ridden by Richard Migliore, Win Crafty Lady scored a pace-setting, one-length victory over Wood So in the $100,000 Interborough Breeders' Cup at Aqueduct yesterday. Quick Mischief, the 7-5 favorite, was a neck back in third. The mare, trained by Robert Barbara, covered 6 furlongs in 1:10 1/5 to win the first New York stakes race of 1993. She earned $66,600 for owner Sabine Stable.

title: College's Fight to Survive Mirrors Plight of Many Black Campuses
description: Morris Brown College has never loomed large on the national stage -- not when it opened in a crude wooden building 108 years ago, and not in its current incarnation as one of six colleges in the mainly black Atlanta University Center.

title: Pepperell Reports a Deficit
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. has reported a third-quarter loss of $179.6 million, in contrast to net income of $2.5 million, or 9 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: Religion Notes
description: Fighting Evil

title: Look, It's, It's . . . the Swamp Thing; At Byrne Arena, 7-Foot Shower Heads, Mrs. Fields Cookies and Ennui
description: This is where sound goes to die: The towering black roof of Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the largest segmented dome in the world.

title: Bassett Furniture Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain on marketable securities of $ 771,000, or 10 cents a share.c-Included charge of $ 448,000 for net unrealized losses on marketable securities in the quarter, and the year included an after-tax unrealized gain of $ 1,382,000, or 12 cents a share, on marketable securities.Latest share earnings for both the quarter and year are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed April 6.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Lidak Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
U.N. Chief Seeks Basis for Peace in Somalia Today
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations is to visit this ravaged nation on Sunday as he begins a new effort to bring together Somalia's battling factions and restore civil authority to a country that has been without a government for two years.

title: Where Whirlpool Flies, and Maytag Sputters
description: NO Norman Rockwell kitchen scene would seem complete without gleaming appliances bearing names like Whirlpool and Maytag lined up like soldiers on review.

title: Ms. Mittelstadt, Othon Prounis
description: Monica Geli Mittelstadt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Mittelstadt of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Othon Alexander Prounis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore O. Prounis of New York. Archbishop Iakovos, the primate of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, gave the blessing at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. The Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Tide Wins With 6 Key Plays
description: The coach's message had been the same in front of the television lights as it had been in front of his players. The understated philosophy of Alabama Coach Gene Stallings was consistent throughout the season:

title: Cash Theft Shows Risks of Armored Car Business
description: They are routinely entrusted with the ultimate in valuables, prize cargoes more coveted than jewels or furs, antiquities, truffles or narcotics. But the largely unregulated courier services that collect and deliver billions of dollars of other people's money in the New York region and around the nation every day are dismayingly vulnerable to theft, particularly inside jobs, law-enforcement officials and industry experts say.

title: Carla McCrie, Hajime Kobayashi
description: Carla Alexandra McCrie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. McCrie of New York, was married on Monday to Hajime Kobayashi, the son of Ambassador Tomohiko Kobayashi and Mrs. Kobayashi of Brussels. The Rev. Scott Campbell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the International Protestant Church of Brussels.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SMALL GAMEBy John Blades.Holt, $19.95.

title: How to Cope When a Solution Shares the Problem
description: In a room filled with 113 students, talking in 4- and 5-year-old voices, a shrill blow of a whistle brings order out of the chaos of four kindergarten classes going on at once. Storybook lessons trail off. Building blocks clunk to the floor. A tenuous calm falls.

title: The State of the Union in the Kingdom of Pan
description: One of the great themes of Western music criticism is how bad things have become, how drastically composition and performance have declined, how little can be expected from contemporary musical life compared with the glories of the Golden Age. Such complaints could have been heard in Monteverdi's time. No doubt Bach felt similarly, observing the rococo amusements of his sons' generation. Berlioz was almost obsessive on this theme, parodying the conditions of the orchestra and the opera house in sardonic prose.

title: When Exotic Really Is the Right Word
description: ETHIOPIAN fare is exotic enough but Caffe Adulis in New Haven takes unusual ethnic dining one step farther in offering Eritrean fare as well. Eritrea is part of Ethiopia (on the northeast coast, bordering the Red Sea), and the restaurant is named for an Eritrean port city. Although the restaurant is barely three months old, its popularity was already evident on recent visits there.

title: Joseph R. Burstin, Theater Producer, 85
description: Joseph R. Burstin, a theater producer and the founder of an advertising company, died on Dec. 27. He was 85 and lived in Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: Ancient Clay Horse Is Found in Syria
description: A craftsman 4,300 years ago molded the clay figurine of a horse, only five inches long and three inches high, but exquisite in detail. It has now been uncovered in northern Syria by archeologists who call it the oldest known sculpture of a domesticated horse and one of the finest ancient representations of a horse ever discovered.

title: A Remembrance Of Visions Pure And Elegant
