title: Review/Opera; Italian Bass Makes Debut In Final 'Semiramide' Series
description: The time came, on Thursday evening, for the Metropolitan Opera to deploy such big guns as it could muster in Rossini's "Semiramide." The current run of the John Copley production, which began in October with a second-line cast, will end next Saturday afternoon, with the performance to be broadcast over the Texaco-Metropolitan Opera International Radio Network.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL AGREES TO SELL METROMEDIA PAGING
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Metromedia Paging Services to New York-based Locate. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Locate is a closely held company that provides local digital microwave services to long-distance companies. Metromedia Paging, based in Ridgefield Park, N.J., is one of the nation's largest paging companies, with almost 1.1 million pagers in service in 31 markets.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline yesterday about a California surfing figure in the 1950's and 60's referred to him incorrectly in some copies. He was Dewey Weber

title: Making a Home in the House Depends on Luck; New Members of Congress Select Offices from the Discards of Last Year's Election
description: Amid a jumble of furniture and canyons of boxes, Michael Hutton mapped out work spaces in the sparse new office of his boss, freshman Representative Robert Menendez of New Jersey.

description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: 4 Dinkins Advisers in the Running for Jobs in Washington
description: Four of Mayor David N. Dinkins chief social policy advisers, including Andrew M. Cuomo, who headed his commission on homelessness, are in the running for high-ranking jobs in the Clinton Administration, city and Clinton transition officials said yesterday.

title: Shift Urged on Foreign Stakes in Airlines
description: Many of the original reasons for restricting foreign ownership in United States airlines no longer apply, a Government report published today concludes. But the report said the Government should approve only those investments that increased competition in the American airline industry.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE SHOWS NO CHANGE
description: Employers' payrolls grew by a modest 64,000 jobs in December as the nation's unemployment rate remained at 7.3 percent, the Labor Department said today in a report that underscores how slowly the job market is reacting to economic expansion.

title: Helen of Troy reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago periods are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock dividend paid Oct. 1. The company said increased profit margins were due to lower advertising and interest expenses.The compay is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: U.S. Tries to Verify Compliance As Iraqi Missile Deadline Passes; U.N. Condemns Iraq Move
description: The Security Council tonight condemned Iraq's announcement earlier in the day that it will no longer allow United Nations arms inspectors to be flown into Iraqi territory in United Nations aircraft. Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, said in Baghdad that the inspection teams henceforth would be required to fly in chartered Iraqi planes.

title: East German Native Is Expected to Be Bonn's New Economics Chief
description: The Free Democratic Party nominated Gunter Rexrodt, a onetime banker, businessman and native of East Germany, as Economics Minister today in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's beleaguered coalition Government.

title: Hong Kong's Money War
description: Conventional wisdom holds that the spat between Britain and China was triggered by Gov. Christopher Patten's effort to expand democratization before Hong Kong reverts to China in 1997. This misperception ignores China's brisk march to capitalism and the role of the colony's Chinese entrepreneurs in it.

title: Let Them Count Before They Calculate
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Switzerland reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Perseverance Has Paid Off for Weight
description: The lowest moment came on Dec. 4 in Landover, Md. The Rangers lost their ugliest game of the season, to the Washington Capitals, and Doug Weight watched from the front row of the press box. He was frustrated, angry and more than a little impatient with his fate.

title: BeautiControl Cosmetics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: BeautiControl Cosmetics said that fourth quarter results were impacted by more than $ 1,300,000 from costs associated with new programs, which include new career and compensation opportunities for their consultants, new recognition programs for consultants and new recruiting and selling tools.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Round 2 of the Playoffs -- Montana and Kelly Get to Cheer; Bills Travel to a Reality Check
description: There are enough subplots in this afternoon's American Football Conference divisional playoff game between Buffalo and Pittsburgh on national television to support numerous spinoffs.

title: A Tax Plan That Won't Help Schools
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo commanded plenty of attention this week when he proposed allowing New York State's counties to use income rather than property taxes to finance schools. But what sounded like a broad, lofty reform is really aimed at a narrow problem: helping people whose incomes can't keep pace with rising property values. The Governor barely touched on the larger issue of achieving broad reforms that would provide more aid to poor school districts.

title: Season Begins In Arbitration
description: Jeff Huson, a Texas Rangers infielder, yesterday became the first player to file for salary arbitration. The filing deadline is next Friday for the 126 eligible players.

title: Issues of Survival for Declining Union
description: The latest painful labor battle at The Daily News is a sign of the decline of the power of unions in the New York City newspaper industry, highlighting deep and, some say, permanent divisions between New York unions that once derived their power from unity.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on the Business Technology page on Dec. 23 about the use of computers to track stolen art gave an incorrect figure for the number of images stored by the system, operated by the International Art and Antiques Loss Register. While the data base can store 350,000 images, the number currently stored is closer to 35,000. The company's New York affiliate was also incompletely identified. It is the International Foundation for Art Research.

title: Chief Retires At Carolina Freight Line
description: Kenneth E. Mayhew said yesterday that he would take early retirement as chairman, president and chief executive of the Carolina Freight Corporation, effective Jan. 31.

title: Dispute Adds to Confusion In Search for Missing Girl
description: Almost two weeks after she disappeared, the Suffolk County police have found no trace of 10-year-old Katie Beers, and the County Police Commissioner said yesterday that the search has been complicated by a long-running dispute between Katie's mother and Katie's godmother, with whom the child spent most of her life.

title: Ewing Waits for Call as O'Neal Gets Last Word
description: Tonight's game ended with the Orlando Magic celebrating, while Patrick Ewing stared at the referees in disbelief, waiting for a foul to be called against Shaquille O'Neal. The call never came. The Knicks lost, despite leading by 10 points with six minutes left. And Ewing seethed over the game's final play.

title: A Founder of Next Resigns; Switch to Software Is Seen
description: Richard A. Page, a co-founder with Steven P. Jobs of the computer maker Next Inc., resigned as general manager of hardware today, increasing speculation that the company was moving to become a software publisher.

title: Both Sides in Allen Suit Scolded for Courting Press
description: The judge in the custody battle between Woody Allen and Mia Farrow upbraided their lawyers yesterday for taking the case to reporters, accusing them of duplicity in claiming to want to shield their children from publicity.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Snippet from the Inauguration guest list: the people compiling the invitation list for President-elect BILL CLINTON have cast the a wide net indeed. Reaching back to Mr. Clinton's days as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University in the late 1960's, they invited his college porter, DOUGLAS MILLIN. As porter, Mr. Millin took telephone messages and served as security monitor and general factotum at University College.

title: Dow Off 17.29 in 4th Fall in Row
description: Queasy investors sent stocks zigging and zagging yesterday, leaving the Dow with its fourth straight drop in heavy trading and a loss of almost 50 points for the first week of the year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Oklahoma Routs West Texas State Bryan Sallier had 26 points and 10 rebounds last night as No. 11 Oklahoma routed West Texas State, 121-71, in Norman, Okla. The Sooners (11-2) held West Texas State (9-4), a Division II team, to 34 percent shooting, and forced 29 turnovers and tied a school record with 14 blocked shots, 7 by Kenneth Conley. (AP) Princeton 63, Harvard 39: A devastating 28-6 opening run powered the Tigers to an easy victory at home in their Ivy League opener. At the end of the first half, Princeton (7-4) led Harvard (3-9, 0-2 in the Ivy League) by 31-12 as the Crimson shot just 8 percent from the field. Princeton's Chris Yetman finished with 18 points, 12 on 3-pointers, to lead all scorers. (AP)

title: Schott to Go Before Executive Committee
description: The Cincinnati Reds' owner, MARGE SCHOTT, will speak with baseball's ruling executive council on Jan. 22 to answer allegations that she made racial and ethnic slurs.

title: Comfortable, Until Proved Guilty
description: Accustomed as we are to bureaucratic incompetence and inertia, it comes almost as a shock to those of us who work in prison reform when we encounter a government program that works. When it happens twice in one week, our heads reel.

title: Princeton Coach Is Given Reprimand
description: Princeton Coach BILL TIERNEY was publicly reprimanded by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for his actions during the Division I championships last spring.

title: Truth on Tap
description: Some say it tastes better. Others think it's safer. But fully 25 percent of the pricey bottled water popular among Americans comes from the same source as ordinary tap water -- notwithstanding brand names and label images evoking natural streams and the great outdoors.

title: Insight; Hectic January
description: Three days this week were among the busiest dozen of the past year on the New York Stock Exchange. If the past is any guide, there may soon be more: Five Days from January 1992 made the list. 201 million shares were traded on an average day in the past year.

title: Cuomo Proposes to End 'Back-Door Financing'
description: It has become a familiar ritual. Every year, New York State faces another yawning budget gap. And every year, it comes up with another creative financing maneuver to balance its books and borrow money for things like prisons and roads.
