title: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The President-Elect; Clinton Says U.S. Will Act Fast on Trade Pact If . . .
description: President-elect Bill Clinton tried today to reassure President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that his Administration will move quickly to put the North American Free Trade Agreement into effect, but only after Mexico accepts side arrangements to protect American workers and the environment.

title: National Bancorp of Alaska reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on Sunday, for tonight's highlights, misidentified the actress with John Barrymore in the 1932 movie "Grand Hotel." She is Joan Crawford.

title: Observer; Lean And Mean
description: In the spirit of the times, we are downsizing the staff that writes these columns. Thanks to the downsizing, we are at last free to say "downsizing," having downsized Walter Mulmer, whose task was to keep the column free of what he called "mushmouth" words.

title: Syracuse Indefinitely Suspends Edwards
description: Syracuse senior guard MICHAEL EDWARDS was suspended indefinitely from the team yesterday after being charged with using a hammer to smash out the windows of a bar manager's truck in Syracuse.

title: Review/Music; A Memorial to Dr. King, Repeated 25 Years Later
description: Politics swarm around Oskar Morawetz's "Memorial to Martin Luther King." Its composer fled Czechoslovakia and the Nazis in 1940 and began a long teaching career in Canada. His memorial piece -- revived by the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night -- was intended for Mstislav Rostropovich, who in 1968 ran into trouble with the Soviet authorities and was unable to travel to Edmonton, Alberta, to play the premiere. The central event, the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., had happened earlier that year.

title: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 15,267,000 and a write-down of $ 135,463,000 related to the disposal of a property in the quarter and Carnival Cruise Lines said income from continuing operations in the year-ago fourth quarter was $ 38,700,000, or 28 cents a share.

title: Rutgers Feels Cuts, but President Won't Cry
description: Dr. Francis L. Lawrence's desk in the president's office at Rutgers University is clean and tidy, but his agenda for the state's flagship campus is cluttered with fallout from New Jersey's slumping economy.

title: History or Heresy? Churchill's War Role Attacked
description: With a sudden ferocity, scholars, amateur historians and even politicians here have joined an emotional debate that seems as strange as it is inflammatory. Would Britain be better off today had Churchill been more willing in World War II to negotiate an earlier end to the fighting with Germany?

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Engle Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results are stated pro forma to reflect the Jan. 21 initial public offering. At that time, Engle changed to a C corporation from an S corporation.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Seaway Food Town reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Taking Reins, Zuckerman Faces Union Challenge
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman assumed control of The Daily News yesterday with an olive branch for the news staff he had decimated in an economy measure and a firm pledge to restore his new, $36.3 million property to its glory days as New York's sassy-but-serious hometown tabloid.

title: Today's TV Listings
description: Television and radio listings, normally found at the end of the second section, appear today on pages 18-19.

title: OrNda HealthCorp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The results are after payments of $ 410,000 in preferred dividends in the latest first quarter and $ 195,000 in the year-earlier period.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Brazil Gets Loan
description: The World Bank has issued a $145 million loan to Brazil as financing for a water quality and pollution control project. The $307.6 million project is intended to clean up and prevent pollution of the Arrudas and Onca Rivers, in the state of Minas Gerais.

title: Shock in a Land of Lifetime Jobs: 35 Managers Dismissed in Japan
description: The unthinkable has happened in Japan, and it has touched a nerve in the ranks of the nation's middle managers.

title: ISRAEL WARNS U.N. ON 415 DEPORTEES
description: Israel warned a special United Nations envoy today that the Middle East peace talks could be undermined if the Security Council takes new measures against Israel for having deported 415 Palestinians to southern Lebanon.

title: Park Electrochemical Corp.  reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 29
description: b-Included $ 359,000, or 8 cents a share, derived from currency exchange gains.

title: Q & A
description: Social Security

title: No Headline
description: It was a mistake that I bought it. It was an even bigger mistake that I didn't sell it. -- CARL C. ICAHN, on Trans World Airlines. [ 41:3. ]

title: Composers Orchestra
description: Dennis Russell Davies will conduct the American Composers Orchestra in a program featuring two premieres, tomorrow at 3 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The new works are Chou Wen-Chung's Concerto for Cello and Orchestra, with the soloist Janos Starker, and "Dreaming," by Roger Reynolds. Also on the program are the New York premiere of Cindy McTee's "Circuits" and Chinary Ung's "Inner Voices." Tickets are $9 to $40. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Brajdas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Included a writeoff of $ 746,000 in previously deferred merger expenses.

title: Pausing to See Poverty, and to Remember Neediest
description: Sure, they're New Yorkers -- pushing and shoving and scrapping their way through the day. But these people belie the popular image of the jaded and grumbling Gothamite. They do not scorn the homeless men who wander past them on the subway. They are moved by stories of middle-aged women thrown out of work for the first time in their lives by the recession.

title: Pioneeer Hi-Bred International reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Flowers Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 12
Parade Permit Will Benefit Gay Marchers
description: The Dinkins administration yesterday awarded the permit for the St. Patrick's Day parade to a group that has pledged to allow lesbians and gay men to march under their their own banner for the first time.

title: Region Adds Jobs but Data Remain Mixed
description: The unemployment rate in December rose a bit in New York State and dropped in New Jersey, but employment among residents of both states increased, offering further evidence that their recession-ravaged economies are bottoming out.

title: Cuomo Won't Appoint Crown Heights Prosecutor
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday rejected a request for a special prosecutor in the case of a black man beaten by a group of Hasidic Jews in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: U S WEST TO TAKE $1.8 BILLION ACCOUNTING CHARGE
description: U S West Inc., the regional telephone company serving Midwestern and Western states, said yesterday that it would adopt new accounting rules for retirees' medical benefits in its 1992 financial results. The company said the rules would result in a $1.8 billion charge against earnings and a loss for the year.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's best-known bridge personalities changed her name yesterday, and thousands of her friends will have to get used to it. Kathie Wei was married in Seattle to Henry Sender, and will live in Nashville. In preparation for this step, she became a convert to Judaism a month ago. Marriage will not, however, slow down her bridge activity: later this month she will be in China, competing in several tournaments.

title: Shetland Oil Tanker Nears Breakup
description: The tanker lodged against the cliffs of southern Shetland has started to break apart after more than three days of pounding from towering waves, threatening to release the remainder of its 26-million-gallon cargo of oil into the sea.

title: Hook-SupeRx Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shares outstanding reflected a 1-for-3 reverse stock split which was effective May 19, 1992. Accordingly, the average number of shares and share earnings for the three months ended Nov. 30, 1991 have been restated.Sales represented net sales.

title: Visiting U.S. General Warns Haiti's Military Chiefs
description: As part of intensive joint efforts by the Bush Administration and aides of President-elect Bill Clinton to settle Haiti's political crisis and avert a renewed flood of refugees, a United States Marine Corps general, in a visit here, has warned Haitian military leaders that they must quickly recognize the country's exiled President.

title: TOP BOSNIAN AIDE IS SLAIN BY SERB
description: Serbian nationalist troops besieging Sarajevo shot and killed a top official of the Bosnian Government today after halting a United Nations armored vehicle that was carrying him from Sarajevo airport into the city.

title: U.S. Tries to Verify Compliance As Iraqi Missile Deadline Passes
description: The deadline for Iraq to remove newly deployed missiles from southern Iraq passed without American action tonight after a last-minute flurry of missile movements by Baghdad.

title: German Law Won't End Immigration Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: When Money Is Time
description: There is a kind of money that is immune to inflation, recession, taxation and government budget cuts. It is called a Time Dollar, and like currency it puts supply and demand together. But Time Dollars are service credits that reward people -- with purchasing power as well as an affirmation of self-worth -- for helping others. Here's how they work.

title: Charter FSB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings are adjusted to reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1992.

title: Review/Film; Pogo Stick, Murders And Gold
description: The title character in the new horror film titled "Leprechaun" is supposed to be fiendish but, though the movie's body count is respectable, he seems to be no more than dangerously cranky. That may be because the setting is rural North Dakota, which doesn't suit leprechauns, or because the screenplay and direction are amateurish, which doesn't suit films of any kind.

title: Hi-Shear Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 241,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 360,000, or 6 cents a share, in the 6 months.

title: Rowe Furniture Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net lossRowe Furniture said that the shares outstanding and share earnings do not reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable Jan. 15.

title: Restaurant Patron Is Slain by Gunmen In Williamsburg
description: Two gunmen opened fire on employees and patrons at a popular Spanish restaurant in Brooklyn early yesterday, killing one person and sending three others to the hospital, a police official said.

title: Allwaste Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Nitroglycerin Pill Shortage Expected to End Next Week
description: A nationwide shortage of nitroglycerin, a heart drug dissolved under the tongue to relieve pains of angina, is expected to end early next week with the shipment of 300,000 bottles from the drug's only manufacturer, officials of the drug company and the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday.

title: Boston Bank To Double Loan Funds
description: Officials of the Bank of Boston said today that they would double, to $6 billion, the amount of new loans they had pledged to make in New England by the end of next year.

title: What's Good for Homeowners . . .
description: The projection of increased deficits this week renewed concern about inflation, prompting a quick rise in long-term interest rates. Bill Clinton can cut the Federal deficit and reassure the financial community by encouraging a significant shift toward short-term financing of the national debt.

title: Elvis Comes Alive at the Post Office
description: Slicked-back hair was the style of the day. Long lines were the order of the day. And the catch of the day? Elvis.

title: Senators' Hopes Dashed
description: Having earned 3 points already against the Devils, which was a third of their season total, the Ottawa Senators came into New Jersey with high aspirations tonight. Could this finally be the first victory on the road for the new franchise after 20 games of defeat? How about the first tie?

title: A Year of Lean Living Puts a Couple's 'Dream House' Within Reach
description: Dana Keeler and Daniel Irons, both 27, plan to be married in October. When they got engaged last July, they began looking for a house and found a $210,000, three-bedroom colonial under construction in Independence Township, N.J.

title: VISA TO BECOME ATLANTA'S OFFICIAL CREDIT CARD
description: Atlanta, which is host to the 1996 Summer Olympic Games, will make Visa its official credit card for the next five years under an unusual sponsorship program announced yesterday by Visa U.S.A., the City of Atlanta and the Atlanta Convention and Visitors Bureau. Joel Babbit, chief of marketing and communications for the city, called the marketing program a first by a city. The multimillion-dollar agreement is subject to approval by the Atlanta City Council and the boards of the convention bureau and Visa U.S.A., a major Olympics sponsor.

title: Sports of The Times; Planting The Seeds Of Protest
description: INSIDE a conference room yesterday at the Essex House in Manhattan, in the midst of a conference on racism in sports, the voice of someone not in the room was suddenly heard, causing one man, a minister, to cast his eyes toward the ceiling.

title: MARRIOTT AND BONDHOLDERS DELAY COURT HEARING
description: The Marriott Corporation and bondholders suing to block its reorganization have agreed to postpone their next court hearing until Jan. 28. The hearing had been set for Monday. Marriott, a hotel and food services company based in Bethesda, Md., was expected to file a motion at the hearing to dismiss the bondholders' suit.

title: Chargers Strategist Has a Familiar Look To Shula and Dolphins
description: Miami Dolphins Coach Don Shula built much of his reputation as one of the National Football League's best coaches with Bill Arnsparger as his defensive coordinator.

title: Acclaim Entertainment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Immigration Official Is Accused of Bribery
description: An examiner for the Immigration and Naturalization Service was charged yesterday with soliciting cash bribes and sexual favors from women who were seeking Employment Authorization Cards.

title: Word of Bosnian's Killing Cuts Clinton Briefing Short
description: The President of Bosnia, Alija Izetbegovic, was briefing Clinton aides on the negotiations in Geneva to end the killing in his country when the news arrived of his Deputy Prime Minister's assassination by Serbian gunmen.

title: Gen. Asif Nawaz of Pakistan, 56, A Champion of Democracy, Dies
description: Gen. Asif Nawaz, the Pakistan Army's Chief of Staff who pledged to foster democracy in a country long dominated by martial law, died today. He was 56.

title: Opening Up Japanese Politics
description: After 36 years of one-party dominance, Japan appears headed toward competitive politics. The leading faction of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party has shattered, pointing the way to a realignment that could eventually bring an American-style two-party system. For a time, political infighting could make it harder for Tokyo to deliver on diplomatic deals. In the longer run, democratic competition would be good for Japan, and the U.S.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AKZO N.V., Arnhem, the Netherlands, a chemicals company, and Allied-Signal Inc., have signed a letter of intent to create a joint venture in Europe for manufacturing and marketing carpet fiber. ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO., Decatur, Ill., an agricultural products company, agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it failed to substantiate claims in television commercials and promotional materials about the biodegradability of plastic products containing its corn starch additive, the F.T.C. said.

title: John P.W. Vest, 91, An Aviation Leader In Navy and Industry
description: John P. W. Vest, who was a leader in Navy aviation, an executive in the helicopter industry and Governor of the Marshall Islands Trust Territory, died on Sunday at his home in Centreville, Md. He was 91.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6 20,000 BOSNIANS REPORTED RAPED

title: Edwin Margolis, 63; Was a Sitting Judge For Court of Claims
description: Edwin Margolis, a New York State judge and former legislative counsel to three Democratic Speakers of the State Assembly, died on Wednesday at his home in North Chatham, N.Y. He was 63.

title: Review/Dance; Exploring Uneasiness and Perplexity
description: No one knew what to expect of Onafhankelijk Toneel, a group from Rotterdam that was virtually unknown in America before it appeared on Thursday night at the Theater for the New City. But before the second of its two offerings was over, it was clear that the Dutch group's New York debut was a success.

title: BanPonce Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: INSIDE
description: Heart Pills Being Shipped

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is no doubt that the crowd of 600 -- including the New York City School Chancellor, JOSEPH A. FERNANDEZ, H. CARL McCALL, president of the Board of Education, TOM BROKAW and BROOKE ASTOR -- who will assemble for a dinner on Monday given by the Bank Street College of Education, will be a mix of sophisticated New Yorkers. So they may be a bit surprised when they find crayons and paper at their tables at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Policeman in King Case Recants Accusation Against Other Officers
description: A Los Angeles policeman who broke ranks and accused his fellow defendants of being "out of control" in the beating of Rodney G. King, now says they used reasonable force in subduing Mr. King, his lawyer said today.

title: Economists Meet, and Puzzle Over a Slump
description: The recession has been pronounced over, but a panel of economists at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association this week said traditional economic theory failed to explain why it ever happened.

title: Taking the Big Plunge Into the Sea of Mutual Funds
description: Call them the investments of the 90's.

title: Light-Rail Link Between Manhattan and Airports Makes Sense; Extend the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Crips, Bloods and Clintons; A Veteran of Gang Wars Tastes Inaugural Glory
description: Charles Rachal, convicted killer and former crack user and gang member, stood on the street where he grew up and triumphantly waved his formal invitation to the Clinton inauguration.

title: Cloning a Firm for a Clean Record
description: GENETIC engineering is bigger than you think on Wall Street, where the cloning process works like this: A brokerage firm with a bad regulatory history spins off key executives to start a new firm. Voila! A clean rap sheet for the new operation, and no investor memories of damaging news reports.

title: Autoclave Engineers reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Review/Dance; Telling a Story About Losing a Job
description: Remember when people were dismissed instead of dislocated, as the current buzzword goes? "Dislocations," a new dance work by Phyllis Lamhut, has a theme close to many a current heart.

title: Light-Rail Link Between Manhattan and Airports Makes Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: What Daily News Might Become
description: When Mort Zuckerman was asked today if he had a model for The Daily News, he gave his clearest vision yet: a sassier version of The Daily Mail of London.

title: Japan Takes a Pre-emptive Step on Auto Exports
description: Japanese auto executives said the Government's decision today that it would extend for another year its current ceiling on automobile exports to the United States was an effort to head off expected demands from the new Administration in Washington for more trade concessions.

title: Oklahoman Who Opposed Foley To Lose House Intelligence Post
description: Speaker Thomas S. Foley will remove Representative Dave McCurdy as chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, a move that senior Democrats said today was made because Mr. McCurdy had tried to undercut other Democratic lawmakers in an unsuccessful bid to become Defense Secretary.

title: EXXON VICTORY IN PATENT CASE AFFIRMED BY JUDGE
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that a Federal judge had issued a permanent injunction barring the Lubrizol Corporation from using an oil additive that a jury said belonged to Exxon. Lubrizol, a specialty chemical company in Wickliffe, Ohio, was found guilty Dec. 23 of infringing Exxon's patent for an oil additive used to prevent corrosion in engines. A second trial will be held to determine damages. Lubrizol officials have said that the additive can be replaced and that the injunction poses no serious threat to business.

title: Harleysville Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Good Day For Ducks, Azinger And Love
description: In chilly weather and on a drenched course, Davis Love 3d and Paul Azinger led an onslaught on par today in the first two rounds of the Infiniti Tournament of Champions, the official start of the 1993 PGA and Senior Tours.

title: New York City Is Star Of Showbiz Expo East
description: Despite its brassy name and exuberant commercialism, the Showbiz Expo East, which ends tonight, is more than just a trade show. The high-decibel, high-tech convention that has commandeered the New York Hilton for the last two days has become a continuing referendum on the viability of New York's film-, theater- and television-production industries.

title: Couples Chosen as PGA Player of Year
description: FRED COUPLES, 33, was selected by his peers for a second consecutive award as the PGA Tour Player of the Year for 1992. The result of the voting by players was announced Thursday night at the PGA Tour's annual awards dinner. Also selected as player of the year were LEE TREVINO on the Senior PGA Tour, and JOHN FLANNERY on the Ben Hogan Tour. (AP)

title: New Temple Planned to Serve Mormons in the Northeast
description: The Mormon Church plans to build a multimillion-dollar temple in this area to serve more than 30,000 Mormons throughout the Northeast.

title: Educator Filled Notebook With Complaints
description: In the month before his body was found in an Albany motel room, a beleaguered Bronx school district superintendent filled a notebook with complaints about educational policies in the city and with concerns about being stricken by Lyme disease, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Emil Mogul Dies at 92; Founder of Ad Agency
description: Emil Mogul, a philanthropist and a former advertising and radio executive, died on Jan. 1 at Scripps Memorial Hospital in San Diego. He was 92.

title: Turkish Envoy Assails U.N. For Not Protecting Bosnian
description: The Turkish representative to the United Nations, Mustafa Aksin, criticized United Nations observers tonight for failing to protect a Bosnian Deputy Prime Minister who was shot to death in a United Nations armored car in Sarajevo earlier today.

title: ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATIONS SETS VENTURE WITH MCCAW
description: The Associated Communications Corporation completed its previously announced joint-venture agreement with McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. The venture, 50 percent owned by each company, combines Associated's 6 percent interest in the San Francisco and San Jose cellular telephone systems with McCaw's 50 percent interest in the Buffalo system.

title: EUROPEAN INQUIRY SAYS SERBS' FORCES HAVE RAPED 20,000
description: A team of European Community investigators has estimated that 20,000 Muslim women have been raped by Bosnian Serb soldiers in recent months as part of a deliberate pattern of abuse aimed at driving them from their homes in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Cambex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
A "Dream House" Savings Plan
description: Dana Keeler and Daniel Irons, engaged since last July, need $42,000 by next July to put 20 percent down on the house they want to buy. They are doing it in a year of lean living on a scrupulous savings plan. Page 36. [ Photo ]

title: Advanced Micro Devices Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Included a gain of 52 cents a share from sales of assets, primarily the sale of 3.5 million shares of Xilinx Inc.Advanced Micro Devices said that during the fourth quarter of 1992, it paid off maturing senior notes totaling $ 106 million and retired $ 10.6 million in long-term senior debt. The company also said it has entered into a two-year agreement for a $ 105 million committed line of credit with a consortium of domestic and international banks led by Bank of America as agent and First National Bank of Boston as co-agent.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Round 2 of the Playoffs -- Montana and Kelly Get to Cheer; Redskins Hope to Stifle Young
description: The Washington Redskins might have rattled Minnesota's Sean Salisbury last weekend, but Saturday they'll see a quarterback scads better.

title: Streetscapes: The Barthman Clock; Fixed in Cement, Not in Time
description: THE brass-framed clock set into the sidewalk at the northeast corner of Broadway and Maiden Lane has long been a reference point for hurried pedestrians. But for exactly how long?

title: Burning of Black Reinforces Troubling Image of Tampa
description: The New Year's Day attack on a black tourist has come as a jolting reminder, black residents here say, that this fast-growing metropolis has a long history of racial problems, many of which remain unresolved.

title: Sound Bytes; A Manager of Creativity Reigns at Frogdesign
description: The first personal computers were hardly works of art. To paraphrase Henry Ford, you could get any style at all, as long as it was a beige box. Newer designs are much more attractive and functional, in large part because of the influence of Hartmut H. Esslinger and his industrial designers at Frogdesign Inc. in Menlo Park, Calif. Frogdesign's style-and-function blend show up in Next's distinctive black workstations, Zenith Data's sleek new product line and the futuristic A.T.&T.-Eo communicator, among others. Mr. Esslinger divides his time between California and Germany, where he teaches at the College of Design in Karlsruhe.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LADY WITH THE ALLIGATOR PURSEBy Ernest Finney.Clark City Press, $19.

title: U.S. Helped Defeat Serbian Challenger; Croatian Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Lobsters in Baja
description: To the Editor: The article by Martha Stevenson Olson on Baja California ("In Baja's Lobster Village, 30 Menus in Three Blocks," Dec. 13) brought back some pleasant memories. We happened to be spending a few weeks back in the 1950's at the adobe house of some relatives on the beachfront in the settlement of La Mision.

title: Earlham: Epitomer Of Reform
description: WHEN EARLHAM College gingerly began offering a two-semester sequence in the humanities that centered on short takes of literature, its creators feared it would overwhelm the average student.

title: Virginia to Execute Man Who Uses Wheelchair
description: The Governor of Virginia today ordered the execution of a disabled prisoner who has said he will need to use a wheelchair to get to the electric chair.

title:
MUSIC;
2 Choral Groups Offer Rarely Heard Works
description: DAME ETHEL SMYTH, an English composer who lived from 1858 to 1944, wrote in her memoirs, "It amuses me to think that someday after my death, when all traces of sex have been reduced to ashes . . . someone will very likely take me up as a stunt."

title: Susan Miller, Steven Lloyd
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. Miller of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan McGaw Miller to Steven Wellington Lloyd, a son of Jack W. Lloyd of Lakeville, Conn., and the late Ann K. Lloyd. A June wedding is planned.

title: Topics of The Times; Road Coffee
description: Trying to drive a car while balancing a cup of hot coffee courts at least the minor disaster of an uncomfortable spill -- and possibly much worse. But more and more Americans indulge, especially on cold winter mornings, as gas stations and convenience stores invite customers to serve themselves from fresh-brewed pots. How to make the habit safer? The market has begun to respond.

title: Rape Becomes 'a Weapon of War'
description: Among all the stories of atrocity and violence in Bosnia and Herzogovina are many that tell of an old crime of war: rape. The practice, investigators from the European Community have concluded, is chillingly systematic. Last week, they estimated that 20,000 women had been raped as Bosnian Serb soldiers terrorized Muslim towns and villages. Excerpts from the delegation's preliminary report follow. RAPE and sexual abuse are neither nationality- nor gender-restricted issues. Muslim women undoubtedly form the vast majority of rape victims. However, there are also disturbing reports of rape of Croat and Serbian women as well as sexual abuse of men in detention camps.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE FIRST ENGLISH ACTRESSES Women and Drama 1660-1700. By Elizabeth Howe. Cambridge University, $59.95.

title: A Tiny Chinese Place for New Canaan
description: NEW CANAAN, which for decades had not a single Chinese restaurant, now has three. The newest is Hunan Taste, which is in a sliver of storefront space that once was part of the Deli-Bake delicatessen next door. The seating in Hunan Taste's narrow space is for 20 at most, with three tables for 4 and four tables for 2. Despite the close quarters, the tiny dining area is neat and cheerful, with good lighting and walls lined with Chinese art works. A waiter dances attendance every time your tea cup is empty.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: STEPHEN J. BOCIAN;
On Homeless Beat At the Bus Terminal
description: ON a wet, cold December morning, Officer Stephen J. Bocian, the most-decorated member of the Port Authority Bus Terminal's police force, was making his rounds through the huge midtown Manhattan complex. Within less than an hour, he talked with more than a dozen homeless people.

title: Where Mayas Ruled
description: AFTER a traveler has spent about two days in the tropical forests of northern Guatemala, the ubiquitous insects cease to be a menace and instead become mild annoyances or objects of curiosity. Wasplike bugs sipping honey off breakfast pancakes are plucked from the goo and flung aside. Tarantulas scouting around outside the tents are shooed away with a mild expletive, and scorpions, a rarer sight, draw crowds instead of dispersing them. Mosquitoes and biting flies have been conquered with jungle-formula repellent, and one learns to live with the rest and get on with enjoying the sights and sounds of their domain.

title: In Bosnia, Peace at Any Price Is Getting More Expensive
description: IN 36 hours in Sarajevo last week, 10 people in one unheated home for the elderly died from the bitter cold. European Community investigators also reported that an estimated 20,000 Muslim women were raped by Bosnian Serb soldiers in recent months as part of a terror campaign to drive them from their homes. And on Friday, Serb gunmen stopped a United Nations armored vehicle carrying a Bosnian Deputy Prime Minister, Hakija Turajlic, and shot him dead in front of his French military escorts.

title: A School That Does Without
description: FOR ALL the arguments that a core curriculum is vital to the creation of the fully burnished student, a large number of the nation's finest colleges and universities get along without one. Typifying them is the bellwether University of Wisconsin, which, officials say, has not had such a curriculum in this century and only a couple of years ago agreed on its first university-wide requirement since the 1800's.

title: College Curriculums Shaken to the Core
description: EVER SINCE Stanford University overhauled its curriculum in 1988 from a rigid core of courses dealing with Western civilization to one that includes few required courses and a larger, more varied menu of subjects on women and minorities from which students can choose, life hasn't been the same at the nation's colleges and universities.

title: Travel Agencies See Smoother Sailing
description: RECESSION has taken a high toll among travel agencies. Many have merged or closed their doors. Yet the worst may be over, according to an assessment of current activities in the industry.

title: Hispanic Journalists to Move Convention, Citing Colorado Boycott
description: Defusing a dispute between gay and Hispanic journalists, the National Association of Hispanic Journalists voted yesterday not to hold its annual convention in Denver.

title: FINANCIAL SCANDAL IS SHAKING KUWAIT
description: A wave of financial scandals has angered Kuwaitis and brought legislative attempts to take control of public money from the ruling Sabah family.

title: This Photographer's No Flop
description: Steven Klein, one of today's most sought-after fashion photographers, doesn't take a lofty view of his profession.

title: The Silent Treatment
description: MOST floor squeaks are caused by loose floorboards, subflooring or the joists underneath. Shrinkage, a natural occurrence, is usually at fault, but sometimes poor materials or insufficient fastening is the cause. Most squeaks are fairly easy to fix, once their precise location is found.

title: In the Ozone, A Child Shall Lead Them
description: THANKS to American children the environment may still have a fighting chance, according to an environmental research group.

title: All Rules Aren't Created Equal
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Computer Imprint On Yearbooks
description: JUST AS desktop publishing has become a standard technology in businesses, computers are playing an increasing role in the annual process of capturing school memories for publication in school and college yearbooks.

title: Economic Pulse/New York, New Jersey, Connecticut; Though End of Recession Is Here, Prosperity Isn't Even Near Corner
description: Amid strong signs that the recession was lifting its grip elsewhere in the nation, Martin A. Gardner braced against a cold wind here the other day, waited for his train to Manhattan and described the ordeal of being out of work for 20 months.

title:
UP AND COMING: Christian Tetzlaff;
A Career, Rooted in Schoenberg, Blossoms
description: Christian Tetzlaff has only disdain for violinists who treat image on a par with music. Serious, articulate and well informed, Mr. Tetzlaff, a 26-year-old German violinist with a growing international reputation, seems determined to shun public-relations gimmickry and focus on the fiddle.

title: Quick and Deadly
description: To the Editor:

title: At Work; Pushing Nurses to a Breaking Point
description: Labor market shortages are supposed to be the drive trains of improvements in employment conditions, so by the laws of supply and demand right about now should be a very good time to be a registered nurse.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MARIE TRAFICANTE;
Bringing Out the Nightingale in All of Us
description: IF you are someone who sings only in the shower -- because you have heard too many groans when singing aloud -- Marie Traficante may have words that could be music to your ears. Ms. Traficante, who teaches singing and performing at the State University of New York at Purchase, says anyone can be taught to sing on key.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MARIE tRAFICANTE;
Bringing Out the Nightingale in All of Us
description: IF you are someone who sings only in the shower -- because you have heard too many groans when singing aloud -- Marie Traficante may have words that could be music to your ears. Ms. Traficante, who teaches singing and performing at the State University of New York at Purchase, says anyone can be taught to sing on key.

title: Basic Pointers for Baking Potatoes
description: ONE of the simplest yet most satisfying of all vegetables is a baked potato. Light the oven, put the potato or potatoes in and roast them till tender. It hardly calls for skill.

title: Cracking Up
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art of Angling Celebrated at Yale
description: TO be an angler is to be a part-time stream ecologist, aquatic entomologist, ichthyologist and full-time environmentalist. "Anglers All: Humanity in Midstream," an exhibition at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven, which runs through April, celebrates age-old connections between people with a passion for fly fishing and the shores, lakes and streams where fish congregate and search for food.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: King Crimson: 'The Great Deceiver' Discipline Records Carol 1597-2; CD only.

title: Nile Cruises
description: To The Editor: I recently saw advertisements for Egyptian Nile cruises for January. Since four of us experienced bitter disappointment last January on a six-day Nile cruise sponsored by the Tourlite International agency of New York, I am writing to warn unwary travelers. A six-day cruise was reduced to one and a half days. We were told that the water level was too low for navigation and that we would have to use the ship as a floating hotel while visiting the temple sites in an aged bus, without air-conditioning. We discovered that the water level was always low in January; operators misinformed us that this was unexpected. We were awarded an 11 percent refund, but this hardly made up for a spoiled vacation.

title: Putting Her Demons to Rest
description: THE FURIES By Janet Hobhouse. 293 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.50.

title: The New Ethics Of Hunting
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Flights Added For Carnival In Trinidad
description: BWIA International will add extra flights and use wide-body L-1011 planes to cope with demand during Trinidad's Carnival on Feb. 22 and 23. The airline will also fly Trinidadian customs and immigration officers to Kennedy International Airport to clear passengers bound for the island.

title: 7 SHOT TO DEATH IN CHICAGO SUBURB
description: The bodies of seven people who were apparently shot to death were found early today in a fast-food restaurant in this middle-class Chicago suburb.

title: Ms. Lieberman and B. D. Pergament
description: Mary W. Lieberman of Yonkers has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Randi H. Lieberman, to Bruce D. Pergament, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Pergament of Old Westbury, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Tutoring, the New Growth Industry
description: AMBER MURPHY, an excellent student in most courses, was struggling with her ninth-grade algebra last year. "I didn't have a clue," she recalled. Her mother, Valarie, sought extra instruction for her daughter not from her school in Boulder, Colo., or from a conventional tutor, but from the local outlet of Sylvan Learning Systems, America's largest chain of tutoring franchises.

title: F. Clifton White, 74, Long a Republican Strategist
description: F. Clifton White, who conceived and masterminded the conservative dominance of the 1964 Republican National Convention and its nomination of Barry Goldwater for President, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 74.

title: 'Our Children Were Your Poems'
description: THE GONNE-YEATS LETTERS1893-1938

title: Marisa L. Azzariti, Mark E. Bonacci
description: Marisa Lane Azzariti, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George M. Azzariti of Alpine, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Edward Bonacci, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Bonacci of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Louis Padovano performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: HOPE IS EXPRESSED ON SHETLAND SPILL
description: Despite worsening weather and rough seas, salvage officials said today that they were fairly optimistic that the remaining intact oil-storage tanks on board the grounded tanker Braer would not rupture and spill the rest of the cargo into the sea.

title: Jackson Runs Again
description: BO JACKSON has hit the comeback trail again, this time on a running pad in a service tunnel at Comiskey Park. White Sox officials said that Jackson, who had not run since a hip replacement last year, had taken his first running steps on the pad last week. Describing his pace as between a jog and a sprint, trainers said he ran for 20 seconds at a time between 20-second rest periods.

title: London Pleasures, and They're Free
description: WHILE it has become a recurrent lament among travelers that London is just too expensive these days, it is also true that there are still plenty of free things a visitor can do. No one charges tourists, for example, to pose with the horses and mounted soldiers outside the Horse Guards in Whitehall, or to stand at the iron gates to Downing Street and crane for a view of the bobby standing beside the lacquered black door to No. 10, 50 yards away.

title: Talking: Seller's Fees; The Costs Keep Going Up, Up, Up
description: BACK when it was easy to make a profit selling a home nobody cared much about the fees involved. Any cash that was needed could readily be taken out of the abundant proceeds.

title: Family Party
description: When the son of Le Cirque's owner marries, the feast is -- where else? Jan. 2.

title: G.O.P. to Name Its Own to Board
description: DESPITE early suggestions of bipartisan cooperation, leaders of the Republican Party, which controls the Board of Legislators, plan to name two of their own to fill vacant seats on the Board at its meeting tomorrow. The two seats, formerly held by Democrats, are in predominantly Democratic districts.

title: As Crises In Health Grow So Do the H.M.O.'s
description: VIRGINIA CROWLEY, a mother of three, spends a lot of time worrying about her family's health. Recently, her husband was treated for cancer, her 20-year-old daughter had to be fitted for a new back brace to treat a congenital spine deformity, and her 17-year-old son broke his arm playing football. Although her youngest child, a 10-year-old girl, has not had any major illnesses, there have been allergy problems to contend with and recurrent bouts of the flu.

title: In the Beginning Was What?
description: THE CREATIONISTS

title: What Olympus Means In Jobs and Revenues
description: In their letter [ Dec.27 ] , Gerald and Elfriede Craddock express support for "sustainable economic growth" and concern over "wildcat industrial development" in respect to the Olympus Corporation headquarters in Melville. In fact, Olympus Corporation represents Long Island's future. The Olympus facility is essential to "sustainable economic growth" in this region. It will make a major economic contribution to the Town of Huntington and to Long Island as a whole.

title: Police Exam Is Attracting More Blacks
description: Since Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly made minority recruiting a top priority on taking office three months ago, the percentage of blacks planning to take the department's test this year has significantly increased, according to city figures.

title: Benefits
description: Education Award

title: What's New At the U.N.? Ask Drew U.
description: THE WORTH of the United Nations may be debated at least as long as Saddam Hussein survives, but its popularity could be measured by Drew University's Semester on the United Nations.

title: New Jersey-Bound: The Staten Island Migration
description: SHI FAN TANG may know more about dim sum than demographics, but he knows a trend when he sees one. He and his brother See, owners of three Chinese restaurants on Staten Island named Crown Palace 1, 2 and 3, opened Crown Palace 4 in the western Monmouth County township of Marlboro last year because, Shi Tang said, "so many of our customers were moving here we decided to follow."

title: Bringing Up A TV-Wise Child
description: WITH THE average household taking in a daily 7.5 hours of television, most of it not made-for-children after-school specials, not even the town preacher has what it takes to fight the influence of today's home-screen menu for children. Unless, according to a bevy of experts on children's viewing habits, the preacher makes the effort to supervise TV time, then helps youngsters put TV's information into some sort of context. 'Opens a New World'

title: The Quiz
description: When it comes to getting people and goods from here to there, humans loafed or pushed along at walking speed or slower. A breakthrough came in about 2000 B.C., which increased the speed of transportation to about 10 miles an hour. That became the standard pace until the late 19th century, which heralded a period of stunning acceleration. So hop aboard -- and bring your parachute.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Housing for the Needy Is Making Gains
description: SOMETIMES at a pace of only one dwelling a year, but always with the conviction that every home makes a difference, religious and other nonprofit groups are building up a housing stock for the needy on Long Island.

title: Cowboys and Eagles: Rivals to the End
description: The rubber match between the Philadelphia Eagles (12-5) and the Dallas Cowboys (13-3) today in Texas Stadium offers much more than bragging rights: The winner advances to the N.F.C. championship game and the loser goes home and will no doubt hang his head in dread.

title: A Son's Drug Slaying And a Father's Crusade
description: ON a hot night in July 1990, Dr. Gary S. Cuozzo, an orthodontist who lives in Middletown, lay in stunned silence on his bed, praying for some way of coping with the slaying of his 22-year-old son, Gary Jr., hours earlier in Miami.

title: The Defiant Ones
description: ZEALOTS FOR ZION

title: Gayle Abrams, Stephen Nettler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Abrams of Cherry Hill, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Gayle Helene Abrams to Stephen Mark Nettler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Nettler of Greenvale, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Games in Buffalo Head Events List
description: The World University Games scheduled for July 8 to 18 in Buffalo have been designated the overall best event of the year in the American Bus Association's Top 100 Events of 1993. The trade group's annual roster of leading events in the United States and Canada is based on their popularity and accessibility to bus travel. The university games are being held in the United States for the first time in 80 years of biannual competition.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Sports of the Times; Is Hockey Entering A Sensitive New Age?
description: THE first sign Roger Neilson was in big trouble was when they traded his goon. It was like the canary dying in the coal mine, a sure sign of deadly methane gas. If Tie Domi could be offed, Neilson was vulnerable.

title: Kristine Simpson, Brian J. Kopan
description: Kristine Marie Simpson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Simpson of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to Brian Joseph Kopan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Kopan of Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. Paul Bryan officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Banking on Clinton Mania
description: The future First Daughter now has a restaurant named after her.

title: On Sunday; Town Guardian Is Appreciated, Not Supported
description: THIS summer community for the wealthy is famous for strict zoning. There are many rules and they are constantly violated, resulting in illegal store signs, illegal apartments and illegal decks. Almost anything built will upset someone, whether it's a second-story addition to the summer home of Alec Baldwin, the actor (a dispute that's only in its second year), or a new caretaker's cottage for Jann Wenner of Rolling Stone magazine. (The town planner felt he should convert his poolhouse instead.)

title: Tracy Pogue and Michael Hausman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Pogue of Shaker Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracy Ellen Pogue, to Dr. Michael Robert Hausman, the son of Esther K. Hausman of Milford, Conn., and the late Sidney Hausman. A May wedding is planned.

title: 'Just One Crazy Female Patient'
description: YOU MUST BE DREAMING

title: In Translation, Too, the Thought Is Mighty
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Van Dyck, Barnaby Noble
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas B. Van Dyck of Princeton, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Paxson Van Dyck and Barnaby Lloyd Noble, a son of John J. and Madeleine G. Noble of Geneva.

title: Business Diary/January 3-8
description: THE ECONOMY A Little Leftover Untidiness From President Bush

title: When a Casual Collector Turns Serious
description: Great collections are often shaped by acquisitive people who happen to be in the right place at the right time. Take Gregory Henderson. When he was posted by the State Department to Seoul for two years in 1948, he bought a few gloriously glazed celadons, jade-green vessels with the shimmer of silk. When he returned in 1958 as the political officer of the United States Embassy, he became a confirmed Korean ceramics collector.

title: Mutual Funds; Stock Twists and Turns of '92
description: Playing the stock market so far in the 90's has been like taking a ride on Coney Island's famous Cyclone roller-coaster. Stock funds in 1990 suffered a 7.3 percent loss on average, only to attain a return of 30.7 percent in '91 and then skid last year to a gain of just 6 percent.

title:
ART;
Yesterday's Pastimes Turning Into Icons
description: LONG after other holiday amusements have been broken or consigned to the closet, board games survive. They may turn up a little the worse for wear in a camping tent in the summertime. Aware of their likelihood for durability, the Milton Bradley Company got its start providing board games for Civil War soldiers. But now these games appear to be entering the pantheon of popular American icons.

title: The Word From China's Kerouac: The Communists Are Uncool
description: THE puzzle is why the Chinese Government has not banned Wang Shuo.

title: Foreign Affairs; Vance And Powell
description: Two men whose views must be respected stand in the way of lessening the bloodshed in Bosnia: Cyrus Vance, the heroic U.N. diplomat, who negotiates tirelessly for a peace settlement; and Gen. Colin Powell, the brilliant warrior, who argues relentlessly against U.S. and allied military intervention.

title: THE WEDDING GIFT
description: When I saw the title of Carolyn Marks Blackwood's Hers column "The Wedding Gift" (Dec. 13), I thought it would be about "things." And, in a way, it was; but this time it was about things that matter. I read on with tears streaming down my cheeks.

title: Heckscher Again Looks to Expand
description: A LONGTIME conflict between cultural and recreational priorities will be debated on Wednesday, when the Huntington Town Board holds a hearing on an environmental report for the proposed expansion of the Heckscher Museum.

title:
FOCUS;
Investors' Defaults Threatening Condos
description: When Paul J. Maglio bought his two-bedroom condominium for $120,500 in 1986 there was a waiting list of 200 people eager to buy at the 393-unit Governor's Park in this town on Boston Harbor.

title: Warning: Underneath Lies A Hard-Rap Fan
description: The label that says "Parental advisory: explicit lyrics" on the cover of a CD may make some youngsters want the disk even more. What record companies may not have foreseen is that the words, altered slightly to read "explicit rap," would one day be used as a fashion statement. A hooded nylon jacket by Rock Embassy bears the message on two embroidered patches -- one on the chest, one on the back. The jacket, black with blue sleeves, costs $90 at Rock Embassy shops in Sam Goody and Musicland stores.

title: Redmen Are Beginning to Be Believers
description: After their most impressive victory this season, the St. John's Redmen look at where they've been, and they look at where they have to go, and the view is suddenly not so bad.

title: Accord With Cree Will Allow Quebec Utility to Finish Dams
description: Hydro-Quebec, the provincial utility that is a major supplier of electricity to New York State, has signed an agreement with the Grand Council of the Cree and two Cree Indian communities on compensation payments for environmental damage, allowing the electric company to finish a giant hydroelectric project in the remote James Bay region.

title: A Wrinkle in Time: Bill Clinton's Wonder Years
description: As the first baby-boom President, the 46-year-old Bill Clinton is the product of many influences -- Chuck Berry, whose "Roll Over Beethoven" came out when Mr. Clinton was 10, "Ben Hur," released when he was in eighth grade, and "The Donna Reed Show," reported to be his favorite television show. (The Bush generation remembers Donna Reed as the prostitute in the 1953 classic movie "From Here to Eternity"; baby boomers are more likely to think of her as the quintessential mom.) During his time at Hot Springs High School in Arkansas, from 1960 to 1964, the young Mr. Clinton was no doubt affected by popular culture. Here are some of the movies, songs and television programs that may have shaped Mr. Clinton's outlook. 1960 Movies "The Alamo" (starring John Wayne) "The Apartment" (Jack Lemmon)

title: State and Lilco Courting Industries
description: WITH a global market breathing down their necks, Long Island manufacturers are finding that doing business as usual does not always work. A result is that the industrial base is shrinking.

title: POSTINGS: And a Bank in Harlem; Waldorf a Landmark
description: Park Avenue gained two new official landmarks Tuesday. One of them -- the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, between 49th and 50th Streets -- seems so obvious a choice that New Yorkers might be surprised to learn it is only now designated.

title: Council System Vote in New Rochelle
description: VOTERS in this city of 67,000 will have a second chance on March 2 to decide if they want each City Council member to represent a section of the city or to represent the city at large, as members do now.

title:
TELEVISION;
The Short Life and Unhappy Death of 'Laurie Hill'
description: During the third week of the ABC series "Laurie Hill," DeLane Matthews, who played the title role, had a dream. "I was at this five-star restaurant," she says, "and they served me this heaping dish of food. Then I turned away for a moment, and when I looked back, the plate was gone and there was a box of Cracker Jacks."

title:
Viewpoints;
Is America Being Shut Out Again?
description: The world's trade negotiators, having reached a tentative agreement on agriculture, are pushing to conclude an agreement on other sectors by next month, when the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is slated to be completed. For the American financial services sector, however, a quick completion of the Uruguay Round threatens to cast in concrete the current one-way street: American financial markets would remain open to all comers, while Asian markets would continue to restrict access.

title: Amy, Amy Everywhere
description: LAST Sunday night at a walk-up in the East Village, a hefty drag performer whose stage name is Faux Pas was watching the ABC and CBS versions of the Amy Fisher story on two television sets with some friends. He was wearing fish-net stockings and what might have been the largest little black dress in the world.

title: Cowher Still Stands By His Man in Loss
description: The lockers of Steeler quarterbacks Neil O'Donnell and Bubby Brister are side by side in the Pittsburgh locker room. From there, the two can share their thoughts and eavesdrop on each other's interviews.

title: Jennifer Headley, R. K. Herrington
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Headley Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lynn Headley to Richard Kirby Herrington, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Herrington of Pittsburgh. A July wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CROW EATERSBy Bapsi Sidhwa.Milkweed Editions, paper, $13.

title: In Newark, 'Role Models to a Generation'
description: THE lettering on the window reads, "Newark Boys Chorus School," but the storefront tucked into a corner of the stately granite building housing Newark Symphony Hall looks more like makeshift office space than a school. The previous tenant was a car dealership.

title: PROBLEMS WE THOUGHT WE SOLVED
description: The first paragraph of Perri Klass's article "Tackling Problems We Thought We Solved" (Dec. 13), where she describes the unnecessary death of a 9-month-old baby from dehydrating diarrhea for lack of a $6 bottle of rehydrating solution, captures just about everything that ails our health-care system: the lack of basic primary care for mothers and children; the high cost of simple remedies that put them out of reach of poor families; the lack of outreach, education and community support; the underlying poverty. For those of us who work on health issues in the developing world, it is a reminder of how important our work is and how relevant to the needs of American children.

title: Carol Lovell, C. G. Carmody
description: Carol Ann Lovell, a director in corporate banking at the First National Bank of Boston, was married in Boston yesterday to Christopher Guerin Carmody, a financial consultant with Merrill Lynch in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Rachelle E. Birnbaum performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church.

title: Valerie Silverman and Drew Kerr
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rogers Silverman of Jericho, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Valerie Silverman, to Drew Reid Kerr, a son of Herbert Kerr and Alma Kerr, both of Forest Hills, Queens. A May wedding is planned.

title: Dinkins Urging Radio Stations To Curb Talk-Show Bigotry
description: Looking for ways to calm ethnic tensions in New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins says he wants to persuade local radio stations to deter talk-show hosts and callers from making bigoted comments on air.

title: Israelis Let 2 Deported Arabs Return
description: Two of the 415 Palestinians expelled by Israel to southern Lebanon were brought back to Israeli-controlled territory today, the first movement of exiles since a crisis over the expulsions began last month.

title: Two in Larchmont Share in Cancer Discovery
description: TAXOL, a new anti-cancer drug, is derived from the bark of a rare yew tree that grows in the Pacific Northwest but two scientists who live in Larchmont are among those responsible for its recent approval by the Federal Food and Drug Administration for use against ovarian cancer.

title: The Last Days of the Intellocrats
description: PAST IMPERFECT

title: 'Martin Guerre' as Mystery Rather Than History
description: A HUSBAND. A lover. A stranger. Though it reads like the blurb for a steamy novel or an X-rated film, the advertising copy is a come-on for "Martin Guerre," which is being billed as a new musical, in it world premiere engagement at the Hartford Stage.

title: Q and A
description: Primary Residence Question: I have a friend who has a rent-stabilized apartment in the East 60's. He uses it for 20 days a year and spends the rest of the time in Europe. In the interim, the apartment is used by others. He was recently told by the owner that to qualify for the apartment he must be a city resident and file a city tax return. Is this true? . . . Charles Tressan, Manhattan Answer: Most likely. "For the landlord to be obligated to give the tenant a renewal of his lease, the apartment is supposed to be his principal residence," said David Smith, a Manhattan lawyer.

title: The Middle Class Goes Public
description: DURING the last generation, the idea of middle-class people enrolling their children in urban public schools has become something akin to letting the youngsters play in traffic: too dangerous for any sensible parent to even consider.

title: Portraits of Gay Men, With No Apologies
description: Gay-rights demonstrators sometimes brandish placards proclaiming "We are everywhere," as a reminder that homosexuals are in all strata of American society. "Everywhere" certainly includes the stages of New York theaters, for gay male and lesbian characters are part of the casts of an increasing number of plays, dances and mixed-media productions. Several choreographers and performance artists have recently offered especially vivid portraits of gay men.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
Building Anew At Foxhall Site
description: WORK has resumed on the fourth and final section of luxury homes carved out of the 25-acre estate of Nelson A. Rockefeller, the late New York Governor, in the Foxhall Road neighborhood of northwest Washington

title: After Bond Defeat, Suffolk Seeks New Financing
description: VOTER rejection of the Jobs Bond Act in November has derailed many Suffolk County projects that had hoped to benefit from it. But the county considers two plans so important it is pursuing a new avenue of state financing.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'CHILDREN OF PARADISE'

title: Wachtler Defense Focuses On Temporary Insanity
description: Two months after he was arrested on charges of extortion and threatening to kidnap the daughter of a woman who jilted him, New York State's former Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, and his lawyer are apparently building a defense based on a claim of temporary insanity caused by depression and the abuse of prescription drugs.

title: In Europe, Unity Begins With Freedom to Shop
description: THE Promised Land of 1993 has arrived in Europe, and to a horde of British shoppers in this French port town it resembles nothing so much as the "section liquide" at the Continent supermarket.

title: Alaska Lodges
description: To the Editor: The article "Two Not-Too-Remote Lodges" (Sept. 6) describes the North Face Lodge in Denali National Park, Alaska. This summer two friends and I, caught in a thunderstorm, sought help at this lodge, believing in a wilderness area help can be found at any port in a storm. Wrong. The lodge refused to call our lodge, offer us a ride, or even a cup of hot tea. I would like to suggest to your readers a far superior and friendlier lodge close by: Kantishna Roadhouse, Box 130, Denali National Park, Alaska 99755; (907) 733-2535. LUCY FREEMAN Chevy Chase, Md. Wallace and Jerryne Cole, owners of the Denali National Park Wilderness Centers, respond: We're sorry for the reception Ms. Freeman described. Although the lodge is a private facility, her experience is neither our way of showing hospitality nor of providing safe haven. We cannot believe that if she and her friends were in serious trouble we would not have helped them. We apologize for what she saw as a lack of intervention in their plight.

title: The Queen Of the Night: A Double Life
description: Two weeks ago, I wrote about a fragrant night-blooming cereus that blossoms its head off for Dr. Kate Bernstein, a molecular biologist and urban gardener who has propagated countless plants from a cutting that she got from the Caribbean 35 years ago.

title: The Prince and the Superwoman (A Very Modern Tale)
description: AH, for the easier days of imperial romance. The last time the chamberlains who run the lives of Japan's royal family went searching for a future empress, they quietly arranged for a "chance" meeting on the tennis courts between Akihito, then the Crown Prince, and an elegant, demure commoner of impeccable social credentials, Michiko Shoda.

title: Cocktail-Party Conversation -- With a Computer
description: The topic: men and women. The conversationalists: one reasonably intelligent and inquisitive reporter, and one very clever and mischievous computer program. Could they have an intelligent keyboard conversation? And would it seem to the reporter that he was talking to a person and not a PC-compatible idiot savant?

title: The Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: JAN. 3-9: Iraqi Missiles; After Deadline Passes Hussein Heeds Ultimatum
description: In a speech at West Point last week, President Bush gave a valedictory on his Presidency by offering guidelines for the use of American force abroad. A few days later, Mr. Bush probably wished Saddam Hussein wasn't still around to help him punctuate his remarks.

title: U.S. Helped Defeat Serbian Challenger
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hartford Symphony Returns to the Bushnell
description: THE Hartford Symphony gets the 1993 orchestral ball rolling with Tuesday and Wednesday evening concerts at the Bushnell, followed by Friday and Saturday returns as the Hartford Symphony Pops, and even a Saturday morning children's program as part of the musical bargain.

title: Miss Pickholz, Mr. Eickelbeck
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome W. Pickholz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Alyce Pickholz, to Steven Eickelbeck, a son of Ralph Eickelbeck of Freeport, the Bahamas, and Sibille Beimel of Stony Point, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Topics of The Times; P.C., 1841 A.D.
description: William Henry Harrison -- the Tippecanoe of "Tippecanoe and Tyler, Too" -- took his oath as President on March 4, 1841. History buffs know he died of pneumonia a month later. Trivia buffs know that he spoke at his inauguration for an hour and 45 minutes, and no one has yet spoken longer.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: STEPHEN J. BOCIAN;
On Homeless Beat At the Bus Terminal
description: ON a wet, cold December morning, Officer Stephen J. Bocian, the most-decorated member of the Port Authority Bus Terminal's police force, was making his rounds through the huge midtown Manhattan complex. Within less than an hour, he talked with more than a dozen homeless people.

title: Good Buys On Theater Tickets
description: GONE are the days when a West End ticket cost a mere fraction of one on Broadway. But putting on a show in London is still cheaper than it is in New York, and ticket prices reflect that.

title: Report Details Variations in Police Review Boards
description: As New York City prepares to institute an all-civilian review board to monitor complaints against the police, a report released yesterday by the New York Civil Liberties Union found that similar agencies throughout the country operate with significant barriers.

title: JAN. 3-9: Combat in Somalia; As Marines Open Fire, Hopes for Early Return Begin to Fade
description: Mogadishu awoke Thursday to the thud of artillery fire. United States marines, attacking with tanks and Cobra helicopter gunships, swooped down on two compounds in the capital used by the forces of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, a major Somali warlord. One compound was reduced to rubble and the marines captured a large arsenal -- the first time they had gone into direct combat against a warring Somali faction, which could have unpredictable political consequences.

title: Aide Says Weicker's Plan Doesn't Hurt Court Case
description: Connecticut's legal standing in a lawsuit charging that the segregation in Hartford's schools violates the state's constitution was not changed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s call this week for a statewide school integration effort, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said today.

title: Home Awaits
description: To the Editor:

title:
WHAT WORKS;
Creating a Space Called School
description: AFTER 12 years of watching her students perform poorly and express open disdain for the concept of school, Cheryl Deaton, the principal of West Forest Intermediate School in Opelika, Ala., decided to make several radical breaks with tradition. All were designed to remove what she considered to be structural impediments to learning among her students, 57 percent of whom are black and 5 percent Asian, mostly Laotians, and 70 percent of whom come from one-parent, blue-collar families in a town where many adults never graduated from high school and unemployment is high.

title: Kristin Williams, Stephen Mugford
description: Mr. and Mrs. James W. Williams of Radnor, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kristin Kiely Williams to Stephen Andrew Mugford, a son of Robert A. and Phyllis Mugford of Southington, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Conference Car On Amtrak Train
description: Amtrak has introduced a club conference car running twice daily between New York and Washington on the Metroliner express. Facilities include a conference room for up to eight people with a private telephone and a marker board for presentations or notes. The car also has two private booths for four passengers, with a table and sliding glass doors for privacy; two semi-private tables each seating two people, and 18 first-class seats. The service started in the fall.

title: Kitsch, Campiness and the Naked Truth
description: "Nude" is a female word in contemporary English; when the other gender lets its bloomers down, the word is usually modified: male nude. So "The Naughty Nude," a cheerful, unpretentious, low-key show at Gallery 292 in SoHo (through Jan. 16), is a gaggle of coquettes, some in brassieres or petticoats, none in jockey shorts. The operative term for these 19th- and 20th-century come-ons is indeed "naughty." Though there are warrantied works of art among these 60-odd photographs -- a 1950's Bill Brandt, Andre Kertesz's "Satiric Dancer" (who has mysteriously strayed in in a dress) -- the atmosphere tends to the kitsch, the camp and the cozy.

title: 19 Contaminated By Nuclear Leak
description: A leak of radioactive material has contaminated workers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, and officials asked Friday that the families of some of the workers be tested for radiation exposure.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Modern Jewelry, the Venetian Way
description: FOR treasure seekers with a good eye, Venice offers perhaps more fun -- and more of a challenge -- than any other city in Europe. Here, tourist shops and boutiques outnumber even churches. To find the perfect Venetian keepsake requires some serious looking beyond display windows jammed with handcrafted trinkets and baubles, leather and paper goods, antiques and glass objects of every description, jewels and costume jewelry and of course the ubiquitous mask. One marvels at the sheer number of these shops all seemingly selling the same things. But then a closer look reveals that they are not all alike, that here and there are shops selling their own fine stock, where talented Venetian artisans are preserving the jeweled world of Veronese and Titian. The trick is to find them.

title: Judith Seibert, Gary R. Schall
description: February wedding plans have been announced for Judith Anne Seibert, a senior consultant at Price Waterhouse in New York, and Gary Richard Schall, a tax associate at the firm.

title: Bosnian Muslims Criticize U.N. Over Official's Killing
description: As crowds of angry Bosnians demonstrated in the streets, leaders of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government accused United Nations military commanders today of failing to protect them from Serbian attacks, including the killing on Friday of one of Bosnia's deputy prime ministers.

title: Data Update
Caught in a Sweet Trap
description: THE GARDEN NEXT DOOR

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 10, 1993
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 RISING SUN, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $5.99.) The death of a woman leads to an investigation involving the American-Japanese rivalry. 2 50 THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $5.99.) A young lawyer learns that his firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities. 3 5 THE WASTE LANDS, by Stephen King. (Signet, $6.99.) The third volume of "The Dark Tower," a series about time travel and a heroic quest. 4 11 A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT, by Norman Maclean. (Pocket, $4.99.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. LP indicates that a book is available in large print.

title: Cowardice in Congress
description: With their new session only days old, House Democrats have already flunked a crucial test of ethics by re-electing an influential colleague, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Instant Water and Fire

title: Challenger Disaster As Corporate Tool
description: NEARLY seven years after the space shuttle Challenger exploded during its launch, a cross-disciplinary management training project is using the incident as a teaching tool. Its purpose is to address many of the problems plaguing American corporations and other organizations.

title: Who Pays Bill? For Adventure?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Margot Bodine, David Congdon
description: Margot Reed Bodine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Bodine 3d of Sanibel, Fla., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to David John Congdon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Congdon of Keene, N.H. The Rev. Sue Anne Steffey Morrow, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Alfredo J. Balinong, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Optimism Unshared
description: To the Editor:

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Education Life/Section 12 A special report on the reformation of college core curriculums. Also:

title: The Cousins Who Would Be King
description: In recent years Edsel B. Ford 2d has occasionally muttered in the presence of co-workers at the Ford Motor Company that "my family owns the place and I'm not even a vice president."

title: Companies' Offers of Scoreboards Raise Questions for Schools
description: WITH state aid to education declining and costs increasing, Long Island school districts are looking more and more to private enterprise for help.

title: A Close-Up Look At Eight Hotels
description: THE hotels used in package tours are often somewhat mysterious entities. They are seldom five-star landmarks, and sometimes not even mentioned in guidebooks. However, a recent inspection of eight hotels used in packages to London suggests that they are typical of budget and medium-priced establishments in the city. There is usually a trade-off required. If you want style, you probably will have to be flexible about location. If you want to be in the heart of London, you may have to forgo charm.

title: The Heavenly Country
description: THE LAND CALLED HOLY

title: PROBLEMS WE THOUGHT WE SOLVED
description: There was no mention of teen-age fathers in Klass's article.

title: SILENCE OF THE FROGS
description: Regarding your very interesting article "Silence of the Frogs," has anyone investigated to determine if there are an unusual number of heretofore unknown princes abroad in the land? PAT MOFFAT Madison, N.J.

title: American Is Top Junior
description: He was runner-up among the juniors at Wimbledon and the Australian Open last year, but when the International Tennis Federation cranked out its year-end junior rankings, 18-year-old BRIAN DUNN of Brandon, Fla., was right there, becoming the first American male to be the I.T.F. world junior championship. DAVID SKOCH of Czechoslovakia, who beat Dunn at Wimbledon, was 200 points back in second place among the boys' ranking, and GRANT DOYLE, who won the junior Australian Open, was third.

title: Sports of The Times; The Pit Bull Who Catches TD Passes
description: SOME teams do it with talent. Some with power. Some with finesse. Some with mirrors.

title: Paula Weber, Brian E. Ohl
description: Paula Bodi Weber, the daughter of Norma D. Cavanaugh of Westwood, Mass., and the late Harry A. Bodi Jr., was married yesterday to Brian Eric Ohl, a son of Lillian M. Ohl of West Palm Beach, Fla., and John P. Ohl of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, in Palm Beach.

title: Off to U.S., Japanese Pack Words, Like 'Police!'
description: At 7 o'clock on Sunday nights, television viewers across Japan tune in to see the latest disaster to befall Hyota, a hapless Japanese traveler trying to survive in America with the English he learned in Japan's public schools. He was recently wandering the streets of Tombstone, Ariz., in search of a security guard.

title: Special rates, vouchers and other frills at London hotels
description: For travelers who choose not to book their hotels as part of a package or through their airline, a number of London hotels are currently offering special deals, subject to availability. These deals should be purchased before leaving the United States. Here are some examples.

title: New Look for the Stock Tables
description: The New York Times today introduces new stock market listings for the Business section on Sundays, providing more information than before in a format designed to make the tables easier to understand and easier to read.

title:
TENNIS;
Jim Pierce: The Problem Parent in Women's Tennis
description: Jim Pierce reacted with belligerence when three fans rooted against his daughter, Mary, at the French Open last June. He punched two of them and bragged about it later.

title: Nina Troster, Andrew W. Hay
description: Nina Riggio Troster, a daughter of Dr. Judith D. Toland of Avoca, Wis., and Vincent Riggio of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Wellington Hay, the son of Nicholas R. T. Hay of Old Black Point, Conn., and the late Anne P. Hay. The Rev. Dr. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: POSTINGS: Architects Now On Board; Huge L.I. Federal Court Complex
description: With the choice of Richard Meier and Michael Harris Spector as architects of the $195 million Federal Building and United States Courthouse planned in Islip, L.I., the Government has shown that it is not looking for a neo-classical temple with fluted columns and pediments. Mr. Meier, in particular, is widely known for the spare serenity of his designs: crisp, cool, bright and uncluttered.

title: Ah, Yesterday, When Men Had Absolute Power Over Women!
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Rodgers and Hammerstein: 'The King and I' Soloists; Hollywood Bowl Orchestra conducted by John Mauceri. Philips 438 007; CD and cassette.

title: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The Labor Department; Nominee Devoted Years To Rehearsing for Role
