description: b-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $ 1,320,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 2,269,000, or 7 cents a share, in the 6 months, both from tax-loss carryforwards.Per-share amounts reflected a 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 31.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Wabash National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods are pro forma for period from Jan. 1, 1990 until the company's initial public offering in November 1991. The company was treated as an S corporation and was not subject to corporate income taxes in that time. Figures reflected a tax provision as if the company had been subject to corporate income taxes.

title: Energy Nominee Plans Broad Agenda
description: The Clinton Administration plans to make the modernization of the Russian oil industry a priority of the Energy Department under a program to aid American industry, stabilize world oil markets and assist Russian democracy by providing hard currency.

title: Empire Blue Cross Also Gets It Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess
description: Nigel Short, a 28-year-old English grandmaster, holds a 3-2 lead over Jan Timman, a 41-year-old Dutch grandmaster, in the final candidates match for world championship aspirants in San Lorenzo de El Escorial, Spain. The winner of the 14-game series will get $124,000 and a title match in August with the world champion, Gary Kasparov of Russia. The loser will receive $76,000.

title: G.M. OF CANADA TO ELIMINATE ONE SHIFT AT ONTARIO PLANT
description: General Motors of Canada said yesterday that it would cut one of four shifts at an assembly plant in Oshawa, Ontario, in March, eliminating 1,450 jobs. The plant, which produces Chevrolet Luminas, will go to one shift late in the month. The decision reflects continuing weakness in the midsize car market, a spokeswoman said.

title: Beth R. Cosnow, 70, A Community Leader
description: Beth Robertson Cosnow, a longtime community leader on the East Side of Manhattan, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 70.

title: Questions for Ms. Baird
description: Zoe Baird and the Senate Judiciary Committee both get a chance to reclaim their injured reputations this week -- she by giving a candid accounting of why she hired illegal immigrants, the committee by asking the tough questions that will elicit a detailed airing of the episode. Confirmation hearings on Ms. Baird's nomination as Attorney General begin today.

title: Snapple Escapes the Grip of Rumors
description: At first, there were only one or two inquiries, by phone and very specific: Was Snapple, soda maker to the New Age, supporting Operation Rescue, the anti-abortion group that tries to shut down abortion clinics? Odd, thought Arnie Greenberg, a company founder and the chief operating officer, but not especially vexing. "Eh," he said of his first reaction in early August, emphasizing the syllable with a shrug that brings one floral suspender up near his ear.

title: TransAmerican Waste Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Hunt Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Included charge of $ 2.7 million for relocation and consolidation of operations.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF PLANS TO FIGHT FOR JOB
description: William S. Sessions has told associates he will fight for his job as Director of the F.B.I. in the face of a searing internal ethics report that accused him of evading taxes and refusing to cooperate with an investigation of a home mortgage loan.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Clinton and Gore families ringing a bell in an Arlington, Va., park misidentified the park in some copies. It is Lady Bird Johnson Park.

title: Nation Is Optimistic About Clinton Years
description: Americans are waiting for Bill Clinton's Presidency with revived optimism about the nation and the economy, a new New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. Three-fourths of those polled said they thought the President-elect cared "about the needs and problems" of people like them. And the survey suggests much indifference to campaign promises, with the exception of health care.

title: John Stender, 76, Dies; First Director of OSHA
description: John Stender, the first director of the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration, died Saturday at the Hallmark Nursing Home in Federal Way, a suburb of Seattle. He was 76 and lived in Federal Way.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about "Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg" at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night misidentified the singer who performed David. He is Lars Magnusson, not Jan-Hendrik Rootering. Mr. Rootering sang Pogner.

title: A Dream for Dieters: Fish Species Can Alter Its Body Size at Will
description: SCIENTISTS say they have discovered a shape-changing fish that can detect the presence of hungry predators and then turn itself from easy pickings into something much more difficult to swallow.

title: No Headline
description: "Every administration tends to be an overreaction to the last. We went in because of Watergate, and in that environment we wanted to be loose, informal, open, press conference every week, no White House perks, and it didn't work. You have to strike a balance." -- HAMILTON JORDAN, President Carter's chief of staff. [ A15:6. ]

title: Center Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Market Place
description: THE stock market verdict could yet change. But right now it looks as if Buffalo can confound the football forecasters and finally win the Super Bowl on its third try.

title: Roshangarh Journal; As India Seethes, Old Rhythms Soothe a Village
description: Sabir Ali combed his cream-white beard with his gnarled fingers and broke into a toothless grin. "Oh, yes," he said, "I'll plow fields for Hindus this year, just like every year."

title: Senate Republicans Hire Official Cited in Clinton Passport Search
description: A State Department official who was demoted for his role in the search of Bill Clinton's passport files during last year's Presidential campaign has been hired by Senate Republicans to monitor State Department activities under the new President.

title: China Cultivates Its Burmese Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: Maverick Tube reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Clinton Hopes to Curb Tongue in Inaugural Address
description: President-elect Bill Clinton, whose penchant for verbosity has cast a cloud over each of the crucial speeches in his career, is working to craft an Inaugural Address that is trenchant, uplifting and, if he can manage it, succinct.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For some people who went to the party billed as a farewell to Henri Matisse at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday evening, it was like saying goodbye to an old friend. For others, it was like seeing a new one depart. It all depended on how many times they had seen the blockbuster retrospective that ends this evening.

title: Employee Benefit Plans reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on retirement of debt of $ 942,000, or 11 cents a share, in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net incomeLatest losses from continuing operations of $ 3,077,000 and $ 1,452,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, included settlement costs of $ 5.7 million in securities litigation.

title: THE INAUGURATION: A Musical Smorgasbord; 2 Concerts Gel Sounds Of America
description: Three days before the Clinton Administration was to get under way, it employed popular music in potent symbolism. The pre-inauguration festivities presented two distinct musical faces: one down home and diverse, invoking roots and heritage; the other glossy and assimilated, a salute to American mass culture.

title: Johnson Controls Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shedding Light On a Morning And a Name
description: It started with a hotel: the Chelsea Hotel in New York City, where Joni Mitchell was staying and, one bright morning, felt as if "the sun poured in like butterscotch and stuck to all my senses." Those impressions inspired "Chelsea Morning," the song that gave Chelsea Clinton her name.

title: Good Times Restaurants Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company also reported its pro forma results. The latest year included sales of $ 13,747,200, and a net loss of $ 803,400, compared with sales of $ 13,381,700 and a net loss of $ 311,900, in year-ago period.These pro forma consolidated results of operations assuming the July 1992 merger between Round the Corner and Good Times had taken place as of the beginning of the periods presented, including pro-forma adjustments for interest, depreciation and amortization.

title: Clinton Is Right on Iraq
description: Brickbats are showering Bill Clinton because he told The New York Times that if Saddam Hussein "wants a different relationship with the United States and the United Nations, all he has to do is change his behavior." Except for his suggestion that U.S. relations with Iraq could be normalized, he was right.

title: Gundle Environmental Sys.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kohlberg Unit to Buy Alden Press
description: A new company formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company has agreed to buy the Alden Press Company for $150 million in cash and the assumption of debt, Kohlberg, Kravis, a buyout firm, said yesterday.

title: N.A.S.D. Set to Expand Available Data to Public
description: The board of the National Association of Securities Dealers is expected to announce today that it has approved a plan to make more information publicly available about disciplinary action against brokerage firms and their registered representatives.

title: An Invisible Generation Looks in the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Pittsburgh Journal; 'Mouse' That Inherited Pittsburgh
description: Saying they were starved for local news, sports columns, comic strips, job advertisements, movie listings and obituary notices, Pittsburgh residents lined up in the bitter cold outside news vendors this morning to buy the first copies of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette to roll off the presses in eight months.

title: SEARS EXTENDS CHILD APPAREL PROMOTION TO SHOES
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company is extending its Kidvantage program, which gives customers a discount for every $100 of children's clothing they purchase plus a warranty if the child wears out a garment before outgrowing it, to include shoes. While adding shoes to the program, Sears said it would delete toys, accessories and infant furniture. Some analysts dismissed Kidvantage as a gimmick when Sears introduced it in 1991, but many now say it has helped the company regain some share of the market for children's apparel.

title: Review/Fashion; A Summer Softness From 7th Avenue
description: The fashion world operates according to its own clock. This week, Seventh Avenue is on summer time, offering the clothes that will be in the stores starting in April to wear during the first big summer weekends..

title: Furs and Cars Incite Ire Of the Painfully Correct
description: IT'S more demanding than special interests. It's more pious than political correctness. It's more evangelical than any rainbow coalition.

title: Suburban Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pending Suits: Their Effect On Budget In New York
description: As New York State budget analysts prepare Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget, which is to be released today, one of their hardest tasks is accounting for unanticipated revenues and unexpected drains on the state treasury.

title: Criticized as Appeaser, Vance Defends His Role in Balkans
description: On the eve of what he regards as a decisive moment in his five-month effort to find a way to end the savage wars in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Cyrus R. Vance finds himself for the first time in his life being sharply criticized for even talking about peace.

title: Observer; Diaries on the Eve
description: Bill Clinton's Diary

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Josephine T. Moran, a former Westchester resident who died on Wednesday in Boulder, Colo., misstated her age. She was 81.

title: Courtroom Drama Pits G.M. Against a Former Engineer
description: In a small Atlanta courtroom, General Motors officials have been witnessing a drama that Hollywood would envy. A former company engineer, who had previously testified only for the car maker, has told a jury that G.M. knew for years that some of its popular pickup trucks were firetraps but that it refused to fix what he called defective fuel tanks.

title: Dow Gains 3.79 in Active Holiday Trading
description: Investors took no holiday from buying cyclical stocks yesterday, as companies that would prosper the most in an accelerating recovery stood out in an otherwise mixed market.

title: Advances in Physics Lie Just Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Rough Times for Rich and Famous
description: The officials ruined Charles Barkley's day. Patrick Ewing's was nearly "messed up" by the fans. It sure is a tough life, having to bear the superstar's cross for a measly five million or so a year, not counting endorsements.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Curtis Macomber Violinist Kathryn Bache Miller Theater

title: Pulse Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Greatest Flood
description: The greatest flood on Earth occurred in south-central Siberia near the end of the last Ice Age, according to a study published in the current issue of the journal Science.

title: Insurer Files Recovery Plan
description: The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company filed a recovery plan last week that incorporates agreements in principle reached in December with state regulators across the country.

title: Patterns
description: Bloomingdale's Beachhead

title: Union Planters reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Agreed to terms with Brady Anderson, outfielder, on a one-year contract.

title: In Crown Heights, Inequality Goes Back to '66
description: To the Editor:

title: Gendex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Critic's Notebook; Robert Shaw Builds a Chorus, and Leads It
description: It is too easy to forget, when faced with a polished, humane and subtle performance like the one of Berlioz's Requiem that Robert Shaw conducted on Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, that music's grand power comes from small details, that its spontaneity arises from meticulous labor, that its simplicity can be created only by confronting seemingly countless complexities. This Requiem hid its origins; it had an organic character, with each movement establishing its own pulse and breath. The performance seemed almost improvised, so natural were its gestures.

title: Acxiom Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Acxiom said that all earnings per share figures have been restated for the impact of a 2-for-1 stock split effected by means of a common stock dividend that was effective Nov. 30, 1992.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: NBD Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 37,885,000 on an accounting adjustment from the adoption of FAS No. 106.Results also included merger-related provisions of $ 51.4 million.Data have been restated for the mergers with Summcorp and INB Financial, both of which were accounted for as a pooling of interests. Period-to-period changes included the purchase on Jan. 23, 1992, of the $ 1.5 billion Gainer Corp. In addition, data for 1991 have been restated to reflect the merger with FNW Bancorp Inc. on Oct. 1, 1991.NBD Bancorp said that its net income for 1992 included merger-related charges of $ 85,322,000 taken in connection with the July 1, 1992, merger with Summcorp of Fort Wayne, Ind., and the Oct. 15, 1992, merger with INB Financial Corp. of Indianapolis.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Thomas B. Curtis, a former Congressman from Missouri, omitted the name of a surviving son. He is Leland B. Curtis of Webster Groves, Mo.

title: Awaiting the Bentsen Treasury
description: With the inauguration of the Clinton Presidency tomorrow, the bond market should find out soon if the Treasury Department under Lloyd Bentsen will fiddle with its debt-management levers to stimulate the economy and cut the record Federal budget deficit.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Aprile Millo Soprano Avery Fisher Hall

title: U.S. LEADS FURTHER ATTACKS ON IRAQI ANTIAIRCRAFT SITES; ADMITS ITS MISSILE HIT HOTEL: RAIDS IN 2 REGIONS
description: Allied warplanes renewed their bombing raids against Iraq today as Baghdad continued to challenge enforcement of flight bans over both northern and southern Iraq.

title: To Bolster Olympic Bid, China Eases Its Surveillance of Reporters
description: The Chinese authorities appear to have stopped following foreign reporters, as part of an effort to spruce up their image and help their bid to become host of the Olympic Games in the year 2000.

title: Insight; Suddenly Popular
description: For Ames Department Stores, no news seems to be very good news indeed, The new shares being issued to creditors more than doubled yesterday, after the company emerged from bankruptcy at the end of last year. Despite a favorable mention in Barron's, analysts saw nothing new to assure them about Ames's longterm prospects.

title: Barkley Explodes, but It's Knicks Who Sparkle
description: It was a game that featured the dominant side of Patrick Ewing, and the volatile side of Charles Barkley, who angrily chased a referee after the final buzzer, vaulting over the scorer's table and pursuing the official down the runway to the locker room.

title: U.S. SECURITY TEAM STILL INCOMPLETE
description: Two days before he inherits a series of foreign policy crises, President-elect Bill Clinton has assembled a team of foreign policy advisers but has yet to fill most of his senior defense positions, transition officials said today.

title: THE INAUGURATION: Generations of Transitions; Former Torch Passers Reflect on Clinton's Daunting Task
description: To Herbert Brownell Jr., Bill Clinton's experience is renewed proof that no incoming President has anything approaching complete control of his agenda. Hamilton Jordan urges Mr. Clinton to fight the natural tendency to overreact to previous administrations' failings. Michael K. Deaver hopes the Clinton team understands that "what's in the package counts as much as the wrapping."

title: Dr. R. H. Edwin Espy, 84, a Leader of Ecumenism
description: Dr. R. H. Edwin Espy, a former general secretary of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the United States and a leader of the ecumenical movement for more than 40 years, died Sunday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 84.

title: Accounts
description: * LTV Steel Co., Cleveland, to Meldrum & Fewsmith Commmunications Inc., Cleveland, to handle its corporate and trade accounts, previously at Ogilvy & Mather Houston. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Article 338093 -- No Title
description: Borland International Inc., deeply stung by rival Microsoft in the business software market, said late today that it had a third-quarter loss of $61.3 million.

title: Southern Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $ 11 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 16 million, or 5 cents a share, in the year, from the settlement of a contract dispute with Gulf States Utilities.c-Included a charge of $ 33 million to cover costs from a work force reduction.The company also said that its 1991 fourth-quarter results included a gain of $ 114 million, or 36 cents a share, on the Gulf States settlement.

title: THE INAUGURATION: The Social Scene
description: It cost $1,500 to eat a "brace of American birds" with Minnesota wild rice at an inaugural dinner honoring Al Gore, but the biggest of tonight's populist events was almost free.

title: Central & South West reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per-share figures are after payment of preferred dividends.

title: Xerox Sets A Course Reversal
description: The Xerox Corporation, which invested in financial services operations in the late 1970's and early 1980's when its copying machines business faltered, said yesterday that it was reversing its diversification to concentrate on its revived copier and printer operations.

title: Neighbors Remember A 'Grandmother' to All
description: He did not have to kill her, her grandson and neighbors insisted. Doll Johnson would have given him the money anyway, as she had done to so many needy people in her 80 years of life.

title: President Riverboat Casinos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a one-time deferred compensation charge of $ 3.4 million.The company was reorganized subsequent to Nov. 30, 1992 and made an initial public offering of its shares on Dec. 11.President Riverboat had pro forma earnings of 87 cents a share for the latest third quarter and 51 cents a share for the latest 9 months. These per-share figures assume the company's reorganization had occurred at the beginning of fiscal 1993 (March 1, 1992) resulting in income taxes being computed at a rate of 40 percent and the issuance of common shares reflecting the reorganization.This and the estimated number of 302,238 shares being sold by the company which would be necessary, net of underwriting discount, to fund a $ 5.2 million distribution to a shareholder that was paid from the proceeds of the company's initial public offering.The company's earnings per share utilizing the ''adjusted'' outstanding shares, which do not include the shares representing the distribution to the shareholders, would be 91 cents a share for the latest third quarter and 54 cents a share for the latest 9 months.Neither of the earnings per share numbers reflect the effect of the company's recent public offering. After the consummation of the public offering, the company had 9,839,900 shares outstanding.Year-ago figures were not comparable.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: First Federal Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: First Federal Bancorp went public on July 14, 1992.

title: Most Markets Open Yesterday
description: The Government securities market was closed yesterday in the United States in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. All other financial and commodity markets were open. Many banks and government offices were closed.

title: 'The Crying Game': The Healing Powers Of a Successful Movie
description: Less than two years ago, Neil Jordan considered giving up the movie business. "The movies were getting worse and worse, the business seemed more difficult to get anything through," he said. "You looked at what was coming out: such paucity of invention. I kept thinking, 'Why not take up something more rewarding?' "

title: Canadian Satellite Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax provision of $ 1.1 million.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mark Twain Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Advertising
description: WHEN a large agency remakes itself, it's often difficult to communicate that change is under way. After all, it is not as if, in some equivalent of Consolidated Edison, a huge "Dig we must" sign can be posted over a blank magazine page to indicate work in progress.

title: Russia Urges the Security Council To Reconvene on the Iraq Fighting
description: Uneasy at the renewed attacks on a former Soviet ally, Russia urged today that the Security Council be reconvened to consider the tensions in Iraq.

title: 2 Officers Are Hurt When Gunman Fires At Car in Brooklyn
description: Two undercover narcotics officers were wounded last night when an unidentified gunman opened fire from behind their unmarked car in East New York, Brooklyn, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. A bullet grazed one officer in the wrist, and flying glass hit the other officer in the eye, he said.

title: THE INAUGURATION: A Lunch to Remember; 'Power Lunch' With Clinton: Faces and Food for Thought
description: It was billed as a gathering of ordinary people who impressed Bill Clinton and Al Gore and their wives on the way to the White House.

description: b-After the cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting principle (adoption of SFAS No. 109, Accounting for Income Taxes.) The net loss before the accounting change was $ 681,000.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the data processing subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation understated the value of a 10-year contract that it was awarded last month by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. It is worth $3 billion.

title: United Carolina Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Review/Television; The Past Is Still Present In a Report on Clinton
description: Although "Clinton Takes Over" may sound like tomorrow's news, tonight's "Frontline" report is mostly yesterday's news. A few minutes of new material was not included in the review tape, but it cannot help much. Despite the best efforts of the producers, who have been trailing Clinton & Company for several weeks, they find themselves doing the job of the little fellow in the Chaplin movie who follows the elephants in the big parade.

title: Allies to Use Threat of Action on Flight Ban as Way to Press Serbs
description: The United States, Britain and France plan to delay any Security Council action on the enforcement of a ban on military flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina unless Bosnian Serbs completely reject a peace plan drawn up by international mediators.

title: NBB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $ 5 million, or 58 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: An Invisible Generation Looks in the Mirror; Search for Nihilism
description: To the Editor:

title: United New Mexico Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Mountaineer Bankshares of W. Va. Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Witt and Friends Becoming Stars in Prime Time
description: These must be the halcyon days of figure skating on television. Katarina Witt, Brian Boitano and Nancy Kerrigan are growing omnipresent in competitions and exhibitions usually taped weeks and months before their air dates.

title: Dr. Matthew A. Kelly, Professor Of Labor Relations, Is Dead at 79
description: Dr. Matthew Arnold Kelly, professor emeritus of industrial and labor relations at Cornell University, died yesterday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 79 and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: The Next Informational Wave May Be Carried on Compact Disk
description: JUST as audio compact disks have banished vinyl phonograph albums to the nostalgia bins, compact disks for computers may soon reduce the role of the familiar floppy disk. After several years of slow growth, the use of compact-disk drives in personal computers is beginning to accelerate.

title: Universal Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Concrete Bunker Dug Up From the Yard of Suspect
description: The concrete bunker in which Katie Beers was held captive for 16 days was carefully dug up today and removed from the yard of John Esposito, the Long Island man charged with kidnapping the 10-year-old girl.

title: This Time, Defense Delivers In Clutch
description: Sam Bowie has had better seasons. There was a time, not too long ago, when the Nets considered him indispensable. But with new regimes come new attitudes. Chuck Daly came in, and the trade talk started. There have been times this season when Bowie has simply flopped. Some began to wonder: Is Bowie tough enough?

title: Turks' Concern Grows On Tie to Anti-Iraq Bloc
description: Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel summoned the United States, British and French ambassadors today amid indications that Turkey is increasingly uncomfortable about being brought closer to the conflict with Iraq.

title: Witness, on Videotape, Links Lawyer to Bank
description: In unusual videotaped pretrial testimony, a dying former official of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International testified yesterday against Robert A. Altman, Clark M. Clifford's law partner, strongly linking Mr. Altman to B.C.C.I. and its secret control of an American bank.

title: Early Departure for the Lone McEnroe Still on Tour
description: Since 1988, when the Australian Open left the grass at Kooyong Stadium for the Rebound Ace of Flinders Park, the McEnroe clan has nearly always played an integral role in the proceedings.

title: THE INAUGURATION: The Overview; Era of 'Peril and Promise' Is Ahead, Clinton Says
description: President-elect Bill Clinton blended celebration with statecraft today as he sought to assure foreign diplomats that he was ready to inherit the White House in a time of global conflict.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Oates Paces Bruins Adam Oates scored a pair of power-play goals within 47 seconds of the third period and assisted on the Bruins' two other goals yesterday afternoon as Boston beat the San Jose Sharks, 4-3, in Boston. Oates, third in National Hockey League scoring with 77 points, set up Ray Bourque and Joe Juneau for goals as San Jose lost its eighth consecutive game. (AP) Jets 8, Whalers 7: Evgeny Davydov's goal at 14:13 of the third period snapped a 7-7 tie and Phil Housley had a team record 5 assists as the Winnipeg Jets beat the Hartford Whalers in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, for their seventh straight victory. Trailing by 7-4 in the third period in front of 7,756 fans at the neutral-site game, the Jets rallied when Hartford's Mark Janssens received a five-minute major for boarding. Thomas Steen scored twice on the ensuing power play. (AP) SOCCER Finally, Some Referees Egypt and Angola played a scoreless tie yesterday in a World Cup qualifying game delayed a day because the game officials didn't arrive at the stadium in Luanda, Angola. (AP)

title: Bruno's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 993,000 in the quarter and $ 1,767,000 in the 6 months.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: 7 Are Killed as Commuter Trains Collide in Indiana
description: Seven people were killed today and dozens of others were injured, 10 critically, when two commuter trains heading in opposite directions sideswiped each other where the tracks converge here to cross a trestle.

title: Whitman Announces Bid
description: Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican who almost defeated Bill Bradley in the 1990 Senate race, announced today that she will formally open her campaign for Governor on Jan. 27. On the three-stop tour of the state to announce her candidacy, she will be accompanied by the co-chairmen of her campaign, United States Representative Dick Zimmer and Hazel Frank Gluck, who was Transportation Commissioner in the cabinet of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Ed Rollins, who managed the Presidential campaigns of Ronald Reagan, and, briefly, Ross Perot, will be Mrs. Whitman's chief campaign adviser.

title: Topics of The Times; Flowery Promises
description: The future, for gardeners, showed up in their mailboxes in early January. The new seed catalogues always seem not so much a sales pitch as an act of mercy at a time when gardeners' expectations are as frozen as their flowerbeds. This year, as the catalogues were arriving, winter played an unkind hoax. The temperatures went up into the 60's, the soil was as warm as April's and everything seemed ready for planting -- except, of course, that there weren't any seeds yet.

title: Sports of The Times; Sir Charles Needs Time To Reflect
description: It started off so sweetly for Charles Barkley and it ended so nastily. He loped toward the court for pre-game warm-ups and he spotted a couple of little boys standing there, gawking at the giants.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP., Louisville, Ky., said it had completed the acquisition of Academy Insurance Group Inc., Atlanta, for $117.6 million. DOW CHEMICAL CO., Midland, Mich., said it had purchased a plastics factory in Yocheon, South Korea, from Sung Hwa Petrochemical Industrial Co. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Gooden Struck by Dizzy Spell
description: Four days after his one-car accident in St. Petersburg, Fla., Dwight Gooden resumed his off-season workouts yesterday and reported some dizziness after a two-mile run. Gooden said he rested for about 10 or 15 minutes after feeling lightheaded and then finished his training without further interruption.

title: Jailers Say New York Inmates Shoot Themselves, Then Sue
description: When it comes to con games and contraband and the run-of-the-mill smuggling of hacksaws and handguns, New York City jail officials have seen it all. Usually the idea is to break out or settle a score.

title: Mutual Fund Case Dropped
description: Citing "grave reservations" about the basis of the state's case, a Virginia circuit court judge today dismissed all charges against the First Investors Corporation related to fraudulent mutual fund sales.

title: Recriminations Follow Debacle of Short First Flight of Earthwinds
description: BITTER recriminations and a far-reaching post-mortem followed the crash last week of Earthwinds, probably the most expensive and ambitious ballooning project in history. But participants believe the crash offers a painful object lesson not only for balloonists but for planners of such complex systems as future space missions.

title: Mysterious Epidemic Of Furtive Liver Virus
description: EVERY Tuesday is liver clinic day at the Veterans Affairs Hospital in Washington, a time when patients with every sort of liver ailment are seen by Dr. Leonard Seeff and his staff. Last week was typical. Dr. Seeff saw 15 patients, and 13 had hepatitis C, a tenacious, insidious and sometimes fatal virus that infects the liver and that only now is becoming recognized as a public health threat.

title: Humbled in Hartford: UConn Loses by 17
description: Another stellar performance by Othella Harrington, Georgetown's freshman center, opened the way for the Hoyas tonight. They routed Connecticut, 86-69, and moved into a tie for third place with Pittsburgh in the Big East standings. And they are just a half game behind the co-leaders, St. John's and Seton Hall.

title: Bulls Activate Williams
description: The Chicago Bulls activated center SCOTT WILLIAMS and placed RODNEY McCRAY on the injured list. McCray sprained his right knee last Friday against Golden State. Williams had been placed on the injured list Jan. 8 with tendinitis in his right knee. (AP)

title: Standex International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jostens Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Jostens said that earlier reported amounts have been restated to include the results of Wicat Systems Inc., which was acquired in August 1992 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Olaf Bar Baritone Alice Tully Hall

title: Suit Threatens Indigent-Care System
description: Every year, Jamaica Hospital in Queens treats thousands of patients like Elba Echevarria, who arrived at its emergency room last summer with a crushed finger and no health insurance.

title: Teco Energy Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Teppco Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: McKay Is Sidelined
description: For the time being, Coach HERB BROOKS of the Devils will have to find somebody else to play left wing alongside BERNIE NICHOLLS, because RANDY McKAY, who played the position Saturday night in Nicholls's New Jersey debut, will be out for at least five days with a strained right knee.

title: COMPANY EARNINGS: Highlights; PRIMERICA CORP. (N)
description: Even with a rise of nearly 68 percent in fourth-quarter income, Primerica's financial results were greeted with a frown on Wall Street yesterday, as investors sold shares on the news.

title: Guilford Mills Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
MDS Health Group reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 12,262,000, or 47 cents a share, from the sale of assets.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said most of the improvement in revenues was attributable to the acquisition of Nordion International Inc., effective Nov. 1, 1991, which added about $ 160 million to the revenue base. This increase was partly offset by a decline in revenues due to the sale of the company's U.S. clinical laboratory operations on Jan. 16, 1992.

title: Bills Aren't Sounding As If You Know What Is a Concern for Them
description: An hour after Buffalo had beaten the Miami Dolphins on Sunday to win its third consecutive American Football Conference championship, there were four players left in the Bills' locker room, talking to reporters. Linebacker Cornelius Bennett was one of them. This caught even Bennett by surprise.

title: On My Mind; Bill Clinton's War
description: And so from the moment he takes the oath Bill Clinton becomes a wartime President -- exactly as he had known all along.

title: THE INAUGURATION: Static on the Coverage; Viewers Are Upset Over HBO's Rights To Inaugural Event
description: In the middle of one of the most glittering events of the inaugural week, the Sunday concert at the Lincoln Memorial, people watching on CNN and C-Span found themselves cut off from the songs of stars like Diana Ross, Bob Dylan and Kenny Rogers.

title: Webber Breaks Nose
description: CHRIS WEBBER, Michigan's star sophomore forward, broke his nose during practice and was described as questionable for the Wolverines' game tomorrow night at Minnesota. Webber leads Michigan with an average of 20.4 points, 9.6 rebounds and 3.3 blocked shots per game.

title: People's Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Anton Crihan Dead; Moldova Exile, 99, Escaped Soviet Rule
description: Anton Crihan, a leader in the movement that reunited his native region of Bessarabia with Romania between the world wars, , died on Jan. 9 in a hospital in St. Louis, Mo. He was 99 and lived in St. Louis.

title: CHEVRON BUDGET STRESSES FOREIGN PROJECTS
description: The Chevron Corporation, the nation's third-largest oil company, said yesterday that its 1993 capital budget would increase by 5 percent, to $4.9 billion, primarily reflecting a continuing emphasis on overseas projects. Chevron said it intended to spend 75 percent of its $2.6 billion exploration and production budget outside the United States, about 10 percent more than estimated exploration and production expenditures last year. The company also said it would reduce spending for domestic exploration and production by 20 percent from last year, to $700 million. The overseas budget includes the planned start-up of a joint venture in the former Soviet republic of Kazakhstan.

title: Gordon W. Fawcett, 81, Paperback Book Pioneer
description: Gordon Wesley Fawcett, who with his three brothers built a publishing empire that included some of the most popular crime and romance magazines in the nation, died on Saturday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 ALLIES RENEW STRIKES ON IRAQ

title: A Hard Lesson in Living With Seniority Rules
description: To Aicila Barksdale, Kendra McCall and the other fourth graders struggling to be somebody in the gifted and talented class at Public School 145, Lorraine Uhlmann was someone special.

title: The Halfway Man
description: What we know is that in two days, the Presidency of George Herbert Walker Bush will be, as they say, history. What we do not know is whether history will judge him more kindly than the voters did in November.

title: Cowboys Travel Full-Speed Ahead to Super Bowl
description: Enthusiasm, courage, talent. All of the things the Dallas Cowboys showed in toppling the San Francisco 49ers by 30-20 on Sunday to earn a Super Bowl XXVII berth are reasons why they are early betting favorites to beat the Buffalo Bills.

title: A First for Kisio
description: Pittsburgh Penguins wing RICK TOCCHET and San Jose center KELLY KISIO have been added to the rosters for next month's National Hockey League All-Star game in Montreal, the league announced. Tocchet replaces teammate MARIO LEMIEUX, who is expected to be sidelined at least six weeks while being treated for Hodgkin's disease. Kisio, a 10-year N.H.L. veteran, will be playing in his first All-Star Game. The 33-year-old former Ranger leads the Sharks in scoring with 12 goals and 30 assists. (AP)

title: Oration by Daughter of Dr. King Adds Special Touch to a Service
description: In a ceremony at times angry, searching, proud and poignant, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was memorialized here today, a quarter-century after his assassination in Memphis.

title: Rockwell International Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 1,519,000,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for retirement medical benefits. The period also included a gain of 8 cents a share from the sale of a product line.

title: Music Notes; Probing the Inner Life Of Gershwin the Man
description: George Gershwin's music is virtually always in the air, but the details of his personal life have remained something of a mystery. It may well be that at this point, nearly 56 years after the composer's death, it's only the music that matters. But Gershwin fans interested in peeking behind the scrim erected by the composer's family will have an opportunity to reconsider the composer's life and times in May, when Joan Peyser's biography, "The Memory of All That: The Life of George Gershwin," is due from Simon & Schuster.

title: Rumors of U.S. Superplane Appear Unfounded
description: RUMORS and reported sightings of a secret American superplane have been proliferating lately almost as abundantly as yarns about unidentified flying objects. But despite the acknowledged yearning of many American aviation experts and buffs for an ultrafast spy plane, it appears that development of even the engine needed for such a plane is moving faster in Russia than in this country.

title: An Inaugural Guide
description: Today 1:30 P.M. "Salute to Children," Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts (ticket required). (Disney Channel - 3 to 4 P.M. (taped)) 3:30 P.M. "Salute to Youth," Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts (ticket required). (Disney Channel - 5 to 6 P.M. (taped)) 7 P.M. "Presidential Gala," Capital Center, with entertainment (ticket required). (CBS - 9 to 11 P.M.) Tomorrow 8 A.M. Prayer service, Metropolitan A.M.E. Church (by invitation). President Bush and his wife, Barbara, receive President-elect Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary, at the White House. 11:30 A.M. Inaugural ceremony, west front of the Capitol. Inovation by the Rev. Billing Graham. Vice President-elect Al Gore is administered the oath of office by retired Justice Thurgood Marshall. President-elect Clinton is administered the oath of office by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Mr. Clinton delivers his inaugural address. Private luncheon with Congressional leaders and members of the Supreme Court, at the Capitol. (NBC - 10 A.M. to 2 P.M., CBS, ABC, CNN - 10 A.M. to 1:00 P.M., PBS - 10 A.M. to 2:30 P.M., FOX - 11:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M.) 2 P.M. The Clintons and Gores head for the inaugural parade reviewing stand in front of the White House. 2:30 P.M. The inaugural parade begins following route from the Capitol to the White House. (NBC, CBS, ABC, CNN - 2 to 4 P.M.) 6:30 P.M. - 9 P.M. The ITT Corporation is holding a "gala reception" in the Sheraton Carlton Hotel. 7 P.M. National Ball, National Building Museum. Thursday 9 A.M. - Noon Open house at the White House (ticket required). 2 P.M.-5 P.M. Reception for Arkansans, White House (ticket required).

title: Stout, Storied Heroes (Cuddly Too)
description: HERE'S a practical idea that probably won't make President Clinton's Inaugural Address tomorrow. We should immediately commission the National Institutes of Health to issue a report as soon as possible titled: "Qualifications, Quantifications and Quotients of the Psycho-Cerebral Impact on Minute Homo Sapiens of Intimate Associations with Ursus Theodoro Stuffus (and the Emotional Deficits Suffered From Deprivations Thereof): An Analysis."

title: NS Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Whitney Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Westco Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 254,263 charge for the adoption of SFAS No. 109.There were no per share earnings in the latest year and both year-ago periods because they were not meaningful; the company converted to a stock from a mutual ownership format in June 1992.

title: Corrections
description: One entry in a series of brief profiles of candidates for mayor of Los Angeles on Friday described the electoral history of Assemblyman Richard Katz incorrectly. He was elected in 1980, and has been re-elected every two years since.

title: Fordham Reaches Bottom In Rout by Marquette
description: In an attempt to recapture the magic surrounding Fordham's 60-55 upset victory over St. John's last Dec. 10, the message board in front of Rose Hill Gymnasium yesterday flashed this to Rams fans: "You helped 'em beat St. John's, Now help 'em beat Marquette."

title: Americans Have High Hopes for Clinton, Poll Finds
description: Americans await Bill Clinton's Presidency with revived optimism about the nation and its economy and a pre-inaugural burst of confidence in him as an effective leader who cares about them, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Investors Punish Centocor for More Bad News
description: Wall Street can be unforgiving of biotechnology stocks that fail to deliver on their promises.

title: Suspect in Bronx Slaying Recalled as a Loner
description: Within the shelter of the Franklin Avenue Armory, Christopher Battiste was a cipher -- a loner who lashed out with angry words and karate kicks at unseen enemies while meandering aimlessly about the drill floor by day and trembling fitfully in his cot at night.

title: Critics Nominate 25 Books
description: The National Book Critics Circle yesterday announced the nominations for its annual awards for fiction, general nonfiction, biography, poetry and criticism.

title: COMPANY EARNINGS: Highlights; NATIONSBANK (N)
description: Making loans is again becoming a good business, at least for Nationsbank. After experiencing a decline in lending in 1991 and the first half of 1992, the banking company based in Charlotte, N.C., increased its loans and leases by 3.8 percent in the fourth quarter to $71.8 billion. Loan demand is beginning to pick up in the Southeast, analysts say, and existing business borrowers are not paying off their loans as quickly.

title: CF Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest per share results for the quarter is fully diluted.Year-ago per share results are not applicable; the company went public in July of 1992.

title: CHARTER CONSOLIDATED MAY SELL METALS-CONCERN STAKE
description: Charter Consolidated P.L.C. said yesterday that it was considering selling its 38.4 percent stake in Johnson Matthey P.L.C., a metals-processing concern, for $:364 million, about $567 million. A spokeswoman for Charter said the London-based mining and manufacturing conglomerate built up its holding in Johnson Matthey from a 28 percent stake it gained in an asset swap in 1979 with the Anglo American Corporation. Johnson Matthey, also of London, supplies automobile catalysts, materials for micro-electronics and metal-based products for platinum anti-cancer drugs. It is also the largest refiner of gold outside South Africa.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Emerson String Quartet 92d Street Y

title: Bio-Logic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Rabbits Beware! Some Birds of Prey Hunt in Packs
description: THE majestic image of the lone eagle may often hold true. But scientists are also beginning to piece together a more complex picture of eagles, hawks and falcons as team players whose hunting tactics and cunning intelligence invite comparison with the wolf and the fox.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: First Georgia Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
4 Wounded by Bombs in Palestinian Camp
description: Four bombs exploded in the largest Palestinian camp in Lebanon late Sunday night, wounding four people, including two children, in what security officials said was recurring violence between rival guerrilla factions.

title: Hibernia Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $ 56,122,000 on debt restructuring.c-Net lossd-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 21,643,000 from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for lease expense.

title: Hunting for Accord on Alaska Wolves
description: The great wolf debate swarmed into this small Indian village aboard a squadron of state-chartered airplanes today as Alaska officials sought to convince conservationists and the American public that wolf killing has a beneficial side.

title: Review/Television; Going Without the Giggles and Leers, on Fox Yet
description: Postponed from October, two Fox broadcasting series will finally make their debuts tonight: "Class of '96," at 8, and "Key West," at 9. In both instances, the evolving network eases away from the giggle-and-trash image it has sculptured with shows like "Married . . . With Children." Is the country ready for Fox and, all things being relative, upscale programming? Each hourlong series is, of course, rooted in formula. What matters are the sensibilities and skills shaping those formulas. So while set in a fictional Northeastern Ivy League college (actually filmed at the University of Toronto), "Class of '96" is not just a next-stage development of "Beverly Hills 90210," Fox's hit high-school drama.

title: Software Spectrum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Murray Phillips, 83, Singer and Teacher
description: Murray Phillips, a folk singer and songwriter, died on Saturday at his home in Emerson, N.J. He was 83.

title: For Rangers' Richter, Banishment Breeds Hope of Revival
description: Mike Richter can chart his downfall. It didn't start with a particular game or a particularly bad goal he allowed. It started with the apartment. That was the first time he really clashed with Coach Roger Neilson. That was the first time in his romance with the Rangers that he felt as if someone in the organization had slapped him on the wrist.

title: Green Taxis and Clean Buses; Transportation for a New-Age Inaugural
description: A new Administration is coming to Washington, and everyone wants to join the parade -- including, quite literally, taxis and buses that run on natural gas and electricity. The taxis are local but the buses are coming by tow truck and flatbed trailer from as far away as Cleveland and Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: MPG Investments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that the net asset value per common share at Dec. 31, 1992 was $ 13.60, compared with $ 13.36 in year-ago period.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There will be no trip to the Inauguration for Iowa's Republican governor, TERRY E. BRANSTAD, who was to have gone to Washington today for a luncheon with President-elect Bill Clinton and for the swearing-in cermonies.

title: In His Own Words
description: PRESIDENT-ELECT BILL CLINTON In an address yesterday to diplomats at Georgetown University

title: Public & Private; The Sins Of Zoe Baird
description: It's been easy for people to be single-minded and sure about the sins of Zoe Baird. The first woman chosen to be Attorney General was caught with her child care down -- her sitter and the sitter's husband, who drove Ms. Baird to and from the office, were illegal aliens. And taxes had not been withheld from their wages.

title: Illinois Central Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special pretax charge of $ 8.9 million for organizational changes and various unrelated asset revaluations in the quarter and a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 23,400,000, or 55 cents a share, in the year.

title: A Splash of Vitriol in the Inaugural Champagne
description: In a city where intrigue and gossip are the coin of the realm, the Presidential Inaugural Committee has been the juiciest target for weeks. Caterers and party planners, who never criticize clients, can't wait to tell their latest horror stories.

title: Diversity on Parade!
description: "A new Administration has just been sworn in and, so help me God, we've got the parade to celebrate it! Hi, I'm your morning weatherman, Happy (Red) Barrons, and here to help me describe the fun is the lovely Trini Slice, whose sitcom 'Dysfunction Junction' premieres tonight on this network!"

title: French Giant Is Acquiring St. Laurent
description: The fashion house of Yves Saint Laurent, a symbol of French creativity in haute couture and beauty products, was acquired today by the pharmaceuticals group Elf Sanofi in a transaction that underscored the current difficulties of French luxury industries.

title: Walt Whitman and Diversity's Promise
description: Cane in hand, hat set at a rakish angle, Walt Whitman wandered Manhattan in the 1840's enthralled by the sights and sounds of America being made.

title: Cheshire Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,604,000, or 47 per share.

title: SAKS PLANS TO HAVE 120 STORES WITHIN 5 YEARS
description: Saks Fifth Avenue plans to have 120 stores open worldwide within five years, its vice chairman, Philip Miller, said yesterday at a National Retail Federation Conference in New York. The company, whose 49 stores generated $1.3 billion in revenue in its most recent fiscal year, plans to open department stores as well as specialty stores. Saks specialty stores will include Armani AX, Salon Z, which sells larger-sized women's apparel, Nancy Heller boutiques and clearance centers.

title: Bausch & Lomb Chooses Warwick
description: Bausch & Lomb's personal products division in Rochester said yesterday that it had selected Warwick Baker & Fiore in New York to handle advertising for Clear Choice, a new nonalcoholic mouthwash. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Warwick Baker was awarded the account after a two-month review that was narrowed to six finalists. The others were Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston and, in New York, Deutsch/Dworin Inc., Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, Masterson Rothberg Advertising and Omon.

title: A Little Sun Shines In On Rainy Santa Anita
description: The sun finally shone on Santa Anita yesterday after the strangest and stormiest run of California weather since the track opened 59 years ago outside Los Angeles. But racing will still be suspended for the next two days so that the horses can get back to training before resuming the season on Friday.

title: In His Own Words
description: PRESIDENT-ELECT BILL CLINTON

title: Hewlett-Packard Is Joining Advanced Micro in Venture
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that they would join forces to build smaller, more powerful microprocessors.

title: Mr. Clinton's Day, and America's
description: It is left now to William Jefferson Clinton to wrest this inaugural week from the power brokers and glitzmeisters and remind the country what a Presidential inauguration is and means: a simple, majestic ceremony signifying the peaceable transition of power and the durability of union.

title: CHEMICAL BANKING CORP. (N)
description: Chemical Banking, the nation's third-largest banking company, said its operating results improved sharply last year but that its net was down because of a $625 million charge for merger-related restructuring. Still, the bank insisted, the merger was a roaring success.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page B1 in some editions on Monday, referring to an article about a dispute between two Greek Orthodox groups, misidentified the clergyman shown before the Weeping Icon. He was Bishop Vikentios.

title: First Virginia Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 886,000 for the adoption of FASB 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes.''In addition, the bank said it will adopt FASB 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions,'' in the first quarter of 1993. First Virginia estimated that the transition obligation will be about $ 13 million and that the annual effect of the accounting change will reduce net income by about 4 cents a share.

title: President for Seahawks
description: DAVID BEHRING, the 37-year-old son of the Seattle Seahawks' majority owner, KEN BEHRING, was named president of the National Football League team yesterday. KEN BEHRING told a news conference that the appointment will give the Seahawks' owners a more direct hand in day-to-day operation of the club. David Behring owns 1 percent of the team. TOM FLORES has been president of the Seahawks for the last four seasons and last season also assumed duties as coach. Flores will remain as coach. (AP)

title: THE INAUGURATION: Screen Play; Hollywood Crowd Gives Capital Two Thumbs Up
description: The current wisdom in Hollywood dismisses movies with political themes and Washington backdrops. Too somber. Too boring. Not enough action. But the inauguration of Bill Clinton, a real-life drama with plenty of music and parties, has virtually turned Pennsylvania Avenue into Sunset Boulevard.

title: Mayors Vote to Move Meeting to New York This Summer
description: Heeding an appeal by Mayor David N. Dinkins, the executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors decided today to hold its annual meeting in New York City this summer.

title:
Campus Journal;
The Enterprise Is Free, the Experience, Priceless
description: At age 13, Kevin McCurdy made a few hundred dollars on his first business, laminating business cards for his neighbors in Mississauga, Ontario. Now a sophomore at Babson College here, Mr. McCurdy, in partnership with his sister's boyfriend, expects to sell about $85,000 worth of custom-made baseball caps this year and have enough profits left over to pay next year's tuition.

title: Food Notes
description: Recipes From Clinton

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP (N)
description: Shares of the Paine Webber Group fell yesterday as the big securities firm reported an 18.8 percent decline in per-share earnings for the fourth quarter of 1992.

title: Smith Corona Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax restructuring charges of $ 500,000 in the quarter and $ 9.5 million in the 6 months, related to move to Mexico.c-Included pretax charge of $ 2 million for software chip replacement program in the quarter and 6 months.d-Net income

title: I.B.M. Posts $5.46 Billion Loss for 4th Quarter; 1992's Deficit Is Biggest in U.S. Business
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported a record $5.46 billion loss for the fourth quarter yesterday and offered little optimism that its business would improve anytime soon.

title: Caviar From Arkansas
description: If caviar is served in the White House, it deserves to be the American sturgeon variety. Not only is this caviar less likely to increase a budget deficit than are other kinds, but most of it comes from paddlefish, a type of sturgeon caught mostly in the lower Mississippi River in Arkansas.

title: A Pop-Up Tutorial on Art for Everyone
description: The crowds that congregated in bookstores last month -- the ones that weren't lining up for Madonna or Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf -- were mesmerized by a beguiling pop-up book about, of all things, art.

title: S&T Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
When Inmates Carry Guns
description: With guns increasingly available everywhere else, it may come as no surprise that they are becoming available inside New York City jails. There should be no controversy about gun control there. Yet the City Correction Department, incredibly, hesitates over serious gun control measures.

title: Review/Jazz; Nostalgia Served With Grit
description: "If you like old-time music, that's me," announced Carrie Smith from the stage of Fat Tuesday's, as she introduced a lightly swinging version of "The Man I Love." The veteran jazz and blues singer, who starred on Broadway not long ago in the musical "Black and Blue," tore into the song as if it were a T-bone steak. She has a large, raw voice with a wide vibrato that oscillates like a breathy tenor saxophone. As determinedly upbeat as she is unpretentious, she treated the Gershwin standard as a rugged statement of intent, not as a wistful daydream.

title: Tidewater Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 700,000 after-tax charge for merger-related expenses.c-Included $ 9.3 million after-tax gain from litigation settlement, partially offset by $ 3 million after-tax charge for merger-related expenses.

title: Next Test for Nets? The Bulls
description: When Chuck Daly was told today that he needed two victories to become the 15th coach in National Basketball Association history to win 500 games, he wanted to know if that total included the playoffs. No, he was told, his 498-318 mark concerned only the regular season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Reprieve for New York on Water Filtering
description: On its last full day in business, the Bush Administration yesterday announced that -- at least for now -- New York will not have to begin filtering its drinking water, a process that could have eventually cost the city $5 billion.

title: An Office First For First Lady?
description: Will Hillary Clinton be the first First Lady to boast an office in the West Wing of the White House?

title: Donors Send Spare Change to Neediest
description: They are inescapable, jiggling and jangling and accumulating in unstable little piles that inevitably topple onto the floor and roll under the furniture. It has long been one of the more annoying problems in a commercial culture where the 99-cent suffix reigns: What is to be done with all the change?

title: Crown Crafts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Review/Dance; Youthfulness and Classicism In 2 Ballets by Robbins
description: For all the quiet of its unfolding, "The Goldberg Variations" is Jerome Robbins at his most ambitious. Mr. Robbins has taken the monumental and difficult Bach score and rendered it in dance in the work, which was presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. Fresh from two encounters with Chopin, in the romantic "Dances at a Gathering" and "In the Night," Mr. Robbins abandoned storytelling for a go at muted architectonic splendor.

title: Cuomo Proposes Spartan Budget With Cutbacks
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed a Spartan state budget that avoids general tax increases by squeezing aid to schools, closing three state mental hospitals, paring the state work force and increasing taxes on hospitals while cutting health benefits for the poor.

title: Bond Prices Surge on Hopes For an Untested President
description: Bond prices were propelled higher yesterday, the day before the inauguration of Bill Clinton as President, on rising confidence in the chances for deficit reduction and visions of nothing more than moderate economic growth.

title: Rene Pleven, 91, Prime Minister Of France Twice in Early 1950's
description: Rene Pleven, a top official in the Free French movement in World War II who served twice as Prime Minister in the 1950's, died on Jan. 13 in Paris. He was 91.

title: Candy's Tortilla Factory reports earnings for Year to Oct 10
description: b-Net incomeCandy's Tortilla Factory blamed the losses for the fourth quarter and year on three factors: its Colorado marketing campaign, which cost $ 1.4 million in the fourth quarter more than anticipated; the delay and costs of starting up new business, and the previously reported loss of Taco Bell as a customer.

title: The Reign of King Bill Descends on the Capital
description: HOW do you know when an Inauguration has crossed that fine line between a populist celebration and the coronation of the Sun King?

title: Clinton Woolsey Dies; Neuroscientist Was 88
description: Dr. Clinton Nathan Woolsey, a neuroscientist at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, died Thursday at Meriter Hospital in Madison. A resident of Madison, he was 88.

title: Johnny Carisi Memorial
description: A memorial service for the jazz trumpeter and composer Johnny Carisi is to be held on Sunday at 7 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Mr. Carisi died on Oct. 3 at age 70.

title: Review/Music; Celebration of Black Culture
description: "The Boys Choir of Harlem and Friends," a two-and-a-half-hour extravaganza that opened a limited engagement at the Richard Rodgers Theater yesterday, is a wholesome family entertainment that wants to be many things to many people. Part variety show, part inspirational pageant, this rambling celebration of black culture takes in everything from Scott Joplin to rap, from old-time vaudeville to the poetry of Maya Angelou.

title: Clinton Rounds Out State Dept. Team
description: Bill Clinton scrambled to fill out his State Department team today as he prepared to become the first President since Richard M. Nixon in 1969 to take office with United States forces deployed in a hostile situation.

title: First Marines Leave Somalia, a Signal to the U.N.
description: On a sand-swept airfield under a broiling noonday sun, more than 200 United States Marines marched in formation today onto a plane bound for California, the first American combat troops to be withdrawn from Somalia since the military operation here began on Dec. 9.

title: Hearty Dishes for Vegetable Lovers
description: For those who like vegetables, and their ranks grow daily, here are two meatless dishes that provide a hearty meal. The mellowness of the broccoli and cheeses finds a nice counterpoint in the sharpness of the dressing for the carrots.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tandy Brands Accessories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Hospitals Need Medically Trained Interpreters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Talk of Vienna; In Post-Modernist Vanguard, Vienna as 'Gomorra' in Opera
description: This is the height of the ball season in Vienna. From New Year's Eve through a giddy procession of Carnival festivities, the Viennese twirl their way toward Lent. It is the ultimate time of year for those who think of Old Vienna in terms of waltzes, Sacher tortes and gobs of billowy whipped cream.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY WOODY ALLEN FREE TO VISIT SON

title: Justice Dept. Challenges Its Civil Rights Division
description: In the final civil rights battle of the Bush Administration, the Justice Department has filed legal briefs that take positions opposed by its own civil rights division involving black voters in Alabama and Georgia.

description: Fourteen men were arrested last night by a police task force combating drug gangs in the Brooklyn neighborhood where a school principal was killed in crossfire a month ago.

title: Abuses by Serbs the Worst Since Nazi Era, Report Says
description: In its final global human rights report, the Bush Administration said today that Serbian forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina were conducting a campaign of "cruelty, brutality and killing" unrivaled since Nazi times.

title: Book Notes
description: Women and Wolves

title: Pirates Survive Overtime Scare
description: Jerry Walker broke out of a season-long slump this evening. The hard-nosed senior scored a game-high 19 points and grabbed 12 rebounds as Seton Hall defeated Villanova, 66-61, in overtime in front of 14,926 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title:
PLAIN AND SIMPLE;
Eating Well
description: "I never eat anything, but I can't lose weight" is a common lament of dieters. Many things are blamed for such an inability to lose weight, among them diets heavy in fat and the bad genetic cards that some people seem to be dealt by their parents.

title: Borden Chemicals/Plastics L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: Last Day in the White House; 'Over and Out,' Bush Says, Then Goes to Walk the Dog
description: It was "kind of a last supper, I guess," said Thomas L. Ashley, one of the five guests at a small dinner given by George and Barbara Bush in the family dining room at the White House on Monday night. "There was no whimpering and no finger-pointing, and we laughed quite a bit.

title: Former Hermes Executive Will Head Oxxford Clothes
description: Oxxford Clothes Inc., the Chicago-based maker of pricey hand-sewn men's suits, named Chrys Fisher president and chief executive yesterday, less than a month after Mr. Fisher resigned as head of the American operations of Hermes, the Paris-based luxury-goods company known for its ties and scarves.

title: Bad News
description: Like many other restaurant stocks, Foodmaker had advanced smartly, by about 40 percent, since October. But the stock's plunge after Washington state officals traced a food poisoning outbreak to the company's Jack-in-the-Box restaurants illustrates how vulnerable such stocks can be. "An isolated situation," the company called it, as investors in other sizzling restaurant issues must hope.

title: Late Selling Pushes the Dow Down 18.92
description: A late round of selling swept blue-chip stocks lower as the benefits of a bond rally were confined largely to those companies most sensitive to interest rates.

title: Changes Are Throwing Sport for a Loop
description: As the sport of figure skating spins with the rotational speed of a triple toe loop, those gathered at the America West Arena this week for the United States championships are holding on for dear life.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday showing properties linked to John Gotti that are among those the Federal Government is suing to seize misstated the Government's version of a relationship between two companies linked to him. According to prosecutors, Mr. Gotti invested money from the Gambino crime family in Albie Trimming, a garment center business, and used it to create a shell company, Scorpio Marketing, from which he drew money he described as a salary.

title: Guards Strive to Fulfill Riley's Dream
description: In the midst of his team's lost Christmas weekend in Chicago and Milwaukee last month, Pat Riley admitted that his team did not have the kind of penetrating point guard capable of taking apart a press or a halfcourt defense all by himself. Name-dropping to illustrate his point, he mentioned the 5-foot-6-inch Muggsy Bogues, who will buzz around Madison Square Garden tonight with the rest of the Charlotte Hornets, looking to repeat their road victory against the Knicks here last month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about Mike Richter, a Rangers goaltender currently assigned to the minor leagues, misattributed a quotation. The passage, which follows, was spoken by Richter, not by Neil Smith, the team's general manager: "It's like they're saying, 'If you start hanging around with a lot of guys who do drugs, even if we don't think you would ever do them, we don't want you to be in that kind of situation.' And it's the idea of the drinking and staying out late, but I'm not doing that."

title: Kodak's Goal: A Leaner Company
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would cut research and development costs, lay off 2,000 people, mostly in its headquarters city of Rochester, and work closely with a new advisory committee of outside directors in an effort to improve its financial performance.

title: THE INAUGURATION: Family Affair; First Relatives Take First Sip of Fame
description: For Arkansans, Virginia Kelley has become an unreconstructed, unapologetic advertisement for the virtues of perseverance, speaking one's mind and devil take the hindmost. But until her son, Bill Clinton, takes the oath of office as President of the United States on Wednesday, the joking, belly-laughing horse-racing fan is holding her peace, publicly.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP. (N)
description: With stronger interest income and higher fees and commissions, the Chase Manhattan Corporation saw a 25 percent gain in earnings in the fourth quarter of last year, compared with the quarter a year earlier, the bank said yesterday. A major component of the gain was in currency trading revenues, which reached $82 million, up from $58 million.

title: An Inaugural Guide
description: Today 8 A.M. Prayer service, Metropolitan A.M.E. Church (by invitation). President Bush and his wife, Barbara, receive President-elect Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary, at the White House. 11:30 A.M. Inaugural ceremony, west front of the Capitol. Inovation by the Rev. Billing Graham. Vice President-elect Al Gore is administered the oath of office by retired Justice Thurgood Marshall. President-elect Clinton is administered the oath of office by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Mr. Clinton delivers his inaugural address. Private luncheon with Congressional leaders and members of the Supreme Court, at the Capitol. (NBC - 10 A.M. to 2 P.M., CBS, ABC, CNN - 10 A.M. to 1:00 P.M., PBS - 10 A.M. to 3 P.M., FOX - 11:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M., C-Span - 11:30 A.M. - 2 P.M.) 2 P.M. The Clintons and Gores head for the inaugural parade reviewing stand in front of the White House. 2:30 P.M. The inaugural parade begins following route from the Capitol to the White House. (NBC, CBS, ABC, CNN - 2 to 4 P.M.) 6:30 P.M. - 9 P.M. The ITT Corporation is holding a "gala reception" in the Sheraton Carlton Hotel. 7 P.M. National Ball, National Building Museum. Thursday 9 A.M. - Noon Open house at the White House (ticket required). 2 P.M.-5 P.M. Reception for Arkansans, White House (ticket required).

title: The Pop Life
description: Traveling Again

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Tomba Falters Again Michael von Gruenigen of Switzerland won his first World Cup race yesterday, in Veysonnaz, Switzerland, keeping Alberto Tomba without a victory in a fourth giant slalom this season. Von Gruenigen, 23, carried over a first-run lead and edged Tomba, the 1988 and 1992 Olympic giant slalom champion from Italy, by .07 seconds. Tomba was lucky to finish after two rough rides and an amazing recovery from a finish-stretch tumble in the first run. Lasse Kjus of Norway was third on the hard-packed snow, .20 seconds behind von Gruenigen's winning time of 2 minutes 29.51 seconds. (AP) YACHTING De Ugarte Is Safe Jose De Ugarte of Spain, a sailor racing solo around-the-world in the Vendee Globe Challenge, avoided near calamity yesterday in the Indian Ocean. De Ugarte sent out a distress signal Monday night that his sailboat was rapidly taking on water. But in a radio message yesterday, Ugarte reported that he had found the leak in his 60-foot sailboat, Euskadi Europa, and was able to repair it. De Ugarte is located about 1,500 miles south of Albany, Australia. De Ugarte is one of 11 yachtsmen in the Vendee competition, a 24,000-mile nonstop race that began on Nov. 22 from Les Sables d'Olonne, France.

title: Review/Theater; A Play On a Film, a Classic of 1945
description: Theatergoers gather onstage for the prologue of "Children of Paradise: Shooting a Dream," as the opening moments of Marcel Carne's 1945 film are re-enacted. With a burst of theatricality, the actors offer a vivid approximation of the carnival life on the Boulevard of Crime in Paris in the early 1800's. Standing high on a distant promontory is Baptiste, the legendary mime, with the American actor Robert Rosen simulating the soulful look of Jean-Louis Barrault.

The investment, which includes $67.5 million for a new parts warehouse in Ontario, Calif., to be built by 1996, is the first decentralization of responsibility by the Toyota Motor Company in Japan to one of its overseas subsidiaries, company officials said.

description: The William Penn Homes, with a third of its windows boarded up and its gardens and lawns paved over, is about as dilapidated as public housing gets. For the people who live in the project here, 12 miles west of Philadelphia in one of the nation's most distressed small cities, remodeling their homes is important. But even more important is a chance to remodel their lives.

description: Mickey Kantor, President-elect Bill Clinton's nominee to become the United States trade representative, announced today that he would remove himself from a broad range of issues to avoid conflicts of interest. And the nominee for Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, broadened slightly his own policy on conflicts of interest.

title: No Wavering on Gay Soldiers
description: In the heat of the campaign, Bill Clinton pledged to issue an executive order to repeal the ban on gay men and lesbians in the military services. The pledge was not made lightly. Mr. Clinton was courting the votes and contributions of homosexuals -- and the approbation of all fair-minded Americans distressed at discrimination and gay-bashing in all areas of society.

description: The former chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Robert C. Stempel, acknowledged yesterday in an Atlanta trial that some of the company's pickup trucks were more likely than competitors' models to catch fire in side collisions.

2 Jurors Dismissed in Glen Ridge Sex Abuse Trial
description: The judge in the Glen Ridge sex assault trial dismissed two jurors today because of problems stemming from a daily prayer group. But he rejected a defense motion for a mistrial, saying he was convinced that comments made by the two jurors would not influence the remaining jurors.

title: Israeli Parliament Lifts a Ban on P.L.O. Contacts
description: The Israeli Parliament voted today to lift a ban on contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization, legalizing meetings with members of the group.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: I always think of pork as winter meat, meat with rich flavor meant to be set off by winter vegetables and robust seasonings. Pork used to have a lot of fat, which was welcome in cold climates in times of no central heating. But today, pork, "the other white meat," particularly the fatless tenderloin, is as good for you as chicken. To me it has more flavor than chicken and deserves to be appreciated in its own right.
