title: Pet Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 5.1 million, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 4 million, or 4 cents a share, in the 6 months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- ADVERTISING
description: EARLIER this week, in introducing Crystal Pepsi clear cola, the Pepsi-Cola Company asserted, "The world is thirsty for change." So must Pepsi be, as evidenced by a decision to substantially change advertising introduced only a year ago for the flagship Pepsi-Cola brand.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW POLICY FOR NEW YORK CITY SHELTERS

title: Restaurants
description: Visiting Barbetta, the longest-running production in the theater district -- since 1925, although founded in the garment district in 1906 -- is sort of like attending a summer repertory theater. In some efforts, the company succeeds surprisingly well, while in others it lays a substantial egg. The best strategy is to go with realistic expectations and a sense of humor.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge on the early extinguishment of debt of $ 10.2 million and $ 41.6 million, for the quarter and year, respectively.c-Net loss and included an accounting charge of $ 1,554,300,000 related to post-retirement benefits.

title: Quaker Oats reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 17.4 million, or 14 cents a share, on the sale of Sorba and Pandea businesses in Italy.

title: Eric R. Sumner, 68, An Engineer, Is Dead
description: Eric R. Sumner, a former vice president of A.T.& T Bell Laboratories, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: Three Days of Artillery Duels Leave 300 Wounded in Kabul
description: Government forces and rebels fought artillery duels in Kabul again today, wounding about 100 people and forcing hundreds to flee their homes, doctors and witnesses said.

title: As His Own Lawyer, a Killer Charms and Sways
description: By many accounts, Joe Hunt might have made a brilliant lawyer, if only his own entanglements with the law had not landed him in prison.

title: May Stores Moving Merchandise Staff to St. Louis
description: The May Department Stores Company announced yesterday that it would move its New York merchandising office to its headquarters in St. Louis.

title: Service for Reginald Lewis
description: A memorial service for Reginald F. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., will be held on Monday at 11 A.M. at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and West 120th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Lewis died on Tuesday at age 50.

title: Clorox Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 19,061,000 from adoption of SFAS 106.Year-ago 6 months' results are restated from $ 25,365,000, or 47 cents a share to reflect the adoption of SFAS 106, Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.

title:
REAL ESTATE: Subsidized Projects;
Recession's Legacy: 15 Affordable L.I. Town Houses
description: The recession has brought an opportunity for this seaside community on Nassau County's South Shore: to transform two vacant lots not far from the central business district into sites for affordable housing.

title: Danger of Mentally Ill Homeless To Be Re-evaluated in New York
description: The Cuomo administration said yesterday that it would begin sending state mental health workers into New York City's homeless shelters in an effort to identify residents who are dangerously mentally ill and place them in state mental hospitals, in some cases against their will.

title: Union Camp Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $ 5,623,000 from early retirement of debt.c-Included a pretax $ 57 million special charge to cover future expenditures to enhance workplace safety. It also included an after-tax charge of $ 7,228,000 from early retirement of debt, and an after-tax gain of $ 40,806,000 from the cumulative effect of adopting SFAS 106 and 109.d-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 3,253,000 from the early retirement of debt in the quarter; the year included an after-tax charge of $ 3,220,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: Jackson Makes Some Strides In a 'One-Shot' Comeback Bid
description: BO JACKSON is preparing for one final comeback attempt with the White Sox. He looked impressive in a workout yesterday in Chicago, fielding grounders, taking swings in a batting cage and running four 120-yard sprints in the carefully monitored time of 20 seconds a sprint.

title: Art in Review
description: Elliot Schwartz Jayne H. Baum Gallery 588 Broadway (near Prince Street) SoHo Through Feb. 13

title: Harry L. Smith; Civic Leader, 84
description: Harry L. Smith, a longtime Brooklyn civic leader, died on Tuesday at his home in Coney Island. He was 84.

title: Daly to Come Back to Tour
description: JOHN DALY, who has undergone alcohol rehabilitation treatment since late last month, will return to action on the pro golf tour next week in Phoenix.

title: Good, Yes, but Against the Bulls, Not Ready for Prime Time
description: The night began with eight-time Olympic gold medalist Carl Lewis delivering the national anthem off key. If that wasn't ugly enough, the Nets, big-time complainers about how they don't get enough respect, blew a big-time opportunity to get some by losing to the Chicago Bulls in front of a packed house.

title: Review/Art; On the Move: The Johns Evolution
description: It seems that an awe-inspiring exhibition reviewing some aspect of Jasper Johns's oeuvre has almost become a requisite of the New York art season. Last year, the Gagosian Gallery devoted an exhibition to "According to What," the artist's complicated 1964 masterwork; in 1991, there was a retrospective of his drawings at the Whitney Museum of American Art, while 1989 brought a show of his "Map" paintings, again at Gagosian.

title: Knicks Hit Road in Improved Spirits
description: On the whole, the Knicks don't mind going to Philadelphia.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the inauguration of President Clinton referred incorrectly to the church where Mr. Clinton attended a morning prayer service. It is African Methodist Episcopal.

title: Dow Up 11.07 and Nasdaq Reaches a High
description: Like Candide, the stock market faced the best of all possible worlds yesterday, reacting to a rally in bonds and evidence from the Federal Reserve of a moderate economic recovery. The Nasdaq Composite average continued its hot streak, rising 3.33, to 700.77, closing above 700 for the first time.

title: Tennis; Capriati Is Able to DefeatA Virus, and Then Labat
description: Jennifer Capriati was lying in bed on Wednesday afternoon, and the prospect of putting on her tennis clothes the next day was growing less appealing by the thermometer reading.

title: Arco Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net charge of $ 56,000,000 associated with the divestiture of its Korean joint venture, and net charge of $ 2,000,000 for cumulative effect of new accounting standards related to postretirement beneifts and income taxes.c-Included an after-tax benefit primarily from business interruption insurance of $ 41,000,000, or 43 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 101,000,000, or $ 1.05 a share, in the year, and the year also included an after-tax charge of $ 15,000,000 related to a cost reduction program.

title: A Plea to the Kennedys
description: In September 1988, I arrived in the United States from Britain intending to write the first complete life of President John F. Kennedy, from his birth in 1917 to his assassination in 1963. I was graciously welcomed by Jacqueline Onassis (my father had been a friend of J.F.K. and of Robert F. Kennedy). Senator Edward Kennedy promised a series of interviews about his own family background, his grandfather John (Honey Fitz) Fitzgerald, his parents and, above all, his elder brother.

title: When MICA's Commit Murder
description: The public's concern last summer focused on Larry Hogue, whose drug-related mental illness led to menace and violence on Manhattan's West Side. Mr. Hogue became notorious for aggressive panhandling, setting fires and other antisocial acts, yet authorities seemed powerless to restrain him.

title: Joseph Anthony, 80, a Director And Stage and Film Actor, Dies
description: Joseph Anthony, an actor and director who at his peak staged four hit productions on Broadway simultaneously, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Hyannis, Mass. He was 80 and lived in Truro, Mass.

title: Sports of The Times; What Parcells Didn't Say
description: IN his best blue suit, Bill Parcells, the best coach in Giants history and until yesterday the best pro football coach available, was answering questions about the New England Patriots while the Giants were trying to complete their deal with Dan Reeves.

title: Centex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Spoken Word
description: ARCHITECTURAL TALK, Transit Museum, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn Heights. An illustrated talk about Squire Vickers, the chief architect of the New York City subways from 1906 to 1942, given by Elisabeth Kashey, a co-director of the Shepherd Gallery in Manhattan. Sunday at 1 P.M. Admission: $6; $3 for members. Information: (718) 330-5839. FOOD LECTURE, Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. "Food for the Belly and the Spirit: Spring Rolls and Other New Year's Foods," a lecture by Barbara Tropp, author of "China Moon Cookbook." Today at 6:30 P.M. Admission: $10; $7 for members. Information: (212) 517-6397 or (212) 517-2742.

title: A Bit of Dissonance Over Pavarotti's Copycat Art
description: It's not even about music. Luciano Pavarotti's latest troubles are about painting. Just a week after he canceled performances with the Metropolitan Opera and other companies, saying his doctor had ordered him to begin a two-month weight-loss program, the 57-year-old tenor is being accused of profiting from three pictures copied from "My Adventures in Europe," a how-to-draw book written in 1972 by Mary E. Hicks, an artist who is now 87 and living on Social Security in La Veta, a small town near Pueblo, Colo.

title: Killing Shown on TV Prompts Debate
description: Two women are walking side by side. A man walks up and shoves one of them out of the way. Then he pulls a gun and shoots the other. As she falls, he shoots her again, 12 times in all.

title: Reconsider Aliens Law in Light of Baird Case
description: To the Editor:

title: SETTLING IN: The Pentagon; Aspin Moves In With Much Unsettled
description: The mundane collided with the sublime at the Pentagon today as Defense Secretary Les Aspin and his staff began moving into their new quarters and immediately faced issues ranging from combat in Iraq to jockeying over Pentagon parking spaces.

title: Time's Up for William Sessions
description: J. Edgar Hoover must be spinning in his grave. Imagine the former F.B.I. Director taking the lashing that Attorney General William Barr administered, hours before resigning, to the incumbent Director, William Sessions.

title: When President Jackson Moved In
description: The most famous White House open house is undoubtedly the one held by Andrew Jackson on March 4, 1829. About 20,000 people poured into the Executive Mansion that day, breaking china and glassware, standing in muddy boots on chairs, ripping down drapery, trampling on rugs and breaking the furniture. But contemporary newspaper accounts were, to say the least, restrained. The Washington City Chronicle March 7, 1829 How a paper that did not support Jackson described the reception.

title: Outside of Alternative Radio, Who's Heard of Mojo Nixon?; Rocking at the Helm
description: To the Editor:

title: In a New Slovakia, Fears Are Both New and Old
description: Wedged into one of the most strategic corners in this unstable region, Eastern Europe's newest small nation has been gripped by uncertainty and foreboding in its first few weeks of independence.

title: Review/Dance; Flamenco 'Dona Flor And Her 2 Husbands'
description: "Flor" is probably one of the most imaginatively staged dance events ever presented at the Joyce Theater. The performers are likable and the energy level high. But the full-evening work, presented by the Zorongo Flamenco Dance Theater on Tuesday night, is essentially dance for those who think of "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding" as fulfilling theater.

title: Results Plus
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Duke Beats N.C. State Sixth-ranked Duke defused North Carolina State's slowdown offense, and Grant Hill had 20 points as the Blue Devils whipped the Wolfpack (4-8 over all, 0-4 in the Atlantic Coast Conference), 92-56, last night in Durham, N.C. Thomas Hill and Bobby Hurley each added 17 points for Duke (13-2, 3-2). (AP) Wake Forest 81, Georgia Tech 58: In Atlanta, Rodney Rogers and Randolph Childress sparked runs of 11-0 and 16-0 as Wake Forest built a commanding first-half lead and handed 16th-ranked Georgia Tech its third loss in a row. Rogers scored 29 points and Childress 18 for the Demon Deacons (10-3, 2-2). Tech fell to 9-4, 2-2. (AP) Utah 82, Hawaii 67: In Salt Lake City, Byron Wilson scored 24 points and led a surge that broke the game open as No. 22 Utah (12-2, 6-0) remained unbeaten in the Western Athletic Conference. (AP) N.B.A. Bucks Edge Pacers Blue Edwards scored 27 points and Todd Day 24 as the Milwaukee Bucks ended their losing streak at seven games with a 110-108 victory over Indiana at Indianapolis last night. The Bucks didn't allow the Pacers a field goal after Sam Mitchell's jumper with 4 minutes 6 seconds left tied the game at 103-103. (AP) Rockets 126, Pistons 120: Hakeem Olajuwon celebrated his 30th birthday with 38 points and helped host Houston win its seventh consecutive game. Joe Dumars scored 32 points for the Pistons. (AP) Nuggets 110, Mavericks 94: Host Dallas, with its best chance of the season to win consecutive games, couldn't pull it off as Denver snapped a 13-game road losing streak. Chris Jackson scored 24 points, helping to send the Mavericks to their 31st loss in 34 games. The Nuggets got 19 points from Reggie Williams and 16 rebounds from LaPhonso Ellis. (AP) N.H.L. Red Wings Rally Again Jimmy Carson and Paul Ysebaert scored back-to-back goals late in the second period to lead the Red Wings to a 5-3 comeback victory over the St. Louis Blues last night in Detroit. The Wings are unbeaten in their last five games (4-0-1). (AP) Whalers 4, Sharks 2: Expansion is all that is keeping the Hartford Whalers from hitting incredible depths. The San Jose Sharks have nothing to keep them afloat. Terry Yake had a goal and an assist as the Whalers won the home game, ending a five-game losing streak and raising their record to 7-0-0 against expansion teams this season. Dean Evason scored both goals for the Sharks. (AP) North Stars 7, Senators 2: Russ Courtnall scored his third career hat trick, giving him nine goals in his last nine games as Minnesota beat Ottawa in Bloomington, Minn. (AP) Blackhawks 6, Capitals 2: Stephane Matteau had two goals for the first time in two years as host Chicago shut down Washington's power-play game and beat the Capitals. With the victory, the Blackhawks remained 4 points ahead of second-place Detroit in the N.H.L.'s Norris Division. (AP) Bruins 5, Flyers 4: Dave Reid's second goal of the game, with 8 minutes 43 seconds remaining, lifted Boston over host Philadelphia. Boston won for just the second time in its last 10 road games (2-7-1) and is 4-1-1 in its last six games overall. Philadelphia dropped its second staight game. (AP)

title: Croats Holding 240 Serbs in a Bosnia Village
description: Disregarding calls by Red Cross and United Nations officials for their release, the Croats who control this remote village are holding about 240 Serbian women, children and elderly people hostage.

title: Kohl Seeks to Cut Benefits to Finance Aid to East
description: To find the $62.5 billion a year needed to rebuild the formerly Communist eastern part of Germany over the next 10 years, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government announced today that it plans to reduce unemployment and welfare benefits for the poor, cut tax breaks for the rich and put a new "solidarity surcharge" on corporate and income taxes in 1995.

title: Much Outrage, Little Sympathy On Main Street
description: Behind the counter at a pet store in a middle-class Washington suburb, Carolyn Williford had drawn herself up in outrage at the notion that Zoe Baird might become Attorney General after hiring illegal immigrants to care for her toddler.

title: Kennametal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 1 million, or 10 cents a share, in connection with a settlement of a patent infringement suit.c-Included gain of $ 300,000, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of a Belgian subsidiary.

title: May Stores Moving Mechandise Staff to St. Louis
description: Pfizer Inc. staked a strong claim yesterday to the title of world's fastest-growing large drug company. At a time when most drug makers are wrestling with slipping growth rates, the New York-based company announced that pharmaceutical sales had leaped 32 percent in the final quarter of 1992.

title: In Killing's Wake, Bronx Residents Debate Men's Shelter
description: Hours before mourners filed past the coffin of Doll Johnson, the 80-year-old Bronx woman who was bludgeoned to death on Sunday, her community demanded that the city close the overcrowded shelter where the suspect in her killing lived.

title: Pfizer Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 312.6 million from the adoption of FASB 106, and a gain of $ 30 million, or 9 cents a share, from FASB 109.c-Included a charge of $ 195 million for potential Shiley Convexo/Concave heart valve fracture claims, in the quarter and year.

title: W. Griswold Smith; Developer, 71
description: W. Griswold Smith, a prominent North Carolina business executive, died Tuesday at his home here. He was 71.

title: Art in Review
description: Paul McMahon Muranushi-Lederman Productions 426 Broome Street SoHo Through tomorrow Zand Projects 38 King Street SoHo Through Feb. 13

title: McDonnell's Earnings Off 61.9% in '92
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that its earnings fell 61.9 percent in 1992, as a result of heavy losses from its C-17 cargo plane and continued declines in its commercial aircraft division. These results excluded the effects of a one-time accounting change that gave the company a net loss for the year.

title: Barnum's Jumbo Is Back In Museum's Center Ring
description: Awe just isn't what it used to be. A century ago, it was enough that Jumbo was the biggest animal anyone had ever seen. Certainly that was sufficient for Phineas T. Barnum, who first displayed the six-and-a-half-ton elephant in 1882. Then he unabashedly mounted an international tour of Jumbo's 13-foot-high skeleton after the elephant died in a much-ballyhooed railroad accident in 1885.

title: But Does Punishment Fit the Budget?
description: With spending on corrections quadrupling in the 1980's and continuing to rise sharply, the North Carolina Legislature this week began considering a plan that would reduce the average criminal sentence in the state by 80 percent and send nonviolent criminals to community programs for supervision, treatment and work.

title: Bill T. Jones Premiere In Dance Center Benefit
description: Performances by the Bill T. Jones/ Arnie Zane Dance Company and the Stephen Petronio Company and the premiere of a work by Mr. Jones will be part of a gala benefit for Movement Research tonight at 8 at the Pace Downtown Theater, 3 Spruce Street, south of City Hall. Mr. Jones has created a new, untitled solo for the program, which also includes his "Love Defined," Mr. Petronio's "Middlesex Gorge" and Mike Taylor's video "Dancenoise: The Phenomenon." Movement Research, celebrating its 15th anniversary, is a center for new dance and workshops on experimental dance and theater.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Whither Hwang?

title: Rodney King Testifies About Night of Beating
description: Rodney G. King told Federal grand jurors that he did not attack police officers on the night he was beaten and complied with their orders after he stopped his car to end a high-speed pursuit, according to a transcript of the testimony.

title: U.N. Inspectors Fly to Iraq To Destroy Chemical Arms
description: After a standoff with Baghdad and a week of United States attacks on Iraq, a team of United Nations weapons inspectors arrived in the Iraqi capital today.

title: McCann Healthcare Is Reorganizing
description: Keeping up with a trend, McCann Healthcare Advertising in Chicago said yesterday that it would reorganize into two specialized divisions, to focus on consumer health-care communications and global medical advertising.

title: TEXACO INC. (N)
description: Texaco Inc. said its operating results in the fourth quarter were 41 percent better than last year's, though after special items its performance was worse. For the year, operating results were down slightly, because recession softened demand for refined products and the price of oil was substantially lower than the year earlier, when the Perisan Gulf war pushed up prices. After special charges, net income dropped nearly 45 percent for the year.

title: Valero Natural Gas Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: SETTLING IN: Presidential Appointees; 14 Major Clinton Nominees Are Confirmed by Senate
description: The Senate today approved 14 major appointments by President Clinton, including Ronald H. Brown as Commerce Secretary after he agreed to sever all ties to his former law firm and to remove himself from all decisions that might give the appearance of a conflict of interest.

title: Boxing; Among the Leisure Class, Bowe Is Hard at Work
description: In the land of heart-shaped bathtubs and starry-eyed newlyweds, Riddick Bowe is an anomaly in winter: a fighter among lovers, a laborer among the leisurely. He doesn't seem to belong.

title: Market Place; Education Alternatives looks great, but read the fine print.
description: FEW things attract as much attention on Wall Street as soaring revenues. So, when Education Alternatives, a school management and consulting company, reported that its third-quarter earnings jumped by some 900 percent, to more than $5 million, investors took notice.

title: Coaches Who Bred Success in 80's Need New Blueprint for 90's
description: The regular season ended less than a month ago and new coaches have emerged for Chicago, New England and probably New York. Dave Wannstedt, Bill Parcells and maybe Dan Reeves will mean that the National Football League would have 11 new coaches in merely one year.

title: Walsh in a Rules Violation
description: Stanford has reported a National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violation committed by Coach BILL WALSH while on a recruiting visit in Connecticut.

title: Total Petroleum (North America) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and the year included a loss of $ 2.2 million from discontinued operations.

title: INSIDE
description: Hailing a Cab, and a Phone

title: CLINTON CANCELS BAIRD NOMINATION FOR JUSTICE DEPT.
description: President Clinton said early this morning that he was withdrawing the nomination of Zoe Baird as Attorney General. The announcement came after a day of steadily mounting public and political opposition had turned the nomination into Mr. Clinton's first political test on his first day in office.

title: Sysco Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Nynex Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included $ 550 million in charges for force-reduction programs and business restructuring.

title: Robert W. Larkin, 61, A Dance Press Agent
description: Robert W. Larkin, a dance and theatrical press agent, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 61 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Under Standing Orders, U.S. Jets Hit Iraqi Radar Seen as a Threat
description: Two American warplanes, acting under standing orders from the Bush Administration, attacked a radar for an Iraqi surface-to-air missile battery today, after concluding that the radar was directed at allied planes patrolling the northern no-flight zone.

title: On My Mind; What's in It for Us?
description: The ruler of a great power had shown kindness and friendship to a new nation. So its leader wrote a letter of appreciation, and of his country's realities.

title: Marko Rothmuller, 84, Baritone And a Writer of Sephardic Songs
description: Marko Rothmuller, an operatic baritone and composer, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Ind., where he was distinguished professor emeritus of music at Indiana University. He was 84.

title: CHRISTOPHER LEERY OF BOSNIA ACCORD
description: Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher said today that he doubted that the international mediation effort to end the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina would succeed, his spokesman said.

title: Talk of a Smaller Issue Lifts Bonds
description: Treasury prices inched higher yesterday as traders and investors continued to wait to see what the new Clinton Administration would do to stimulate the economy and cut the record Federal budget deficit.

title: Some Small Steps by Byrd Turning Into Giant Leaps
description: Less than two months after suffering a broken neck during a football game, which resulted in his partial paralysis, Jets defensive end Dennis Byrd took his first real steps during a therapy session yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Review/Photography; Making Industrial Buildings Look Like Butterflies
description: With their deadpan photographs of such industrial structures as cooling towers, natural-gas storage tanks and factory facades, Bernd and Hilla Becher have for more than 30 years exercised a great influence on contemporary photography. Three years ago, an extensive retrospective of work by the German couple was held at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea; now a show at the Sonnabend Gallery in SoHo offers updated versions of some of their familiar grid works, as well as a selection of recent single-frame pictures.

title: ANN TAYLOR SETTLES A LAWSUIT FILED BY SHAREHOLDERS
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, the specialty chain that caters to career women, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $2.8 million and some legal fees to settle a lawsuit filed against it, its major investor and two former senior executives. In October 1991, shareholders filed a suit naming Ann Taylor, Merrill Lynch and Joseph Brooks and Thomas Brooks, respectively the former chief executive and president of Ann Taylor. The lawsuit contended that the defendants had misrepresented and omitted pertinent facts about Ann Taylor in its prospectus, in news releases and in statements to the investment community about its business and prospects.

title: Katie Beers's Mother Asks to Cede Financial Control
description: The Suffolk County Attorney should take charge of Katie Beers's financial affairs, including any money she may receive from movie deals, Katie's mother, Marilyn Beers, said today.

description: b-Net income

description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 4 million for discontinued operations.c-Included a gain of $ 30.2 million, or 26 cents a share, resulting from the sale of about 20 percent of First Colony; a charge of $ 6 million for estimated relocation costs in connection with the future transfer of St. Louis employees to Richmond, Va.; and a charge of $ 17.1 million related to accounting changes for postretirement benefits and deferred income taxes.The company also said fourth-quarter earnings reflect an after-tax realized investment gain at the company's 80 percent-owned First Colony Corp. unit of $ 55.6 million, or 47 cents a share, compared with a gain of $ 14.1 million, or 13 cents a share, in the 1991 fourth quarter.

title: Will Razorback Royalty Root Out the Rogues?
description: THE hugging is over. The backstabbing is back.

Before this added cost, the company had operating loss of $ 118.8 million. Also included a gain of $ 14.5 million, or 44 cents a share from the sale of a joint venture interest.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO. (N)
description: The General Electric Company's earnings of $1.34 billion for the fourth quarter of 1992, up 6 percent from a year earlier, were within the range of analysts' predictions, althought toward the lower end of the range.

title: HOME INTENSIVE CARE REJECTS $6-A-SHARE BID BY GRACE
description: Home Intensive Care Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected an offer for the home health-care company of $6 a share, or $93.8 million, from W. R. Grace & Company. Home Intensive Care, of Miami, has 15.6 million shares outstanding. "We think the company is worth more than what Grace offered," said Joann Rushing, a spokeswoman. "Some people in the financial community told us that Grace set a bottom value for the stock by coming in low with an initial offer. We're not aggressively exploring any further sales possibilities at this point." Grace had no comment. Home Intensive's stock, which was trading at $4.375 before Grace's bid, rose 25 cents yesterday, to $6.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CHRONICLE
description: President FRANCOIS MITTERRAND has made JEAN-CLAUDE KILLY, the former Olympic ski champion, a commander of the Legion of Honor, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Jenny Craig reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge on early repayment of debt of $ 6,280,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: At the Bar; HBO's trial of James Earl Ray may stir sensation, but will it produce revelation?
description: Next week in Memphis, the ever-fuzzier line between fact and fiction, justice and show biz, history and entertainment, courtroom and television studio, will be blurred still further. That's when Home Box Office puts James Earl Ray on trial for the 1968 killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

description: Six Mets who underwent surgery during or after last season:

title: If Some Ignore Parcells, The Patriots Surely Don't
description: Twenty months after he suddenly quit the Super Bowl champion Giants, Bill Parcells returned to coaching today to take over the moribund New England Patriots.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the transfer of power in Washington described one of President Clinton's campaign pledges incorrectly in some editions. He promised to cut the budget deficit in four years by half, not by one-quarter.

title: American Express Job
description: Directors of the American Express Company charged with finding a successor to James D. Robinson 3d as chief executive continued their mission yesterday, discussing options in secrecy.

title: Review/Film; Bucharest Mavericks In Love
description: "The Oak" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 1, 1992. The film (in Romanian with English subtitles) opens today at Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, Broadway and 63d Street.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There's the Rhodes scholar connection, the Yale connection, the Little Rock connection. And now, it seems, there's also a Carnegie foundation connection that leads right to the top of the Clinton Administration.

description: Companies

title: Projecting a Rosy Future for Schools
description: Network news departments have a way of alternating between laments over the present condition of America's schools and celebrations of what Peter Jennings tomorrow calls their "glorious future." The latest exercise in optimism, "Common Miracles: The New American Revolution in Learning," is pieced together from "World News Tonight" reports by the ABC News education correspondent, Bill Blakemore.

title: Reconsider Aliens Law in Light of Baird Case; Let Her Measure Up
description: To the Editor:

title: A Debate Unstilled
description: In moving to identify and hospitalize violent mentally ill residents of New York City shelters, state officials are taking a small step to improve coordination in a fragmented, overwhelmed mental health system.

title: Rose Says He Still Gambles
description: PETE ROSE, banned for life from baseball in 1989 because he was gambling on the game, said he was gambling again, The Cincinnati Post reported yesterday.

title: Hillary Clinton Gets Policy Job And New Office
description: Breaking decades of tradition, Hillary Rodham Clinton will set up shop in the West Wing of the White House, alongside the President's senior staff members, where she will help formulate policy on health care and other domestic issues, White House officials said today.

title: Raytheon Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL MOTORS CORP., Detroit, said its Oldsmobile division had cut prices on its compact Achieva by $1,300 and its Eighty-Eight Royale sedan by almost $3,000 to spur sales of its two newest models. AMSOUTH BANCORP., Birmingham, Ala., definitively agreed to pay $93 million of stock for First National Bank of Clearwater, Fla., a unit of closely held Mickler Corp.

title: Three 'Baby Bells' Report Better 4th-Quarter Results
description: Three regional Bell telephone companies reported yesterday that their fourth-quarter results improved. But year-to-year comparisons are difficult to make because of one-time charges for work-force reductions and large noncash charges to cover accounting changes involving retirement benefits.

title: British Air Buys 20% Of USAir
description: British Airways has invested $300 million to buy a 20 percent stake in USAir, the companies said yesterday. The announcement came just a month after the companies had withdrawn a plan for combined operations in the face of objections from United States carriers and the Transportation Department.

title: First Data Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Beirut Chief Says Hostage-Taking And Civil War Are Over for Good
description: Signaling what he termed the emergence of "a Lebanon of peace and reconstruction," Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri said today that he wanted to assure the world that 15 years of civil war in his country "are over for good, and that the kidnapping of foreign nationals and hijacking of aircraft are something of the past."

title: AST Research reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Group Makes Ultra-Thin Chip in the U.S.
description: After five years and $500 million of public and private money, Sematech, the consortium of United States computer chip companies, said yesterday that it had accomplished the first of its goals: using American-made equipment to produce a chip with ultra-thin circuitry.

title: Abroad at Home; The Clinton Doctrine?
description: The classic reason for the use of American military force has been to protect our vital interests. In one pregnant sentence of his Inaugural Address, President Clinton added another.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Matisse Encore With Picasso for Just a Week
description: The great Matisse retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art closed on Tuesday, and the city already seems a dimmer place. But the museum has managed an encore. It has put together, for just a week, a 20th-century-art version of the Dream Team.

title: Figure Skating; Reunited U.S. Pair Captures Crown
description: Calla Urbanski didn't mean to call him a toad.

title: Mayor's Film Office Should Go After Productions for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: "Mr. President, I wanted to tell you I was so excited when I received my call. And I wanted to call my parents. But they aren't talking to me for the last 11 years because I'm a lesbian. I hope your Administration will change that. " -- CHRIS HENRY, one of 3,000 visitors at President Clinton's open house. [ A1:4. ]

title: When Helping Hands Have to Pay Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: LSI Logic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 101,785.c-Net incomed-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 5,626,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Jordan Says No Thanks To the Dream Team II
description: If he had to do it over again, Michael Jordan would have passed on the Olympics last summer. Once the business of the National Basketball Association championship had been taken care of, he would have headed straight to the golf course in Hilton Head, S.C., instead of carrying his clubs from San Diego to Portland to Monte Carlo to Barcelona.

title: From Children's Savings, Neediest Are Enriched
description: The words may be clumsily scrawled, waving and wiggling their way across the thickly lined paper. But the sentiments expressed in these letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are often well formed. The authors are children who are taking their first steps toward assuming responsibility for the less fortunate in their society.

title: Wang Turnaround Artist Quits Work in Progress
description: Richard W. Miller, who has waged an unsuccessful three-year effort to resuscitate Wang Laboratories Inc., surprised the computer industry today by stepping down as chairman and chief executive.

title: Morceli in Wanamaker Mile
description: Algeria's NOUREDDINE MORCELI, the world indoor and outdoor record-holder at 1,500 meters, and Spain's FERMIN CACHO, the 1992 Olympic 1,500-meter champion, have entered the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games Feb. 5 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sonoco Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 25 million in the quarter and year; the year also included a charge of 6 cents a share for the incremental cost of postretirement benefits, a charge of $ 35.5 million related to FAS 106, and a credit of $ 20.1 million relating to FAS 109.Sonoco said that its 1991 results included a gain of 10 cents a share from the sale of Sonoco Graham.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Comdisco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from an accounting adjustment of $ 20,000,000, or 49 cents a share.

title: LIONEL CLOSES A MANHATTAN STORE AS IT STREAMLINES
description: The Lionel Corporation closed its Kiddie City toy store on Broadway at 79th Street in Manhattan this week under its plan to close 40 stores and two regional distribution centers by the end of February. Lionel, which has operated under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since June 1991, declined to discuss its plans beyond stating that after it closes the stores and centers, it will operate 29 stores in markets that include Philadelphia and central New Jersey. The list omitted New York, where two other Kiddie City stores remain open in Manhattan, suggesting that those stores will close as well. Last year, the company, based in Edison, N.J., tried unsuccessfully to merge with another troubled toy retailer, Child World Inc.

title: Books of The Times; A Couple's Story, During Marriage and Beyond
description: Mystery Ride By Robert Boswell 334 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: Seton Hall Team Puts Words Through Hoops
description: HERE'S startling news: Not every student at Seton Hall University plays basketball.

title: Pacific Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bear Stearns Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Children
description: Chinese Folk Artists Asian American Arts Center 26 Bowery Street, at Bayard Street Chinatown (212) 233-2154 Recommended for all ages Sunday

title: Reeves on Golf Course as Giants Hold the Phone
description: If everything goes the way the Giants expect, Dan Reeves will become their head coach, two people in the team's front office said yesterday. But Reeves was on a golf course in southern California yesterday, a contract was not yet signed and nothing seemed likely to be completed before early next week.

title: TV Weekend; Wendy Hiller as Countess With Past
description: Acting can sometimes be a miraculous profession. Wendy Hiller, who was 80 in August, has in the last year or so been doing some of the best work of her distinguished career. And "Masterpiece Theater" on public television has been a chief beneficiary. Earlier this season, there was "The Best of Friends," with John Gielgud and Patrick McGoohan. This Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 there is "The Countess Alice," co-starring Zoe Wanamaker.

title: U S West Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 17 million in the quarter and $ 1,793,400,000 in the year, both from adjustments in accounting.c-Net loss and included a charge of $ 40 million from adoption of an Oregon alternative regulation plan, and after an extraordinary restructuring charge of $ 590 million.d-Net income and included a charge of $ 40 million from adoption of an Oregon alternative regulation plan, and after a extraordinary restructuring charge of $ 590 million.

title: Who Owns The Rights To 'Rite'?
description: In the Walt Disney film "Fantasia," music from Igor Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" accompanies scenes of the creation of the earth, the demise of the dinosaurs and the birth of civilization.

title: Computer Associates International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results for 1991 were restated to reflect the adoption of Software Revenue Recognition.

title: Taxis to Put Telephones In Back Seat
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission decided yesterday to let yellow cabs in New York City begin installing back-seat cellular pay phones, a move that will add convenience for many passengers and safety for cabdrivers.

title: Critic's Notebook; Can Showy Gestures Fill In the Blanks?
description: WHEN Demi Moore paces furiously while talking into a cordless telephone during "A Few Good Men," she takes a big step forward in the name of busy behavior. Aficionados of showy, meaningless gestures have long appreciated both the purposeful walk and the commanding phone call, even before technological progress made it possible for these two maneuvers to be combined into such mega-bluster.

title: The Costs of a Savings; Retirement Incentives Ease Strain on School Budgets at Expense of Continuity in Class
description: Eugene Frank's class was just wading into a discussion of Holden Caulfield and his relevance for modern teen-agers when the bell rang and Mr. Frank had to say goodbye to his students -- forever.

title: 9 Orchestras Face a Strike By Musicians
description: The freelance musicians who make up nine of New York City's orchestras might strike at midnight if an agreement is not reached in contract negotiations that begin today at 2 P.M., a spokeswoman for Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians said yesterday. The musicians' contract expired on Sept. 8, and they have been performing on an extension that expires tomorrow.

title: Athens Journal; Coping With a Rumor That Could Be Ruinous
description: The streets are clean, the fences mended and the leaves raked on the lawns of the Greek Revival homes that line the historic district here. Not surprisingly, residents of Athens, a city of 17,000 people in north-central Alabama, take the notion of civic responsibility seriously.

title: Japanese Stocks Fall
description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei average of 225 issues lost 201.87 points, or nearly 1.22 percent, to 16,336.81. On Thursday, the Nikkei gained 28.50 points.

title: Joseph A. Albertson, 86, Creator Of 651-Store Supermarket Chain
description: Joseph A. Albertson, who took a chance on an Idaho grocery store more than half a century ago and parlayed it into one of the nation's largest supermarket chains, died Wednesday night at his home in Boise. He was 86.

title: Popeye's Is Moved To Fitzgerald
description: America's Favorite Chicken yesterday named Fitzgerald & Company in Atlanta to handle the national advertising account for its Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits chain. The account, with billings estimated to exceed $5 million, was previously handled by Garfield, Linn & Company in Chicago.

title: Martin Marietta reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charges of $ 122 million associated with force reduction programs. Without the charge, 1991 fourth-quarter earnings would have been $ 280 million, or 71 cents a share.

title: 8 Broadway Theaters Join Alliance to Cut Ticket Costs
description: A major expansion of the Broadway Alliance, the two-year-old plan to produce plays at low cost to bring reduced ticket prices to Broadway's darkened theaters, was announced yesterday by Broadway's theater owners and the major theatrical unions.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "SPIC-O-RAMA," Westside Theater, 407 West 43d Street, Manhattan. A one-man show with John Leguizamo; directed by Peter Askin. Through Sunday. Performances: today and tomorrow at 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets, $30. Information: (212) 307-4100; 315-2244.

title: Art in Review
description: David Hockney Andre Emmerich Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through Feb. 13

title: Colleges; Its Good Deeds Aside, N.C.A.A. Is a Culprit
description: Bonnie Frankel has a cold, an "emotional cold," she thinks, from watching herself become a heroic symbol, so she probably won't jump into the swimming pool until tomorrow at the earliest. Joan of Arc was burned for following her inner voice, so Frankel, who is not put off by the comparison, is willing to wait a few more days to get wet.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Wednesday about the earnings of the Chemical Banking Corporation misstated the change in its net income for all of 1992, compared with 1991. Chemical's earnings rose sevenfold, to $1.09 billion last year from $154 million in 1991.

title: Jordan Sends Taunts And Teases Nets' Way
description: He is Michael Jordan, basketball superman, and last night he prepared himself to do battle against mere mortals from New Jersey by imagining them to be a serious threat to his no fly zone.

title: Moynihan Sorts Out U.S. Prosecutor Candidates
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan is moving swiftly to recommend nominees for two of the nation's most visible law-enforcement jobs -- the United States Attorney posts in Manhattan and Brooklyn -- as the first Democratic President in 12 years prepares to put his stamp on the country's justice system.

title: Supercomputer Maker May Lose I.B.M. Aid
description: The bold crusade of Steve S. Chen to build the world's fastest supercomputer may be nearing an end because his major partner, I.B.M., is backing out, several people familiar with the project say.

title: A Shakeout Is Under Way For Japanese Chip Makers
description: Japanese companies took over the computer memory chip market in the 1980's by withstanding heavy losses that drove most American companies out of the business. Now the losses are becoming too heavy even for some Japanese companies, and a shakeout is beginning here.

title: MONSANTO CO. (N)
description: A one-time gain enabled the Monsanto Company to post fourth-quarter net income of $141 million, or $1.14 a share. The gain came on the sale of Monsanto's Fisher Controls International, a manufacturer of automated valves, for $554 million, or $4.49 a share.

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: Total assets of the nation's 609 retail money market mutual funds decreased $675.1 million, to $386.65 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Thousands Show Up to Greet White House's New Tenants
description: They wandered around the Rose Garden in blue jeans and business suits, furs and frayed jackets, tight running pants and tight party dresses, and they peered through the window of the Oval Office even before President Clinton got there. Most called their host "Mr. President," though many greeted him as "sir," and a few blurted, "Hi, Bill!"

title: Uncovered Short Sales Decline 8% on Big Board
description: The figures on short interest are closely watched on Wall Street as a gauge of investor sentiment, since they reflect the activities of professional traders who specialize in ferreting out companies whose stock price they believe is in for a fall. The sellers borrow shares of these companies and sell them, betting that they will be able to buy the shares back at a lower price and profit from the difference. Amex Also Down

title: Editorial Notebook; Old News from Albany
description: Here's an educated guess from a former Albany resident: Many people who work in New York's state capital still don't understand why two legislators apologized to an Assemblywoman who complained of sexual harassment. I can hear them now, the Albany regulars, asking each other: Apologize? What for? Those two guys were just kidding around, flirting. Where's the harm?

title: Imperial Oil Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net after-tax charge of $ 5 million and $ 63 million for the quarter and year, respectively.c-Net lossd-Included a net after-tax charge of $ 35 million in the quarter and a net after-tax gain of $ 72 million in the year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Film; Friendly Aliens And Other Creatures
description: Dan Curtis's "In Advance of the Landing," opening today at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is a feature-length documentary about people in the United States and Canada who have taken rides in unidentified flying objects, have talked to space aliens, are preparing to welcome such aliens to earth or simply daydream about them. Mr. Curtis, the film's producer and director, takes a very benign view of his subjects. Though if he doesn't send them up, it's probably because he knows he doesn't have to.

title: Outside of Alternative Radio, Who's Heard of Mojo Nixon?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Events column in The Home Section yesterday about a talk by Philip Zimmerman, on the New-York Historical Society's furniture collection, misstated the location. The talk, on Tuesday at 6 P.M., will be at Christie's, 502 Park Avenue (59th Street).

title: Champion International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 454 million from cumulative adjustment for accounting changes.c-Net incomeCorrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Large Group of Monitors Is Planned for Haiti, a U.N. Official Says
description: The special envoy to Haiti from the United Nations and the Organization of American States said today that the two organizations will dispatch a large contingent of human-rights monitors to the country in about 10 days, even though questions persist about whether the military-backed Government will allow them in.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8 PESSIMISM ABOUT BOSNIA TALKS

title: DPL Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Paris Journal; It's a Little Late, but Still, Bouquets for Louis XVI
description: With the French tricolor flying at full-staff as if to signal the Republic's official indifference to the occasion, about 5,000 true-blue royalists gathered in the Place de la Concorde this morning to commemorate the exact moment 200 years ago when King Louis XVI was beheaded.

title: The Art Market; New Mood at Antiques Show
description: COMPETITION is healthy. At least it seems to have made a difference at this year's Winter Antiques Show, which opens to the public tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan and runs through Jan. 31. For most of its 39 years, the event has been something of an institution on the antiques circuit, but in recent seasons this decidedly American show had become overridden with boring brown furniture, banal objects and works of dubious provenance.

title: Upturn Continues in Most Areas, Fed Reports
description: With the notable exception of California, the economy showed continued improvement in December and early January, with sizable gains in retail sales augmented by better activity in factories and residential construction, a survey published today by the Federal Reserve Board said.

title: Mismanagement Cited In New York Agencies
description: The managements of the New York City Fire and Sanitation Departments have not kept up with the changing reality of their missions and are wasting tens of millions of dollars a year, a private group that monitors the city's budget contended yesterday.

title: Train Station Arouses Fears and a Plan to Allay Them
description: Lisa Zarkower has used the dilapidated railroad station in South Norwalk for more than two years, but she has never felt comfortable there.

title: Stock Picks Plagued by Leaks
description: Brokerage firms try hard to guard against the leaking of information about coming stock picks. But trading on such leaks, known as "front running" in the securities business, appears to be a recurring problem at Raymond James & Associates, a high-profile and flourishing regional brokerage firm, according to internal company memorandums.

title: Tijuana Flood Victims In a Political Bog, Too
description: The pounding rains have ended and the floodwaters have begun to recede, and after two weeks of storms that left at least 28 people dead and more than 5,000 homeless, the sun has begun slowly to dry this border city.

title: The Mets in 1993? Get a Second Opinion
description: There is at once blind denial and blunt honesty about the 1992 season. Forget it, the Mets tell themselves one moment. Never forget it, they say to themselves in the next breath. It is one very confused self-help clinic out at Shea Stadium these days.

Still Reeling From Hurricane, Louisiana Is Hit With Floods
description: Still recovering from the effects of Hurricane Andrew's destructive winds, low-lying areas of South Louisiana have been swamped by widespread flooding after heavy rains this week.

title: Big Pension Fund Prodding 12 Companies
description: Flexing its $71 billion muscles, the California Public Employees Retirement System released the names of 12 companies today in which it holds large blocks of stock and whose management it wants to see improved in 1993.

First Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Thursday about President Clinton's saxophone-playing at an inaugural ball misidentifed the musician clapping to the left of Mr. Clinton. He was Everette Harp, not Joe Henderson.

title: The Lesson of Zoe Baird
description: They didn't understand, the powerful who lead the country. Bill Clinton and his advisers, who promised a departure from the old ways of go-along Washington, didn't get it. Neither did Joseph Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Separated by some invisible shield from the feelings of everyday Americans, they were unprepared for the angry public reaction to Zoe Baird's revelation that she knowingly violated the law by hiring illegal immigrants. Astonishingly, neither Mr. Clinton nor his talent scouts understood just how seriously Americans took his promise to hold his appointees to the highest standards.

title: Observer; The Generation Excess
description: The papers say a new generation has come to power. It is tempting to smile at a pomposity. Nowadays new generations come along more often than the Ninth Avenue bus. It's inevitable that a few will wind up in power.

title: Review/Dance; Martha Graham Dancers as Choreographers
description: Eight members of the Martha Graham Dance Company presented their own choreography on Thursday night, and three aspects of the evening stood out sharply.

title: Yves Saint Laurent's Buyer Scurries to Calm Investors
description: Executives of Elf Sanofi, the French pharmaceuticals group, are scurrying to calm the furor here over the company's acquisition of the Yves Saint Laurent fashion house this week.

title: Corrections
description: The real estate column yesterday about subsidized housing misidentified the architect of an affordable-housing project in Long Beach, L.I. He is Leslie Feder.

Also included a $ 17 million, or 19 cents a share, credit to income tax expense as a result of an Internal Revenue Service settlement which allows the company to recognize additional deductions for tax purposes.

title: New Appeals to Pocketbook Patriots
description: By the standards of respectable economic thinking, people like William Lynott are dismissed as well-meaning but misguided eccentrics whose ideas come from the Rush Limbaugh-Patrick Buchanan school of economics.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball National Basketball Association

title: SETTLING IN: Anatomy of a Doomed Nomination; The Baird Appointment: In Trouble From the Start, Then a Firestorm
description: Thursday evening, on the second day of Zoe Baird's confirmation hearings to be the nation's first woman to hold the post of Attorney General, the Senate majority leader and the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee interrupted the proceedings to place an urgent call to the White House.

title: Fleecing the Public, Faster
description: Count two more states as culprits in the rush to expand state-sponsored gambling. New York and New Jersey are both on the verge of launching new electronic games to fatten the take from their lotteries. That's how politicians avoid unpopular tax hikes and spending cuts, no matter that it casts the government in the role of pickpocket.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: An Image That Launches Sponsorships
description: Nancy Kerrigan is very publicly adorned with a Seiko watch. She is nurtured by Campbell's and clothed in black Lycra by the designer Vera Wang.

title: Unifi Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Included charge of $ 24,805,000 for merger expenses.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICA WEST AIRLINES INC., Phoenix, is planning to pool its resources with Aeromexico on two routes linking Phoenix and Mexico. INGALLS SHIPBUILDING, Pascagoula, Miss., a unit of Litton Industries, received a $340 million Navy contract to build an Aegis guided-missile destroyer.

title: No Credit Left, Post Demands 20% Pay Cuts
description: The New York Post, which has operated for years on the brink of extinction, plunged into a new survival crisis yesterday. Short of cash, its bank credit cut off, the newspaper said it would suspend publication as early as Monday unless its 720 employees took a temporary 20 percent pay cut.

title: Paying for Health, The German Way -- A special report.; Medical Care in Germany: With Choices, and for All
description: If the most critical problem in providing national health care is getting control over rapidly rising costs, as President Clinton has often said, he may find some intriguing ideas in the German health care system, which offers coverage to all at a much lower price than Americans pay.

title: Russia and Partners Meet, But Unity Still Eludes Them
description: Leaders of the Commonwealth of Independent States met today in the Belarus capital, Minsk, for a summit meeting that once again failed to give real shape or purpose to the association that emerged 13 months ago as the successor to the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Accuses Angolan Rebel of Inciting Civil War
description: The Clinton Administration today accused Jonas Savimbi, an Angolan rebel leader once closely allied with the United States, of escalating the civil war in Angola and urged him to take part in a new round of United Nations-sponsored peace talks.

title: Police Bullet Hits Sergeant
description: A police sergeant was injured last night in Queens when another officer fired at a robbery suspect and struck the sergeant instead, the police said. The sergeant, Gerald Corrigan, 30, was grazed on the back of his head and was not seriously injured, said Sgt. Ed Burns, a police spokesman. The injured officer was treated last night at Bellevue Hospital. The shooting occurred at 8:43 P.M., when the sergeant and two police officers confronted two men who emerged on the fourth-floor landing of 43-28 39th Place, in Sunnyside, where a robbery had been reported, Sgt. Burns said. One suspect was taken into custody, and the other escaped, he said. Two handguns were recovered.

title: The Abortion Tide Turns
description: With a few strokes of a pen yesterday, President Clinton discarded five Federal policies that both traduced tolerance and infringed freedom. By doing so, he gave his new Administration a wise and humane start.

title: Anthem Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOBIL CORP. (N)
description: In the fourth quarter of 1992, the company took $69 million in special charges, including $49 million for restructuring; in the prior year it took a $12 million benefit. For the quarter, operating income was up by half compared with the similar 1991 period. Allen E. Murray, Mobil's chairman, noted that the increase came despite a drop in world crude oil prices of about 75 cents a barrel.

title: As Redgrave Teaches, The Audience Is a Jury
description: The body in question was Edward Plantagenet, Prince of Wales, slain in battle by Richard III. Rebekah Slotnick, a senior in the drama department of Adelphi University on Long Island, was having trouble, as Edward's widow, dealing with the corpse. Wouldn't the natural reaction be one of revulsion at the cold flesh?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 6 about Bill and Hillary Clinton's choice of Sidwell Friends School in Washington for Chelsea Clinton referred incorrectly to another Quaker school in some editions. That school, Germantown Friends School, is in Philadelphia.

title: Beliefs
description: Once the phrase was uttered, it ran like a mantra around the table of guests on the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" on Wednesday. The inaugural festivities, they repeated, were the nation's great "secular holiday."

title: National Convenience Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 168.1 million primarily related to restructuring.

title: Smith (A.O.) Corp. (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $ 1.6 million from the adoption of FASB 106, covering post-retirement benefits, and also a one-time, non-cash charge of $ 46,122,000 related to the adoption of FASB 106.c-Net incomeThe results are after preferred dividends.

title: Moscow String Quartet
description: The Moscow String Quartet is to present a concert at 8 tonight at Washington Irving High School, East 16th Street at Irving Place, Gramery Park. The program includes Mozart's Quartet in D (K. 575); Schnittke's Quartet No. 2, and Tchaikovsky's Quartet No. 2. Tickets are $3.50. Information: (212) 586-4680.

title: Haggar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Island of Lost Souls? No, but the Talk of the Mall.; Spate of Highly Publicized Crimes Leaves Many Asking What's Got Into Long Island
description: On Long Island, in the same suburbs that for decades have been considered prototypes of security, wealth and tranquillity, now comes the macabre.

title: The Red Light Goes On, But It's Over the Exit
description: After undergoing surgery seven times on his left shoulder and twice each on his right shoulder and right knee, TIM KERR has finally surrendered.

title: It's Not Just Zoe Baird
description: There's an old saying in Chicago politics that comes to mind in the wake of the Zoe Baird debacle. "We don't want nobody nobody sent," the ward heelers used to grumble. Translation: If you don't stand for somebody, stay home.

title: Gibson Stays With Mets
description: Left-handed relief pitcher PAUL GIBSON has signed a minor league contract with the Mets and will report to spring training with the team's other pitchers and catchers on Feb. 18.

title: PNC FINANCIAL BUYS PITTSBURGH OFFICE BUILDING
description: Pressed for space and leery of leasing, the PNC Financial Corporation has bought an office building near its headquarters for $63.25 million. The 34-story office at Two Oliver Plaza is next door to the company's headquarters, in the heart of Pittsburgh's corporate and financial district. Thomas O'Brien, chairman and chief executive of PNC,, the nation's 13th-largest bank holding company, with 550 community banking offices in five states, said the purchase made sense financially. PNC outgrew its 535,000-square-foot headquarters, built in 1971, and in recent years had leased office space around the city to accommodate workers.

title: Croatia's Army Launches Attacks on Serb-Held Lands
description: Croatia's army launched attacks on territory held by breakaway Serbs near the port city of Zadar today in an action that threatens to destroy a year-old United Nations cease-fire for Croatia and sour peace talks on Bosnia and Herzegovina set to resume in Geneva on Saturday.

title: Review/Film; A Grandmaster Who Plays Cat and Mouse. Your Move.
description: Carl Schenkel's thriller, "Knight Moves," which opened yesterday, is a film that should do nothing but enhance the image of professional chess as a sport for lunatics. Or as Peter Sanderson (Christopher Lambert), the main character, puts itdarkly in one of the film's many howlers, "Chess is a reflection of the world, and the world is violent."

title: Review/Music; Penderecki Returns to a Style He Overthrew
description: Every period in history, no matter how brief, summons an artist or two to explain its feelings. Krzystof Penderecki's "Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima" and "Polymorphia" ushered in the 1960's as if the product of some unspoken commission. They and other pieces by the Polish composer became instantly famous. Where many composers had sought to reduce the uncertainties of a nuclear age to stringent counterpoint and rigorous organization, Mr. Penderecki embraced cold-war anxiety with a metaphor of his own.

title: Apartments for the Homeless Are Left Vacant in New York
description: While scores of homeless families spend night after night on chairs and tables in the offices of the city's welfare agency, hundreds of apartments that have been set aside as permanent housing for the homeless have been standing empty, often for months at a time.

title: IBM Canada Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 165 million pre-tax provision to cover the costs of restructuring measures announced by the parent company in December.c-Net loss and included a charge of about $ 200 million related to restructuring.Results are in Canadian dollars.IBM Canada is a unit of International Business Machines Corp.

title: McDonnell Douglas Plans 4,000 New Layoffs; Stock Jumps
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced another 4,000 layoffs today at its commercial aircraft unit, where production has dropped sharply.

title: Fans and Devils Take Hats Off to Holik
description: As long as Bobby Holik kept his arms and his stick raised in celebration, the hats kept coming on all parts of the ice tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was only the second time such a scene occurred here this season and Holik was at center stage both times.

title: Valassis Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago periods are pro forma because the company first went public in March 1992.The year-ago periods included a one-time foreign exchange gain of $ 4.2 million.

title: F.B.I. Chief Insists He'll Stay Although Support Is Fading
description: A day after the White House sent him an unmistakable signal of its disfavor, William S. Sessions said today that he would not step down from his job as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: New Iraqi Site Raided as White House Vows Firmness
description: For the second time in its two days in office, the Clinton Administration used military force against Iraq today, attacking an antiaircraft missile site in the north. It also vowed to continue a tough policy against President Saddam Hussein.

title: How Stockbrokers Use The Tricks of the Trade
description: ALONG with other troubles coming to light about operations at the Raymond James & Associates brokerage firm are some of the company's questionable sales practices. They should give investors helpful lessons in how securities are sold at Raymond James and many other brokerage houses.

title: Judge Blocks New Rules On Emissions
description: A Federal judge today blocked the adoption of stringent automobile emissions standards that would have required the production of cleaner cars sold in New York State by 1995.

title: Charlie Gehringer, 89, a Hall of Famer for Detroit
description: Charlie Gehringer, the unassuming Detroit Tiger whose .320 career batting average was quietly overshadowed by his reputation as one of baseball's most accomplished second basemen, died on Thursday at a nursing home near his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: Willamette Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Thursday about the National Arts Club's awarding a medal of honor to Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn misstated the author's policy on accepting honors in person. Mr. Solzhenitsyn accepted honorary degrees from Harvard University in 1978, when he also gave a commencement address, from the College of the Holy Cross in 1984 and from Dartmouth College in 1991. He also accepted the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion in London in 1983.

title: Micropolis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 930,000 in connection with the settlement of the company's class-action lawsuits.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: N. H. Strouse, Chairman, 86, Of Ad Agency
description: Norman H. Strouse, who started as a secretary in a newspaper advertising office and became the head of the world's largest ad agency, died on Tuesday at a hospital in St. Helena, Calif. He was 86 and lived in St. Helena.

title: It Isn't Head Coach Reeves Just Yet
description: Dan Reeves remained on a golfing vacation in California yesterday, but he still seemed on course to become the next coach of the Giants. The question was when, and there were mixed signals.

title: Insight; A Sign of Zeal
description: Borrowing to purchase Big Board stocks quietly rose 20 percent last year. Margin debt stood at $43.99 billion in December, theatening the record of $44.17 billion set in September 1987, the month before the crash. To Richard Eakle, a money manager, it's a sure sign of speculative zeal, with the popular technology stocks among the most vulnerable.

title: Continental Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Washington Mutual Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 4,638,000.The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Irwin Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec. 30, 1991, and a 2-for-1 split effective Sept. 2, 1992.

title: Meridian Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 6.5 million from the company's discontinued title insurance operations, and included an after-tax gain of $ 26.8 million, or 64 cents a fully diluted share, on the sale of Meridian's credit card portfolio.Per share earnings are fully diluted.Meridian Bancorp said that earnings per share were affected by an increase of 3.3 million in average shares outstanding between the two years primarily because of the sale of common stock in September 1991.The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Too Many Specialists
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Philadelphia Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: Leetch Trying to Reach Out But It's Still Just Too Painful
description: Brian Leetch woke this morning in his Santa Monica hotel room and stretched his left arm out from under the sheets. He flexed, he wiggled, he tried to lift a few things off the night stand nearby.

title: Testimony Changed in Sex Assault Case
description: A former defendant, now testifying for the defense in the Glen Ridge sex assault case, today disavowed a major element in the sworn statement he made to a judge last year in pleading guilty. He then proceeded to add details to his earlier account of one phase of the incident.

title: Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: Many tournament players conduct a post-mortem after the play is complete, comparing the scores with their estimates and trying to discover whether they could have done better. For winners there is a slight risk in this, as an episode at the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y., a week ago demonstrates.

title: Strength of Big Issues Lifts Dow 3.79, to 3,256.81
description: Invigorating economic news lifted the industrial heavyweights high enough yesterday for the stock market to finish with narrow gains.

title: Released From Care, Jean Harris is Freed
description: Jean S. Harris regained her freedom last night after 12 years in prison for killing her lover, Dr. Herman Tarnower. She was released directly from a hospital in Westchester County where she was recovering from heart surgery.

title: PNC Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included an extraordinary charge of 46 cents a share from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle for post-retirement benefits.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORP. (N)
description: The company also benefited from a strong performance by Telefonos de Mexico, the Mexican national carrier in which Southwestern Bell owns a 10 percent stake. Mexico, which adjoins Southwestern Bell's main territory of Texas, has been growing rapidly.

title: Reynolds & Reynolds reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $ 1.1 million, or 5 cents a share, and was restated to reflect adoption of Statement of Federal Accounting Standard 109 relating to accrual of deferred income taxes.

description: In percent

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Delay in Martin Marietta's Purchase of G.E. Unit
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said yesterday that completion of its pending acquisition of the General Electric Company's Aerospace division had been delayed a month, partly because of Government antitrust concerns. But the company said it was planning to complete the transaction by April 1.

title: Hibernia Savings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Jury Panelists Asked Views on Abortion
description: In an unusual prelude to an unusual trial, lawyers asked prospective jurors this week about their attitudes toward abortion, in the case of a Lower East Side doctor accused of attempting an illegal third-trimester abortion that severed the arm of a fetus who was born the next day.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY ROOMS FOR HOMELESS AVAILABLE AND EMPTY

title: New-Home Starts Rose Last Month
description: Builders broke ground for new homes in December at a pace 5.5 percent faster than in November, the Government said today, ending a year in which housing starts posted their first advance since 1986.

description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.
