description: Sylvan Winds Weill Recital Hall

title: Lifetime's Work, Tested and True
description: IN the late afternoon of last Aug. 30, Eileen Egan, who has spent most of her almost 80 years in the advocacy and practice of nonviolence, was attacked in Manhattan.

title: Bell Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share results are not applicable because the bank went public in December 1991.

title: Edward J. Ross, 80, a Lawyer Involved in Rothko Estate Case
description: Edward J. Ross, a lawyer in the case that pitted the estate of Mark Rothko against the Marlborough Gallery in the 1970's, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Say They Hired Illegal Aliens
description: Two candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey said today that they had employed undocumented aliens.

title: GFC Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 4,107,000, or 20 cents per share, in the quarter and $ 12,207,000, or 60 cents per share, in the year.c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 13,729,000 in both the quarter and year.

title: Chester Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Film; Behind a Hotel Desk, Dreaming of Adventure
description: For anyone who has ever dreamed of being a hotel desk clerk, "Hexed" describes the comic adventures of Matthew Welsh (Arye Gross), clerk extraordinaire. Matthew's Mittyesque life is filled with far-fetched escapades, since he enjoys borrowing clothes and cars from other parts of the hotel and masquerading as a man about town.

title: Union Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included special third quarter charge of $ 870 million, before tax, ($ 575 million after tax), related to operational restructurings, principally at Union Pacific Railroad. Excluding the charge, net income would have been $ 639 million, or $ 3.16 a share, for the 1991 year.

title: World Bank Keeps Improving Its Approach; How I.M.F. Helps
description: To the Editor:

title: A New York Premiere
description: The Cleveland Quartet is to perform the New York premiere of Libby Larsen's "Schoenberg, Schenker and Schillinger" in a concert at 3 P.M. tomorrow in Alice Tully Hall. Ms. Larsen's three-part quartet reflects the points of view of the three influential 20th-century music theorists for whom the work was named. Also on the program are Schubert's Quartet in A minor and Dvorak's Quartet in A flat. The quartet's members are William Preucil and Peter Salaff, violinists; James Dunham, violist, and Paul Katz, cellist. Tickets are $22. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about "The Boys Choir of Harlem and Friends" at the Richard Rodgers Theater misidentified the reader of a poem after an unannounced program change. Maya Angelou's poem "Still I Rise" was read at a preview on Saturday night by Robert Jason Jackson, not Richard Lawson.

title: BRENDLE'S SAYS IT WILL CLOSE 8 OF ITS STORES
description: Brendle's Inc. said yesterday that it would close eight of its low-performing stores in the next couple of months as part of a reorganization. The company has already filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Some of the 302 employees in these stores will be relocated, but most will be laid off, the discount retailer said. Five stores will be closed in Virginia, one in North Carolina and two in South Carolina. There will be clearance sales in the stores to close out inventories.

title: Nominee for Pentagon Aided Buildup of Iraq
description: The likely nomination to a senior Pentagon post of an official who helped shape the Bush Administration's policy of aiding Iraq before the Persian Gulf war is causing deep concern among Senate Democrats, staff aides said today.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus Leaps to a Record
description: Japan said today that its trade surplus with the United States jumped 14 percent last year, as its surplus with the entire world reached a record high.

title: Briggs & Stratton reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are based on 14,463,500 shares outstanding.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC. (N)
description: Mr. Junkins said the company increased its capital-spending budget for 1993 to $625 million, from $429 million, mainly for chip-making equipment. Research spending also will be higher and will include several new ventures, including digital imaging.

title: Who Is Meal Ticket?
description: GEORGE FOREMAN is hungry for one more heavyweight title shot, and Lennox Lewis has offered to defend the W.B.C. championship against Big George. So when will they break bread and make an agreement?

title: BOEING AWARDED CONTRACT BY THE AIR FORCE
description: The Boeing Company received a $290.8 million contract from the Air Force to test the Awacs Electronic Support Measures systems and upgrade 18 NATO E-3A aircraft, the Pentagon said yesterday. The contract, awarded on Tuesday by the Electronic Systems Center of Hanscom Air Force Base in Massachusetts, is expected to be completed in December 1995. Under the contract, Boeing is responsible for testing the system for the NATO mission simulator No. 2 in Germany, the Government said. The Seattle-based aerospace company will also produce and test the NATO E-3A Modification Block 1 systems for 18 aircraft. In addition, Boeing will upgrade two E-3A mission simulators.

title: Canbra Foods reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a pre-tax write-off of deferred expenditures of $ 4,375,000.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Andrew Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Review/Music; When All Is Synthesis, There Are No Categories
description: The composer Alfred Schnittke commented not long ago: "Contemporary reality will make it necessary to experience all the music one has heard since childhood, including rock and jazz and classical and all other forms, as a synthesis." That reality is taking hold. In the last decade, a fair number of composers have found a language that entirely defeats categorization by genre. The music heard at the Kitchen on Saturday night, closing a series devoted to "Gruppen: Chamber Music for the 21st Century," displayed persuasive evidence of the continuing synthesis.

title: ADVO Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Sixers Can't Handle Knicks' One-Two Punch
description: There are many nights when John Starks provides a spark for the Knicks. Tonight, it was more like a bolt of lightning.

title: GPA GROUP OFFERS A PLAN TO ITS CREDITORS
description: The embattled Irish aircraft leasing company GPA Group P.L.C. took another step to restore its financial health yesterday by giving creditors a three-point restructuring plan. GPA, founded as Guinness Peat Aviation, has been battered since 1990 by a slowdown in world aviation as airlines reported huge losses and the value of used aircraft plunged. In broad terms, the refinancing package, which may be wrapped up by late February, aims to cut GPA's $5.5 billion of debt in half in the three years ending March 1996, said a GPA official close to the deal who insisted on anonymity.

title: U.S. Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 7,780,000 on an accounting change, which reflected the cumulative effect on prior periods of the adoption of FASB 109 and FASB 106.The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Breast Implant Report Was Premature
description: To the Editor:

title: Still a Boys' Club
description: The new female members of the House, Democratic and Republican, have agreed to work to make Congress abide by the same civil rights laws that most Americans obey -- laws that Senators and Representatives passed for everyone but themselves.

title: KnowledgeWare Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Munis: Popular, Tax Free and Tricky
description: With as much as $15 billion worth of municipal bonds being redeemed this month by the states, cities and public authorities that sold them, and almost $7 billion worth of new municipal bond issues coming to market, many investors are focusing their attention on these tax-exempt securities.

title: SETTLING IN: The Overview; Clinton Concedes He Erred on Baird Nomination
description: President Clinton acknowledged today that he had made a mistake in rushing through Zoe Baird's selection as Attorney General. He conceded that he had not fully reviewed her hiring of illegal aliens, even though his aides informed him in general of the legal violation before he announced his choice.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: Someone on my staff had said, 'Oh, this is a parking ticket.' I said: 'It is not. It's a freeway crash.' -- SENATOR JOSEPH R. BIDEN JR., on Zoe Baird's employment of illegal aliens. [ 8:2. ]

title: SETTLING IN: The Armed Services; Joint Chiefs Fighting Clinton Plan To Allow Homosexuals in Military
description: In an angry challenge to the Administration's promise to lift the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces, the Joint Chiefs of Staff are fighting to persuade President Clinton to reverse his campaign pledge, senior military officials said today.

title: Review/Ice Skating; Champions in a Display of Patriotism
description: Some 20 minutes after the announced starting time for the Ice Capades on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, Christopher Bowman, a star of the show, asked: "How about seeing just a little bit of skating right now? Does that sound good?"

title: C.H.S.A.A. Wants Everyone to Ride the Local
description: When Rice and St. Raymond play each other tonight at Iona College, one question should be settled: which of New York's two top-ranked high school basketball teams is the best.

title: BancTexas Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said the improved results are primarily due to an increase in net interest margin of $ 3.4 million and a one time reversal of an expense accrual of $ 600,000 booked in a previous year.

title: WAL-MART BOARD DECLARES A 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the largest retailer in the United States, said yesterday that its board had declared a 2-for-1 stock split, its first since July 1990. The company will issue a 100 percent stock dividend Feb. 25 to shareholders of record on Feb. 2. Wal-Mart has about 1.15 billion shares outstanding. Shares of Wal-Mart closed up $3.125, or 5 percent, at $62.625 on volume of nearly 4 million shares. The stock was the seventh-most-active issue on the U.S. Composite, even though trading was halted for nearly 30 minutes.

title: Sealed Air Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a stock dividend in September 1992.

description: New Crisis at New York Post

title: 20-Year Term Asked in Exxon Kidnapping
description: Federal prosecutors have recommended a 20-year prison sentence for Irene J. Seale, half of the maximum sentence she could have received for participating with her husband, Arthur, in the fatal kidnapping of an Exxon official, Sidney J. Reso.

title: Valero Natural Gas Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: InaCom Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: InaCom Corp. said the increase in revenues for the year reflected a complete year with the Inacomp Computer Centers channel, after the August 1991 merger of ValCom and Inacomp.The company attributed the latest-quarter revenue gains to an increase in customer demand for products from major manufacturers, which account for the vast majority of InaCom hardware sales.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Citizens Banking reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 1,947,000, or 30 cents a share, which included an after-tax curtailment gain of $ 2,965,000, or 45 cents a share, for an accounting change, an after-tax charge of $ 955,000 for restructuring Citizens leasing subsidiary, and a minor increase in postretirement benefit expense. The restructuring charge represents costs associated with the closing of certain offices and a writedown of goodwill and business related assets.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 11,753,000 which included an after-tax curtailment gain of $ 2,965,000, or 45 cents a share, for an accounting change for adoption of FAS 106, a one-time after-tax charge of $ 12,905,000 which was recognized retroactively in the first quarter, and an after-tax increase of $ 795,000 in postretirement expense.The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Queens Man Kills Wife And 2 Girls, Police Say
description: An unemployed garment worker from Queens fatally stabbed and bludgeoned his wife and two young daughters on Thursday, telling the police that voices had warned him they would be tortured if he did not kill them before the Chinese New Year, the authorities said yesterday.

title: SOROS GROUP HOLDS A 5.2% STAKE IN BECKMAN
description: An investor group that includes George Soros holds a 5.2 percent stake in the common stock of Beckman Instruments, a Fullerton, Calif., maker of medical instruments. Mr. Soros owns Soros Fund Management, the principal investment adviser to the Quantum mutual fund. Purnendu Chatterjee, manager of Winston Partners in New York City and an adviser to Mr. Soros, also bought Beckman Instruments shares this month, according to a filing yeaterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission. Earlier this month, the S.E.C. said that Mr. Chatterjee had passed nonpublic information about an impending acquisition of the Foxboro Company to two other persons. Mr. Chatterjee, Mr. Soros and Quantum own more than 1.4 million Beckman shares, according to the filing. Beckman's stock rose 50 cents a share yesterday, to $24.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When MIDORI, the 21-year-old violinist who already has 10 years of performing with the New York Philharmonic on her resume, returns to New York on Monday from a tour abroad, she won't be giving blockbuster concerts.

title: Chief of F.B.I. Says He Will Not Resign
description: A day after the White House sent him an unmistakable signal of its disfavor, William S. Sessions said in an interview that he would not step down as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Tarkanian to Rest
description: The former Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach JERRY TARKANIAN says he may have suffered a slight heart attack recently and won't be taking any kind of a job this year.

description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 1,586,000 from the write-down of plant facilities and a $ 2,416,000 non-cash after-tax charge from the adoption of an accounting change for post-retirement benefits.c-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: World Bank Keeps Improving Its Approach

title: 9 Orchestras Go on Strike
description: The freelance musicians who make up nine of New York City's smaller orchestras went on strike just before midnight last night, when the orchestras and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians were unable to reach an agreement on a new contract, said Leonard Leibowitz, the lawyer for the musicians. The players had voted last week to authorize their negotiating committee to strike.

title: Review/Film; The Difficulties of Life On Aspen's Ski Slopes
description: "Aspen Extreme," which opened at theaters here yesterday, is a cautionary tale with scenery about two young automotive workers from Detroit who become ski instructors in Aspen, Colo., but pay a terrible price for the glamorous lives they achieve.

title: This Family's Tuition Bills Come in Triplicate
description: When thier children were younger, the Rev. David Tontonoz, rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Md., and his wife, Susan, didn't have spare cash to start a college fund. Despite limited savings, they have managed to find the funds for their sons' school expenses. The couple's combined gross income, including $9,000 from Mrs. Tontonoz's part-time job at Salisbury State University, is $56,100 a year. School costs will be $69,000 next year, when all three sons will be enrolled. Here is how their bills add up, and how the family plans to pay them.

title: Air Products & Chemicals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4.2 million, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of a business venure and the partial sale of stock options in an insurance company.

title: SETTLING IN: News Analysis; Early Damage Control
description: It was a most inauspicious beginning, but President Clinton had no choice.

title: Putting Homes in Trust To Avoid the Estate Tax
description: FOR many Americans, a house is more than a home; it is also their most valuable asset. And when the home's value is added to investments and other assets, it can easily push the worth of an estate above the $600,000 threshold for Federal estate tax.

title: Associated Banc-Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe bank said results have been restated to reflect the F&M Financial Services Corp and Northeast Wisconsin Financial Services Inc., as a pooling of interests.The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

description: b-Included $ 70,235,000 restructuring charge and a $ 7,500,000 charge for an adjustment in the company's accounting for post-retirement medical benefits.

title: Top Futures Regulator Quits; Clinton Can Name 3 to Panel
description: Wendy Gramm resigned as chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission yesterday, clearing the way for President Clinton to appoint a majority of the five-member body that regulates the nation's futures markets.

title: Sharpton Aides Say He Will Not Enter City Council Race
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who has said often in recent weeks that he was considering running for New York City Council President this year, has apparently decided against the race.

title: Sherwin-Williams reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by $ 1,455,000 due to the adoption of SFAS No. 106, Accounting for Post-retirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.c-Included income of $ 18,057,000, or 20 cents a share, reflecting the cumulative effect for change in accounting method for income taxes, and also included extraordinary charge of $ 99,828,000 reflecting cumulative effect of change in accounting method for post-retirement benefits other than pensions.Adjustments for the fourth quarter 1991 increased net income by $ 1,364,000, or 2 cents per share. The increase was due to year-end adjustments of inventory and prior quarters' LIFO expense of $ 16,489,000, primarily offset by provisions of $ 3,585,000 for the disposition and termination of certain operations, provisions for environmental protection and control of $ 6,942,000, and other year-end adjustments of $ 4,598,000.

title: Laughing at AIDS
description: A friend was in the hospital, dying of AIDS. But Eddie was not only dying, he was whining. He demanded specific diet sodas, candy bars and flowers; he could not abide cheap roses from the deli or milk chocolate as opposed to dark. He refused to wear his new silk robe, which he deemed "too George Hamilton." He loathed the nurses. He patrolled the halls, lugging his intravenous hook-up behind him, just to light up an unfiltered Camel in every possible "No Smoking" zone.

title: Rare Tap-Dancing Films
description: Lincoln Center is to present "Movement as Metaphor: Jazz Dance on Film," a screening of rare films of tap dancing over six decades, on Wednesday at 8 P.M. at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. Jimmy Slyde, the tap dancer, will serve as host of the show, which includes films of Tip, Tap and Toe, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, the Nicholas Brothers and Bunny Briggs. Information: (212) 875-5600.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Desormeaux Returns With Two Victories Six weeks after being carried from the track bleeding and with multiple skull fractures, Kent Desormeaux, the nation's top-winning jockey with more than $14 million in 1992, returned yesterday in Arcadia, Calif., with winners in his first two races. In typical, aggressive Desormeaux style, the 22-year-old Louisiana native rode the mare Shrewd Vixen to victory in the fifth race at Santa Anita. Then in the $61,500 Ack Ack Handicap at a mile, he found a hole between two horses and directed the favorite, Slerp, to a $5.20 win payoff by a half length. (AP) GOLF Mickelson and Hart in a Tie for Lead

title: Donations to the Neediest Carry an Extra Meaning
description: They appear to be ordinary checks, seemingly no different than the billions of others that flow through the nation's financial system each year. But these are endowed with something extra, for they are filled out for sums that are multiples of 18, the numerical value of the Hebrew word for life, chai.

title: D. M. Johnson, 78; Led Mead Johnson In Rapid Expansion
description: D. Mead Johnson, who turned a medium-sized family business that made infant formula into a worldwide marketer of nutritional products and pharmaceuticals, died Thursday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., where he had retired. He was 78.

title: SETTLING IN: Picking Up the Pieces; Baird's Consolation Prize: Her Old $507,000 Job
description: Hours after Zoe Baird withdrew her nomination for Attorney General, her employer, Aetna Life and Casualty, issued a statement of warm reaffirmation, saying it would gladly welcome her back as the company's top lawyer.

title: Racial Pranks at Fraternity Bring Rebuke From College
description: The president of Rider College moved today to suspend some privileges of an all-white fraternity for a work night in which potential pledges were ordered to emulate a black stereotype and clean the fraternity house.

description: b-Included net charge of $ 5.7 million, which included a $ 2 million charge in connection with the closing of its futures subsidiary, a $ 1.2 million pension reserve adjustment benefit from employee severances, and a $ 4.5 million charge for the further write-down of the value of the corporation's office building in New York City.c-Included net restructuring charge of $ 11,950,000.Discount Corp. said the 1992 results ''reflect the current unavailability of tax loss benefits. The corporation now has approximately $ 27 million in deferred tax losses and tax-loss carryforwards.''

title: Trenton Tries to End $2.2 Billion Budget Gap
description: Faced with a projected $2.2 billion budget gap in an election year, New Jersey officials have begun negotiations on a range of revenue sources that they hope will allow them to close the gap with "minimal pain" to voters.

title: Kings of the Mountain, at Least for Now
description: A look at the latest performances of the 18 stock fund categories reveals a good lesson in market cycles -- what was first could very well become last.

title: Steel Prices Rise, and Industry Sees Profitability
description: Buoyed by the economic recovery and the possibility of new duties to protect them from foreign competition, the nation's large steel companies have announced price increases that could help the industry return to profitability this year.

Jones a Victor on Court, Not in Eyes of the Fans
description: When the American qualifier Kelly Jones surprised David Wheaton, 0-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2, in the third round on Friday, he pulled off the most significant victory of his career.

description: WHEN Sports Illustrated publishes its swimsuit issue next month, the University of North Carolina men's basketball players probably won't bring their copies to practice.

title: Bolar Co-Founder Receives A 5-Year Sentence for Fraud
description: A co-founder of the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company, a multimillion-dollar generic drug maker and a stock market favorite in the mid-1980's, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court in Baltimore to five years in prison for defrauding the Food and Drug Administration.

description: Free-agent relief pitcher JAY HOWELL signed a minor league contract with the Atlanta Braves yesterday and was invited to spring training. Contract terms were not disclosed.

title: Schott Has Her Say; Now Awaits Ruling
description: George Steinbrenner, despite threats to take legal action, never sued Fay Vincent, then the commissioner, over his suspension as the Yankees' managing partner. But Marge Schott's lawyer has strongly indicated that she would sue if the major leagues' executive council suspends her.

title: Two Shelters Inspected in Effort To Find Mentally Ill Residents
description: State officials said yesterday that they had inspected two New York City shelters for the homeless in an effort to identify residents who are dangerously mentally ill, and so far three residents of the Franklin Avenue Armory in the Bronx have been voluntarily taken to psychiatric emergency rooms.

title: Crying Wolf in Albany
description: A New York State Assemblywoman, Earlene Hill, says she was harassed by male colleagues in the Assembly. Her claims were reported last week in the press, accompanied by announcements of sensitivity training in the Assembly and "isn't-it-terribles" all around. But if the label "sexual harassment" is accepted for the actions described by Ms. Hill, it trivializes a very serious matter.

title: Jordan. Wilkins. The Nets See Double.
description: Facing two superstars in two consecutive nights was the less than enviable position the Nets found themselves in. On Thursday, it was Michael Jordan. Tonight, it was Dominique Wilkins. That's like facing Clint Eastwood and Charles Bronson in back-to-back shootouts.

title: SETTLING IN: An Angry Public; Fueled by Radio and TV, Outcry Became Uproar
description: By Sunday, most of official Washington and the news media had already dismissed the problems with Zoe Baird's nomination as Attorney General. But anyone listening that morning to Susan Estrich's talk show here on KABC radio knew the nomination was in deep trouble over Ms. Baird's hiring of illegal aliens as household help.

title: Kobo Abe, 68, the Skeptical Poet Of an Uprooted Society, Is Dead
description: Kobo Abe, a literary master whose haunting visions of people senselessly trapped by modern urban life made him one of Japan's most highly acclaimed postwar authors, died today. He was 68.

title: SETTLING IN: Easing Abortion Policy; CLINTON ORDERS REVERSAL OF ABORTION RESTRICTIONS LEFT BY REAGAN AND BUSH
description: Signaling a sea change in domestic policy, President Clinton moved today to reverse a decade of Republican edicts on abortion and other issues, including a repeal of the ban on abortion counseling at federally financed clinics.

title: Garner Hitches Ride Out of Anonymity
description: The identity of the first American man to reach the round of 16 at Flinders Park came as no surprise on Friday.

title: Phar-Mor Fraud Estimate
description: Phar-Mor Inc., the discount drugstore chain that was pushed into bankruptcy in August, said yesterday that a scheme by former executives to inflate profits was more extensive than previously estimated.

title:

description: The economy may be recovering, but with many companies still laying off workers, homeowners might want to consider insurance that picks up mortgage payments in case of an involuntary job loss.

CHRONICLE
description: In the White House not even a week, and already HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON will take a trip out of Washington. On Tuesday, she will come to New York to pick up the Lewis Hine Award for Distinguished Service to Children and Youth, given by the National Child Labor Committee. It will be presented to her by PAUL ALLAIRE, chairman and chief executive of the Xerox Corporation, at a reception in the Chemical Bank corporate headquarters on Park Avenue. Then she is to attend a dinner the organization will give at the University Club.

title: One Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings reflected 20 percent stock dividend declared and payable Feb. 15. Before adjustment for the stock dividend, share net for the latest fourth quarter was 70 cents, compared with 60 cents in year-ago period and $ 2.75 in 1992, versus $ 2.31 in 1991.

title: Bruce Kelly, 44, Architect of Strawberry Fields
description: Bruce Kelly, a landscape architect who created the gently welcoming realm of Strawberry Fields in Central Park, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 44.

title: Ruling Aids U.S. in Rodney King Case
description: Removing a significant obstacle to Government prosecutors, a Federal judge ruled today that they would not have to prove racial bias to win conviction of four white police officers in the beating of a black motorist, Rodney G. King.

title: U.S. Surgical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
London Journal; Labor's Problem: Must Beliefs Be Whitewashed?
description: Among the thousands who gathered on Wednesday under red, white and blue flags in the Dorchester Hotel ballroom to raise a long-distance toast to Bill Clinton's inauguration were more than a smattering of Labor Party leaders, members and sympathizers. They could be forgiven for what they were thinking: we could have been winners, too.

title: Chicago Plans Barriers To Hinder Street Crime
description: Confronting a murder wave that made 1992 the second deadliest year in Chicago history, and criticism that he has not done enough about it, Mayor Richard M. Daley says he wants to block off streets in every ward as a way of discouraging criminals by limiting their movements.

title: Dim Hope For Bosnia
description: After five months of deadlock and walkouts, the peace talks on Bosnia and Herzegovina will resume on Saturday in Geneva with all three warring parties committed, at least in principle, to the outline of a settlement.

description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 6.8 million on early retirement of debt.

description: More than a hundred actions taken by the Bush Administration in its final days were rescinded today in a sweeping move by Leon E. Panetta, hours after he was sworn in as Director of the Office of Management and Budget, Administration officials said.

Audrey Hepburn's Perfection
description: Audrey Hepburn, who died this week, was a charming actress. She was also an impassioned ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund. But a lot of women, and more than a few men, remember her best for the way she looked. It's not that she was a clotheshorse, though she was, or a great beauty, because she wasn't. It's that she came along in the age of the sex bomb -- the Monroes, the Mansfields -- and blew most of them away.

title: Maryanne Blacker, Nicholas Baker
description: LAST year, 13,126 couples were married in the Marriage Chapel at City Hall in Manhattan. On a recent visit, it seemed as if wedding parties were arriving as often as airplanes do at Kennedy International Airport, one after another after another, all day long.

title: SETTLING IN: The Old Order; Conferring on Future, Conservatives Long for the Past
description: In their first major gathering since the election last November, many prominent conservatives vowed today to stage a comeback even as some spoke almost in awe of President Clinton's political skills.

description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Portsmouth, N.H.;
Giant Stores Irk Residents
description: THE opening of one giant warehouse store last month and the construction of another across the street has Portsmouth residents questioning whether their government is pursuing the kind of economic development they want for this historic coastal city of 25,925.

title: SETTLING IN: The View From Rome; Vatican Attacks Clinton's Moves on Abortion
description: The Vatican castigated President Clinton today for his new abortion policies, saying his frequent calls for an American renewal have "embarked on the paths of death and violence against innocent beings."

title: Donna Krupp and Jeffrey Jepson
description: Joseph M. Krupp Jr. of Jersey City, has announced May wedding plans for his daughter Donna Marie Krupp and First Lieut. Jeffrey Freeman Jepson, a son of John K. Jepson Sr. and Anne Hastings, both of Simsbury, Conn.

title: Caroline Ewing, Jonathan Crystal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander C. Ewing of Winston-Salem, N.C., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Caroline Day Ewing, to Jonathan Michael Crystal, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Crystal of Beverly Hills, Calif. An April wedding is planned.

title: World Titles Spread Beyond U.S. and Italy
description: UNTIL four years ago, world championship play was dominated for 40 years by Americans and Italians. But that has all changed. The winners of open events, teams and pairs, from 1989 through 1992 were from Brazil, Germany, Iceland and France.

title:
The View From: Hawthorne;
Brainstorming With County Parks Department Planners
description: SNOW may be on the ground, but for the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, spring and summer are right around the corner. Like a department store that stocks merchandise well in advance, the Parks Department staff thinks about roses and beach romps even while office windows are coated with frost.

title: Q and A
description: Quorums by Proxy Question: Since a quorum always refers to the number of members present and not to the number voting, is it legal under New York State Business Corporation Law to establish a quorum by adding proxies to present members? . . . Theodore R. Smith, the Bronx

title: This Week's Numbers
The Square Root
description: It takes a lot to like a turnip. The squat little bulb is like a lover you'd rather not remember -- bitter and embarrassing. But the turnip is so persistent, so omnipresent from May to November, that grudgingly you accept it into your stew pot. There, simmering in its juices, its sulfurous aroma never fails to evoke the old sod.

title: A Trove of Greene and Greene Houses
description: AT the turn of the century, Midwesterners came to Pasadena to winter in a semi-arid landscape offering dependable sun and panoramas of the majestic San Gabriel Mountain range and its expansive valley. The houses they built in these rolling foothills and along the boulder-strewn, oak-rich ravine that cleaves the city -- the Arroyo Seco -- record the values of what has been called the Arroyo Culture.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Demothballing Developments Along I-78
description: THE mid-80's building boom inspired a spate of corporations to set up headquarters along the western stretch of Interstate 78, which slices through the rolling hills of Hunterdon County. But the recession stanched the wave of speculative development that was expected to follow.

title:
MUSIC;
40 Flutes, Some Humor and a Bit of Fire
description: ABOUT three years ago, Trevor Wye, a British flutist, retired from his teaching position and decided it was time to tell the public the history of the flute, how it works and what kinds of flutes exist.

title: Balkan Peace Talks Resume as War Drags On
description: Overshadowed by a renewed offensive in western Croatia and by battles in Bosnia and Herzegovina, talks on ending the Balkan war resumed here today among top leaders of all hostile factions.

title:
FILM;
Off to Siberia In the Search For Understanding
description: Shortly after the blacklisted Hollywood director John Berry took refuge in Paris in 1951, he found himself at the Left Bank cafe Les Deux Magots listening to Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus discuss suicide.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Quebec
description: In a 1964 song that the Quebecois took to heart like no other, the chansonnier Gilles Vigneault sang, "My country isn't a country, it's winter." If that sounds like a lament, you don't know Quebec, where long ago they decided to make their frosty fate one more excuse for communal merrymaking. In Quebec City, where January and February can be punishingly cold, that translates into Carnival.

title: Jean Harris's Plans Include Helping Inmates
description: Jean S. Harris yesterday spent her first full day of freedom in nearly 12 years recuperating from coronary bypass surgery and preparing to commit herself to helping the children of the imprisoned women she left behind, her lawyer said.

title: Julie E. Farris, Kevin Valentine
description: Mr. and Mrs. David J. Farris of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Julie Ellen Farris and Kevin John Valentine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Valentine of Landing, N.J.

title: Wall Street; When Inflation Hits the Gallop -- Duck
description: INVESTING during high-inflation times is apparently fun only for the short sellers. When the consumer price index soared 1.8 percent in August 1973, tobacco stocks dropped 8 percent, and drug issues lost 8.5 percent in a single month, said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a research firm in New York. In August 1974, the price index jumped 1.2 percent and electrical equipment stocks lost 20 percent while retailers dropped 16 percent, he added.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Dropping In for Ouzo and Appetizers in Athens
description: TAVERNAS get all the press, but the ouzeri may well be the definitive dining experience in Athens. These bars-cum-eateries, the Greek answer to the tapas bar, offer a window on the city's social life and cuisine.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a new process for converting natural gas to methanol misidentified a chemical. From 1992 to 1994 the United States is expected to triple its capacity to make methyl tertiary butyl ether, which is derived from methanol, not to triple the capacity to make methanol itself.

title: Patch by Patch, Putting Life Together
description: CREATING quilts was a way for women to speak out -- on politics, during celebrations, in good times and in bad. Quilting represented a coming together to create an object of warmth, but the art was also an avenue in which to apply the hands, head and heart to a craft.

title: Croat-Serb Clash in Croatia
description: Croatian forces and breakaway Serbs were trading fierce artillery and small-arms fire near the Adriatic port of Zadar. Page 12.

title: Members' Muscles Only
description: WEARING black leggings, a hairnet and dark sunglasses, Suzanne Bartsch, who is perhaps Manhattan's most infamous nightlife hostess, worked the room.

title: The Survival of a Tough and Tender Heroine
description: These days, "Anna Christie" pretty much boils down to the title role. Everything else about Eugene O'Neill's 1921 drama has aged badly. Its waterfront slang now sounds like parody. Its male characters subscribe to the double standard with a vehemence that invites derision. And its attempt to see in the fog-bound waters of "dat ole davil sea" a symbol of the world's malevolence fairly reeks of contrivance.

title: Jennifer Griffith, Brian D. Black
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Griffith of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of his daughter Jennifer Ann Griffith to Brian D. Black, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Black of Lakeland, Fla. A May wedding is planned.

title: Ambiguity And Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: From Bach to Berlin, Vocal Works Abound
description: "THIS is a rich, inspirational work, full of lush harmonies in a very traditional style," said Timothy Vernon, music director of the Choral Arts Society, about Bach's "St. John Passion." "It is exciting for the singers and wonderful for the audience." The society, the oldest continuous community chorus in Westchester, has engaged a professional orchestra and six vocal soloists for the performance this afternoon at 2:30 in Ossining High School. The number to call for reservations is 741-1365.

title:
ART REVIEW;
43 and Younger: 10 New 'Moderns'
description: IDENTIFYING the generation of an artist sometimes matters, because factors like the decade of birth can explain a style, a direction, a spirit or possibly even a lack of spirit.

title: A RIVER OF ONE'S OWN
description: Sport fishing is not necessarily a man's game, but it does have a tradition and history that have purpose, even if that tradition and history were created by men. Sandor overlooks the beauty of a ritual of which I am a 50-year acolyte.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Garden City to Vote on Buying Landmark
description: IF residents of Garden City vote "yes" in a referendum on Feb. 2, the village will take over the historic St. Paul's School at 295 Stewart Avenue.

description: CHILD-LOVING The Erotic Child and Victorian Culture. By James R. Kincaid. 413 pp. New York: Routledge. $35.

description: The Devils allowed the Bruins to parade freely in front of Chris Terreri for a great part of the night at Boston Garden, and they paid the price.

description: Jo Ann Komar and Timothy Jecko, consultants in business communications with Communispond Inc., a management consulting company in New York, were married Friday at the Appellate Division Courthouse in Manhattan. Associate Judge George Bundy Smith of the New York State Court of Appeals officiated.

title: For Too Many, Clemency Program Raises and Dashes Hopes
description: To the Editor:

title: Pamela Rosenblatt, Lee Samuelson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Rosenblatt of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Michele Rosenblatt, to Lee Evan Samuelson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott D. Samuelson of Melville, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: A review of "The Island," by Gustaw Herling, on Dec. 27 misstated the year of the American publication of his book "A World Apart." It was 1951, not 1986.

title: Judith Brous, Jeffrey R. Poss
description: Mr. and Mrs. David B. Brous of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Brous to Jeffrey R. Poss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Poss, also of South Orange. A May wedding is planned.

title: Public & Private; I'm O.K., You're Bill
description: Like reporters covering Elizabeth Taylor, we Americans have been through a lot of honeymoons with Bill Clinton. There was the apres Gennifer honeymoon and the apres draft honeymoon, the convention honeymoon and the transition honeymoon.

title: How Very Odd to Be Here
description: NATURAL OPIUM

title: Sands Pt. House in Landmark Fight
description: HARBOR ROAD in Sands Point curves and dips toward Hempstead Harbor, ending in a cul-de-sac overlooking a stately white colonial homestead that is plainly visible through the bare wintry trees.

title: Help in a Ship Fire
description: To the Editor: My husband and I were on the Seabourn Spirit Aug. 15, 1992, when a fire developed in the engine room. At 5:30 A.M. the captain directed passengers to put on life jackets and report to their lifeboat stations. He then announced that there was a fire in the engine room, which was under control. We stood on deck at sunrise watching black smoke billow from smokestacks and after about 20 minutes were directed to get into lifeboats.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Scott McVay;
The Ingenuity of the Dodge Foundation
description: THERE are foundations that spend more money on New Jersey organizations and projects -- the Prudential and Robert Wood Johnson Foundations, for example -- but experts in the field agree that none of these groups have been more ingenious and innovative in giving than the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation.

title: The World of Nancy Kwan
description: NAME: Nancy Kwan

title: Cauthen: Crossroad or Finish Line?
description: The Kid came home the other day and admitted that one of racing's renowned careers had reached a crossroads.

title: Freudian Trip
description: FREUD, JUNG, AND HALL THE KING-MAKER

title: Hangin' With the Nintendo Generation
description: For more than a year, "hard-core" has been the most vibrant dance-music cult in Britain. The term comes from "hard-core techno," a brutal, high-speed style of electronic rave music. Early on, hard-core meant bombastic synthesizer -- programmed machine-rhythms and a clinical though crazed atmosphere. But the music evolved into a hybrid of hip-hop and techno, merging the former's grit with the latter's futuristic weirdness, as disk jockeys and producers started to take beats from rap records and speed them up. In the process, they retained hip-hop's funky syncopation, yet at tempos (140 to 150 beats per minute) far faster than any flesh-and-blood drummer could sustain.

title: A Smorgasbord for the Ears
description: When David McLees, a projects supervisor for Rhino Records, wanted to use the song "Max's Kansas City" on the label's nine-volume compilation of punk and new wave, he followed the money trail. Since songwriters, like everyone else, expect to be paid for their work, he figured that someone connected with Wayne County, the obscure New York band that produced the song, would be registered with ASCAP or BMI. Wrong. Next he turned to the American Federation of Musicians. Strike two.

title: THE WORLD
description: EVEN before taking the oath of office, President Clinton was bombarded with advice on how to deal with Russia and the other former Soviet republics. Most of it portrayed Boris N. Yeltsin as a critical and threatened bulwark against the revival of an evil empire. If the United States fails to shore him up, goes the argument, Russia could fall to Communists, fascists, revanchist generals or worse.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a producer's schedule change, an events listing on page 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, includes an outdated reference to a Columbia University benefit. It is being delayed and will be rescheduled.

title: 'Assisted Living'
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan the Kitchen and Avoid Pitfalls
description: READY-TO-ASSEMBLE kitchen cabinets make remodeling a kitchen much easier than when cabinets were just available ready-made or built to order by a cabinetmaker. But planning the sizes, and determining how the cabinets will look when installed, can still be challenging, unless the new cabinets will be exactly the same sizes as the old ones.

title: A Pianist's 10-Day Tour of Bridgeport
description: THE pianist Jose Ramos-Santana, a native of Puerto Rico whose most recent honor was his selection as the 1992-93 Xerox Affiliate Artist, is in the midst of a 10-day visit to the Bridgeport area. He played a solo recital last Friday, has been giving informal programs in schools and for groups of older people, and performed yesterday for two organizations, Atteneo Latino and Aspira.

title: Mary Dudine, Ronald Kyle
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Dudine Jr. of Water Mill, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Margaret Dudine to Ronald William Kyle, a son of Enid Kyle of Lethbridge, Alberta, Canada, and the late Cyril Kyle. An August wedding is planned.

title: Bathed in Glory
description: MORNINGS ARE A delicate time. But a shower of natural light can be as invigorating as a splash of hot water.

title: A RIVER OF ONE'S OWN
description: Marjorie Sandor should take heart (Hers: "A River of One's Own," Jan. 3). As the daughter of a backwoods-raised father, I was brought up with the philosophy that you fish to eat. In fact, the more we caught the better. We would freeze our extra fish and share it with friends, in what we Southerners call a "fish fry."

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Gail Eilene Paley to Dr. Samuel Fox misstated Dr. Fox's age. He is 34, not 43.

title: JAN. 17-23: No Comfort in Sight; Justice Dept. Report Clouds F.B.I. Chief's Past and Future
description: "Deeply disturbing."

title: LAUGHING OFF THE RECESSION
description: Regarding Murphy Brown, did Diane English ever ask the little children of single mothers if they, too, feel "liberated" having no fathers? SYLVIA DAY Woodstock, N.Y.

title: A FATHER'S RITE
description: Higgins paints a poverty of inheritance for his daughter. By sentimentalizing the bonding of father and son, he perpetuates the bias that only men are heirs to the power and glory of their ancestors. This reinforces the debilitating notion that men inherit the cultural landmarks of society and women inherit the familial. AUDREY SHIMKAS Mill Valley, Calif.

title: Schools Are Wary of Merger Study
description: A STATEWIDE plan to study school districts that might be candidates for merging is being greeted with skepticism and criticism by the four Westchester County and two Putnam County districts selected for preliminary study and by other local officials. The Board of Regents authorized the State Education Department at the board's January meeting to look at 137 school districts in the state that met one or more of six criteria the department established.

title:
DANCE;
Moving to an African-Caribbean Beat
description: GARTH FAGAN DANCE, a multi-ethnic company of 15 virtuosic dancers, will make its McCarter Theater debut on Saturday in a program that reflects the African-Caribbean and modern-dance backgrounds of its founder and artistic director, Garth Fagan.

title: Mad, Bad, Still Hard to Know
description: BYRON By Sigrid Combuchen. Translated by Joan Tate. 518 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Heinemann/Trafalgar Square. $24.95.

title: Jeffrey R. Peltier, Valerie H. Speyer
description: Valerie Hope Speyer, a daughter of Lynne Tishman Speyer and Jerry I. Speyer, both of New York, was married last evening to Jeffrey Richard Peltier, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Peltier of Tipp City, Ohio. Rabbi Peter Rubenstein performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Blasting Off In a Wild Bull Market
description: YOU wouldn't know it by looking at the Dow Jones industrial average, and certainly not by studying the performance of I.B.M., but this is a wonderful bull market. Technology stocks are hot and the speculative juices are flowing.

title: Their Songs Were America's Happy Talk
description: Once upon a time, America dreamed of itself as a singing fairy tale for grown-ups, with a happy ending. Norman Rockwell painted this storybook country, and Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d wrote its songs. More than just pop confections, they added up to a kind of secular catechism that sweetly but firmly instructed people on the rules of behavior in a world where America knew best and good triumphed over evil.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a musicians' strike, the classical music listings on page 33 of the Arts and Leisure section today include outdated references to performances by the American Composers Orchestra today and by the Brooklyn Philharmonic this Friday and Saturday. Those orchestras' concerts have been canceled pending resolution of the labor dispute. A report on the strike appears today in the Metro Report, page 26.

title: Live, and in Sizzling Color, The Trashing of the Island
description: AFTER three made-for-television movies, at least one "quickie" paperback book, a top-rated edition of "Donahue" and day-after-day headlines, the question is not whether there is anyone who does not know the names Buttafuoco and Amy Fisher. The question is, Is Long Island becoming a laughingstock to the rest of the nation?

title:
In the Region: Westchester;
White Plains Seeks to Enliven Downtown
description: AS White Plains prepares for the opening this fall of the first of three new malls, landlords, merchants and officials are exploring ways to improve the downtown shopping district.

title: Barbara Bush Was Boss, But Another Duty Called
description: Anna Perez, who was Barbara Bush's press secretary, spent Tuesday, her last full day on the job, working a decidedly different beat. Ms. Perez helped handle publicity for one of the many parties last week celebrating the inauguration of President Clinton.

title: No Headline
description: Now that sex and drugs have become acceptable, yuppies will be judged by the immigration status of their baby sitters. PROF. MITCHELL MOSS, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. [ 32:2. ]

title: Once-Sleazy Timeshares Gain New Vacation Respectability
description: THE concept of a timeshare vacation had never appealed to Sandy Bowman of Cincinnati. "Buying a studio for a specific two weeks at the same resort didn't seem that attractive," she said.

title:
ART;
Artists-Cum-Beach Denizens Have Come In From the Cold
description: A WELL-FOCUSED exhibition, imbued with the spirit of summertime, is welcome these days with a long stretch of winter ahead. The show is "Celebrating Long Point" at the Station Gallery in Katonah, N.Y., with Vincent Baldessano as curator.

title: Robin C. Stopsky, Anthony C. Grow
description: Mr. and Mrs. David C. Stopsky of Plainview, L.I., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Robin Carrie Stopsky and Anthony Clay Grow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton C. Grow of Winchester, Ind.

title: Data Update
'Passion Fish' Nourishes the Grown-Ups
description: John Sayles is one of those unfortunate film makers who is often damned with great praise. "Matewan," the tale of a 1920 West Virginia miners' strike, and "City of Hope," the story of racial tension and urban blight in a New Jersey town, were acclaimed for being rigorous, uncompromising social visions. That kind of praise can kill a picture, and pretty much did. Audiences saw code words for dreary, depressing, stay away.

title: Clinton and Yeltsin Aides to Arrange Summit
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin spoke by telephone today and agreed to arrange a summit.

title: Pentagon Agrees to Delay a Reactor Test in Space
description: Pentagon officials, responding to complaints by astronomers, have agreed to defer for at least six months any commitments to carry out a nuclear reactor test in orbit. The delay would give scientists time to assess the chances that the test might produce radiation that could interfere with astronomical observations.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ROSE REASONBy Mary Flanagan.Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $23.95.

title: Democrats In Their Glory
description: Washington's inaugural balls welcomed over 70,000 on Jan. 20.

title: A la Carte; The Charm of Cold Spring Harbor Is Limitless
description: THE quaint North Shore village of Cold Spring Harbor has a seaside style of its own, and the cozy new Cold Spring Harbor Cafe, at 134 Main Street (367-6060), has a colonial look that fits right in.

title: A Summer School Program for Teachers
description: IT may be some students' idea of the ultimate revenge: summer school for teachers. But Westchester students will be the final beneficiaries of a new program planned by the State University of New York here to establish an intensive teacher-training program on its campus this July.

title: Delegation Gains Posts To Guard Home Front
description: NO one knows exactly what it takes to win a coveted seat on a major Congressional committee because voting on assignments takes place behind closed doors. The ingredients seem to be a predictable political mixture of seniority, networking, regional affiliation and power of personality.

title: A Female Rabbi With Spirituality Enough to Make History
description: IT is a frigid Saturday morning in mid-January, but inside the intimate sanctuary of Congregation Genesis-Agudas Achim, Rabbi Susan Grossman is just beginning to warm to her subject -- talking to teen-age children about God. Leaving the elevated perch of her pulpit, she begins to stroll, a la Donahue, down the aisle of the synagogue, articulating her position, encouraging congregants to contribute their thoughts and queries on the subject.

title: 'Acting Should Be A Joy'
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus: Oakland, Calif.; Collecting on Insurance After the '91 Fire
description: A FIRESTORM in October 1991 swept over the steep hills of this city and destroyed the home of Ron and Bette Bugaj, among 3,300 other houses here and in neighboring Berkeley. But as far as Mr. Bugaj is concerned, "the damage we really suffered was in our negotiations with our insurance company."

title: The Sky's the Limit, But Don't Bank on Elvis
description: FRESH from Elvis ecstasy, the United States Postal Service this week moves on to another hot topic for stamp designs, space exploration. Several surveys by the Linn's Stamp Weekly and American Topical Association, a national group of people who collect stamps by subject, have shown that space travel is the most popular topic among collectors.

title: Two Motels Added to List of Shelters for Families
description: Confronted with families sleeping on table tops and dirty floors in city welfare offices, the Dinkins administration has announced plans to shelter more than 60 homeless families in two more motels, one in the Bronx and the other on Staten Island.

title: Elisabeth Murdoch, Elkin K. Pianim
description: Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation media empire, and Anna Murdoch of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Murdoch, to Elkin Kwesi Pianim, a son of A. Kwame and Cornelia Pianim of Accra, Ghana. A September wedding is planned.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Brighton Beach
description: THE Russian influence in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn is so pervasive -- Pat Singer, executive director of the Brighton Beach Association, says emigres make up 60 percent of the population -- that it has been dubbed "Little Odessa by the Sea."

title: Sounds of Venice
description: To the Editor: In "The Serene Sounds of Venice," Louis Inturrisi remembers the sound of the locals talking -- "that energetic blend of lilting intonation and slushy sibilants."

title:
Long Island Q&A;: Azad K. Anand;
65,000 M.R.I.'s a Year In Doctor's 5 Clinics
description: DR. AZAD K. ANAND, who is 45, came to the United States from his native India in 1975 after briefly practicing medicine there. He is founder and president of Long Island Diagnostic Imaging, which has offices in Lake Success, Rego Park, Ridge, East Setauket and Syosset.

title: The Clinton Challenge Is Hardly Self-Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; A Just January
description: When the sky isn't spitting rain it's spitting snow -- enough to be a nuisance, too little to make things pretty. After a few fitful appearances the sun disappears for good along about noon. Which is just about the time the wind is picking up speed. Waiting for the bus is even less fun than usual. Getting up in the morning is no joy either. Going to bed is a pleasure.

title: Supreme Court No Longer Protects Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurers Second-Guess Doctors, Provoking Debate Over Savings
description: Dr. Robert Sawyer, a Denver surgeon, has a full-time office manager to get approval from insurers to perform operations. He also speaks to the companies every couple of days himself to report on patients' progress, spending about an hour each day on the phone justifying his patients' care.

title: Knicks Are Striving To Maintain Groove
description: The Knicks needed the kind of week they just finished.

title: With Issues Unresolved, Police Get Powerful Guns
description: As 1,000 powerful semiautomatic 9-millimeter handguns are distributed this week for the first time to police officers in precincts throughout New York City, questions about whether the gun is suitable in the city's teeming streets have yet to be resolved.

title: Technology; Inside Human Cells, a New Frontier
description: MOST drug discovery has focused in recent years on the development of molecules that either interact with or block receptors -- proteins that act as on-off switches for genetic activity -- on the surfaces of human cells.

title: Britain Senses a Lapse in That Special Relationship
description: FOR weeks, editors and politicians here have been waging an unusual trans-Atlantic campaign, nudging the incoming Clinton team to consider preserving at least one holdover from the Bush Administration: Raymond G. H. Seitz, the United States Ambassador to Britain. "If he is wise," The Times of London advised, "Mr. Clinton will recognize that there are some virtues in continuity."

title: The Rehabbing of America
description: THE MAKING OF A DRUG-FREE AMERICA Programs That Work. By Mathea Falco. 254 pp. New York: Random House/Times Books. $22. RECKONING Drugs, the Cities, and the American Future. By Elliott Currie. 405 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $25.

title: As Seen on TV
description: IN a television studio on the West Side, video cameras and monitors surrounded a set that had the look of a chic laboratory, with beakers filled with colored liquid. A 46-year-old woman with her hair in rollers, wearing a baggy black sweater over zebra-striped leggings and no makeup, emerged from the bustling crowd of camera operators and technicians.

title: Sasha Lawer, Mark Noonan
description: Alexandra Lawer, the publisher of special publications at the Hearst Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to Mark Noonan, a vice president in debt markets at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. The Rev. Steven Geckeler performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: The Reformation of a Street Preacher
description: Al Sharpton was up on the stage, that familiar voice booming and his words streaming in a hot cascade over an audience of teen-agers, most of them black, who strained forward in their chairs. The Democratic senatorial primary was long since over. But Sharpton looked as though none of that had really registered. Two months after his defeat, he was still running. His speaking, handshaking, protest marching, celebrity bow-taking, back-room strategizing schedule was so busy that his youngest daughter, Ashley, who is just 5 and perhaps does not yet understand what makes her father run, had to ask, finally, "Does Daddy know yet that he didn't win?"

title: The View From Another Hungarian
description: Throughout his life as a physicist, Eugene Wigner, now 90 years old, has sought nature's symmetries. As a result, the physics canon includes Wigner crystals, Wigner theorems, Wigner rules -- all expressions of symmetry and order. THE RECOLLECTIONS OF EUGENE P. WIGNER (Plenum, $24.50), as told to Andrew Szanton, makes it clear that the physicist's love of order has also spilled over into politics. When disorder of the most extreme sort came during World War II, Mr. Wigner's abhorrence of the Nazi plague contributed to a crucial application of physics to warfare: in 1939, he and Leo Szilard drove out to Albert Einstein's summer hideaway on Long Island and persuaded him to write the letter to President Roosevelt that initiated the Manhattan project, the development of a fission weapon. The project itself brought together a brilliant quartet of Hungarian physicists -- Eugene Wigner, Leo Szilard, Edward Teller and John von Neumann -- all of whom, save Szilard, embraced conservative politics after the war. Mr. Wigner became strongly anti-Communist and a supporter of the Vietnam War, largely, he says, because he saw a fearful symmetry between Nazism and Communism. Even Mr. Wigner's discussion of

title: Speaking of Deficit Spending
description: In January, consumers traditionally rue their holiday largess as they study their credit card bills. Some consumers - those with thinly stretched finances - may find themselves unable to make credit payments.

title:
DINING OUT;
Aging Gracefully in Granite Springs
description: FRITZ'S, in the county for at least two dozen years, first in a fondly remembered luncheonette in Somers and now in a cute, countryesque restaurant in Granite Springs, has moved gracefully into mellow middle age. Eschewing the racy flourishes of its youth, the kitchen has settled into serving with some consistency solid, wholesome fare with enough culinary surprises here and there to amuse the palates of a faithful local clientele. The trick to having a terrific meal here is to zoom in on those surprises.

title: Case Receives 30-Day Suspension
description: WALTER CASE JR., the record-setting harness driver, has received a 30-day suspension for failing to take a urine test, a New Jersey state racing commission official said yesterday.

title: State Department Simplifies Its Overseas Advisories
description: AS part of its task of safeguarding Americans while they are out of the United States, the State Department has for 15 years been issuing sporadic cautionary reports on conditions in foreign countries, advising citizens not to travel to particular places, to be wary of certain situations, or to be aware of the level of certain crimes against Americans.

title: Bevin M. Maguire And Craig P. Hunt
description: Lieut. Col. Frank J. Maguire of the Army, retired, and Mrs. Maguire of Wilton, Conn., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Bevin Mary Maguire and Craig Phillips Hunt, the son of Sarah Hunt of Leesburg, Va., and Roger Hunt of Fountain Hills, Ariz.

title: Mutual Funds; Sharing the Load, and Other Topics
description: READERS have written recently asking about sales commissions, fund performance data, tax-exempt funds and more. Following are some of their questions.

title: A Sports White Paper for Clinton
description: Having made his initial cabinet and staff appointments and settled into the Oval Office, President Clinton can now get on with the business of governing. Sort of. How he organizes his White House and who he puts in certain non-Cabinet posts will add texture to the broad vision of renewal articulated in his inaugural address.

title: Marie W. Blair, Arnold Beermann
description: Marie W. Blair of Wilson, N.C., and William J. Blair Jr. of Wilmington, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marie Watson Blair to Arnold Edward Beermann Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Beermann of Douglaston, Queens. A June wedding is planned.

title: Solace for Victims of Chronic Pain
description: FOR Eileen Arena of Holtsville, the recent holiday was the first time in many years she was able to shop for gifts, because she had finally mustered the courage to ask for help. She suffers from chronic pain, which prevents her from walking any distances or carrying anything heavy.

title: Croats Battle Serbs for a Key Bridge Near the Adriatic
description: Croatian forces and Serbs traded artillery and small-arms fire today near Zadar, a port on the Adriatic, a day after the Croats mounted surprise assaults hoping to wrest a vital bridge and airport from the Serbs.

title: Making a Street: Forget About Logos On the Skyline
description: Building as object, building as icon: that was the mode corporate architecture favored in the 1980's, when the goal of every company indulging in the act of construction seemed to be to end up with a trademark on the skyline. The most important criterion for judging a building's success as a symbol of corporate aspirations in that extravagant decade was not whether it functioned well, or whether it contributed anything to its surroundings, but whether it looked strikingly different and created an easily identifiable form.

title: Hard Landing in Tokyo
description: THE BUBBLE ECONOMY Japan's Extraordinary Speculative Boom of the 80's and the Dramatic Bust of the 90's. By Christopher Wood. 210 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.

title: County Draws Up A Wish List For Albany
description: EACH year at this time, lawmakers in the county sit down with experts in the executive branch to draw up a legislative shopping list for Albany -- legislation that Westchester's political leaders believe would reduce costs, increase revenues or simply enhance the quality of life.

title: Sounds of Venice
description: To the Editor: Your essay, "The Serene Sounds of Venice" (Dec. 20), brought to mind our trip there several years ago.

title: Remember the 'S Corporation'
description: To the Editor:

title: SETTLING IN: The Media; Outdoing Bush, President Keeps the Press at Bay
description: On President Clinton's first full day in office, his Administration's communications strategy was already clear: tightly control the information flow to reporters as the President speaks directly to the people.

title: Easing Racial Tensions With a Night of Melody
description: RONALD HARRISON, the vice president for community affairs at Pepsico here, was reflecting on the state of race relations in the county. "I don't think we do any worse than other places," said Mr. Harrison, who is black. "But I always thought Westchester should do better, because we are more affluent. There's almost a Mason-Dixon Line between northern and southern Westchester."

title: McClellan at His Worst
description: TO THE GATES OF RICHMOND

title: New Effort To Teach Homeless Children
description: A STUDENT at the Burnet Street School in Newark recently learned how to read.

title: The Smoke That Thunders
description: THE smallish, two-decker boat on which I sit meanders upstream, rattling and knocking, with the great Victoria Falls roaring out of sight. If you didn't know the falls were there, you would assume that this broad, calm river in Zimbabwe wound on and on, that the faint thundering you can hear is simply the noise of the bush. In fact, the guide says over the boat's loudspeaker, David Livingstone was lucky. When he came upon the falls in 1855, there was a drought. Had the Zambezi been high, as it was now, he would have been swept off the edge.

title: Justice Delayed Is Bitter Justice for Carter
description: With his one good eye, his left, still piercing out from behind steel-rim glasses, the black man, the onetime middleweight contender, half-blind because of a botched operation in prison, stood Friday night at the lectern and looked out over an audience of some 400 people in the Austin Hall auditorium here at Harvard University.

title: Jonathan Harwitz, Aileen Atkins
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Allan Atkins of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Aileen Debra Atkins to Jonathan Michael Harwitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Harwitz of Buffalo. An April wedding is planned.

title:
Viewpoints;
Crashing Wall Street's Stag Party
description: WHEN Muriel Siebert was interviewed recently in The New York Times, she commented on the lack of prominent women on Wall Street and their seeming inability to make it to the top. "Lawsuits won't do it," she said. Maybe not, but if firms are not complying with the law now, what will make them change later?

title: Contracts to Provide Ombudsmen's Services
description: We appreciate "Short-Staffed Ombudsmen's Offices Face Onslaught of Complaints" [ Dec. 20 ] on the growing importance of Ombudspersons in nursing and adult homes in Suffolk and Nassau Counties. It would be very useful if the public understood that the Suffolk County Department for the Aging and the Nassau County Department of Senior Citizens have contracts with the state for the Ombudservice programs. They are administered by two highly respected nonprofit voluntary agencies, the Family Service League of Suffolk County and the Family Service Association of Nassau County.

title: Freelance Musicians in 9 Small Orchestras Strike
description: The freelance musicians who make up nine of New York City's smaller orchestras went on strike just before midnight Friday night, when the orchestras and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians were unable to reach an agreement on a new contract, said Leonard Leibowitz, the lawyer for the musicians. The players had earlier voted to authorize their negotiating committee to strike.

title: Jesse Jackson's Unfair Plan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Riding the Crest of an Italian Food Wave
description: WITHIN the last 16 years, a trim little frame house set back from U.S. 1, where Stamford melts into Old Greenwich, has been host to at least three restaurants. Now a fourth has taken possession. Ciaobella! (Hello, Beautiful!) is an elegant looking restaurant riding the crest of the Italian food craze.

title: 'Mystery of Irma Vep,' A Ludlam Masterpiece
description: CHARLES LUDLAM was a master at taking bits and pieces from theatrical and literary classics and rearranging them into original and entertaining mosaics. One of his masterpieces, "The Mystery of Irma Vep," is receiving a wickedly funny production at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title:
FILM;
The Doctor and 'Lorenzo's Oil'
description: In 1990, when the director George Miller read an article about a man and woman who discovered a "miracle cure" for ALD -- a rare, horrific and fatal neurological disease -- his response was blunt: "As a doctor, I said it was a great story but I didn't believe real life happens this way -- that ordinary, nonscientific people eclipse scientific knowledge and come up with a cure."

title: Lesson for a High-Tech President
description: IT is no mystery why Silicon Valley became Clinton country in last year's election. The Clinton Administration's style and policy pronouncements appeal to the people who labor in high-technology industries like software and semiconductors. The Clintonites talk technospeak, often at length. They aren't squeamish about declaring that some industries are more equal than others, or that these favored high-tech fields should get government help and taxpayers' money.

title: CURRENCY
The Frog on the Typewriter And Other Literary Illusions
description: AMID all the leather and marble in an elegant furniture store, I saw copies of my first book on several shelves and offered to buy them. The salesman flinched and recoiled: "We don't sell books." I said, "Please, I'm short of copies." He fled, consulted his colleagues, reported that they were "in shock" and gave me the books without charge -- while hastening me toward the exit. It seemed as if he thought I was demented. Perhaps I made bizarre requests all over the city, asking for an old riding crop from a Ralph Lauren display, or a dried sea horse from a window full of sand and sunglasses, or a plywood cow from the Food Emporium.

title: DIALOGUE: Last Word on the October Surprise?; Missing Link
description: O n Inauguration Day 1981, Iran released the hostages minutes after Ronald Reagan became President. The timing gave rise to claims of a secret deal between the Reagan-Bush campaign and Iran. As a White House official involved in the hostage negotiations, I refused for many years to accept those allegations.

title: Pump Food
description: WHAT THEY ARE: Trendy nutritional supplements for body builders and the body-obsessed. Hot Stuff is a protein powder that, its manufacturer claims, helps build muscles. Razor Cuts is an herb and amino-acid caplet that, its maker says, helps metabolize fat and eliminate excess water. The goal: that "ripped" look of sharply cut, well-defined muscles. Example: Marky Mark. CELEBRITY USERS: Marky Mark does Hot Stuff. So do Hulk Hogan, Evander Holyfield, New Kids on the Block and W. Axl Rose. Richard Barretta, a trainer and nutritional adviser at the David Barton Gym in Manhattan, uses both Hot Stuff and Razor Cuts. He has also advised many clients -- among them William Norwich, the gossip columnist; Blaine Trump, the socialite, and Linda Wells, the editor of Allure magazine -- to do the same. Some do. Some don't.

title: Oliver Hailey, 60, Author of Plays And Scripts
description: Oliver Hailey, a prolific playwright and writer of film and television dramas, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 60 and died of cancer, said his wife, Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey.

title: E. J. Borrack, Robert L. Reider
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris Borrack of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Esther Jo Borrack to Robert Leonard Reider, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Reider of Oceanside, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Two Are Slain, Three Injured At Loud Party
description: Two people were shot to death and three others were wounded early yesterday after a dispute erupted at a warehouse party in Brooklyn and spilled out onto the street, the police said.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Fifth Avenue; Doldrums? Not Along Fifth Ave.
description: IT is rare enough to sight a building nearing completion in New York City. On Fifth Avenue, however, there are two: a 30-story office tower at 46th Street and the 20-story Takashimaya Building, between 54th and 55th Streets, which will house a specialty shop, art gallery and restaurant, as well as offices.

title: SILENCE OF THE FROGS
description: So I pick up your magazine expecting to be enlightened on some major issue only to find a frog staring out at me. Then I read the headline that frogs are mysteriously disappearing from the planet. And I think, What are we going to do without frogs? Will we no longer be able to go to French restaurants? Will biology teachers all across the country be laid off?

title: Access Law Is Still Open to Interpretation
description: CONNECTICUT is on the way to becoming more accessible to people with disabilities under a new Federal civil rights law. But certain loopholes exist that might preserve discrimination rather than prohibit it, according to advocates of people with disabilities.

title: Sports of The Times; Time to Get Nostalgic For Commish
description: AS soon as the Giants hire a coach, perhaps we can all get serious about truly vital affairs. I have never seen so much energy expended trying to come up with a figure who will materialize only 16 Sundays a year and otherwise spend his time like a surly mole in concrete bunkers underneath a stadium in the swampland.

title: The Smoke That Thunders
description: THE smallish, two-decker boat on which I sit meanders upstream, rattling and knocking, with the great Victoria Falls roaring out of sight. If you didn't know the falls were there, you would assume that this broad, calm river in Zimbabwe wound on and on, that the faint thundering you can hear is simply the noise of the bush. In fact, the guide says over the boat's loudspeaker, David Livingstone was lucky. When he came upon the falls in 1855, there was a drought. Had the Zambezi been high, as it was now, he would have been swept off the edge.

title: Playing the Cowboys For a Turnaround
description: Everyone knew that this Texas outfit was damaged goods by early 1989. A brash innovator, perennial leader and occasionally dominant force for 20 years, it had lost its way and become mired at the bottom of a high-profile industry.

title: History May Not Help Millrose Milers
description: Two four-time Millrose champions will be on the line for the women's mile at the Chemical Bank Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5, and neither may be the favorite. The two are MARY SLANEY, the American indoor and outdoor record holder, and DOINA MELINTE of Romania, who has won the last three Millrose events.

Poetry Alone Won't Defeat the Deficit
description: INAUGURAL addresses are intended to be poetic expressions of leadership and intent, but more than poetry may be needed these days. As I watched President Clinton deliver his speech, a delivery man walked by and said: "God bless America. I hope this guy has some guts."
