description: While the United Nations probably enjoys a higher profile today than ever, its most important peacemaking missions are bogged down or threatened with collapse in trouble spots as varied as Angola, El Salvador, the former Yugoslavia and Cambodia, raising the possibility of a damaging reversal to its influence.

title: Smith Runs Hip-Hop and Heads Up
description: For the funky, the hip-hop and the proper slant on all that really matters in Super Bowl XXVII, the MTV host Bill Bellamy last Friday turned to the spot where youth reigns in the National Football League: the Dallas Cowboys' locker room.

title: Brett Weston, Photographer, 81; Saw Purity in Nature's Patterns
description: Brett Weston, a photographer long renowned for his magisterial, sharply delineated landscapes and close-ups of plant forms, sand dunes and other natural objects, died on Friday, at Kona Hospital in Hawaii. He was 81 and lived in Carmel, Calif., and Paradise Park, on the island of Hawaii.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Germans Plan to Make It Easier For Some to Obtain Citizenship
description: At the same time they are tightening laws to slow an influx of asylum seekers, German legislators are planning to make it easier for foreigners who have long lived here to become German citizens.

title: Interleaf Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Two Games Too Long for Gartner
description: Mike Gartner was stuck at No. 29 for a mere two games, but it felt like forever. He scored his 29th goal of the season on Jan. 13, against the Washington Capitals. One more and he would set an all-time National Hockey League record, becoming the first player to score 30 or more goals in 14 consecutive seasons.

title: In Focus Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Elco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a loss of $ 1,355,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Cancer Center Curbed In Radiation Incident
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has suspended the license of Oncology Services Inc. of Harrisburg, Pa., to use radioactive iridium in cancer treatments. The decision came after a treatment center owned by the company accidentally left a sliver of radioactive metal inside an 82-year-old Pennsylvania woman in November, apparently causing her death five days later.

title: Belgrade May Act on Croatia
description: The President and the military chief of Yugoslavia vowed to intervene in Serb-Croat fighting in Croatia unless the U.N. restored peace. Page A9.

title: Keithley Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; Question: Can We All Run Together?
description: AT halftime of tomorrow night's Knicks-76ers game at Madison Square Garden, there will be another basketball game, one that season-ticket holders had not bargained for.

title: Malone, Magic Clear Air
description: KARL MALONE and MAGIC JOHNSON blame a lack of communication and intrusion -- by mainly the news media -- for reports in November that Malone helped push Johnson into retirement.

title: Public Defender Work Is Its Own Reward
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Clinton and Iraqgate
description: The scandal called Iraqgate began, I am told, with a personal request in early 1989 from a foreign head of state to George Bush on a matter requiring the assistance of Saddam Hussein.

title: Pedone Is Selected By Genesee Brewing
description: The Genesee Brewing Company in Rochester has selected Pedone & Partners Inc. in New York to handle its beer brands account, previously at Mullen Inc. in Wenham, Mass. Billings were estimated at $5 million. Pedone was awarded the account after a four-month review that also included two other finalists, Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot in Boston and Grace & Rothschild in New York.

title: Baseball Cards at Issue In Bizarre Murder Trial
description: ON the dance floor in the local V.F.W. hall, prosecutors set out to prove that an Armonk neurologist, Dr. Daniel Pack, was killed in a baseball-card deal gone bad.

title: YUGOSLAV LEADER THREATENS CROATS
description: Yugoslavia's Serbian President and a top military officer threatened today to intervene in fighting between Croats and Serbs on Croatia's Adriatic coast unless the United Nations restores peace.

title: Birmingham Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are restated for 3-for-2 stock split, in the form of 50 percent stock dividend, effective Dec. 16, 1992.

title: Dance in Review
description: Sefa Jorques and the Klixbull Dance Company Ohio Theater SoHo

title: Read-Rite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Saudis Call For Cuts By OPEC
description: In a move that could substantially lift sagging oil prices, Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer and exporter, has called on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce its overall output of oil production by more than a million barrels a day.

title: Texas Town and Fertilizer From That City
description: A tiny yellow engine and 18 bright red railroad cars stand out sharply as they trundle past dark creosote bushes and the occasional sotol plant, bringing another load of treated sewage from New York City to the high desert of West Texas.

title: Leo Lowenthal, 92, Professor of Sociology
description: Leo Lowenthal, a retired professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley who analyzed the role of literature in society, died Thursday at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley. He was 92 and lived in Berkeley.

title: Fighting for Custom House, Boston Appeals to U.S.
description: Towering 500 feet above the tourist-packed Quincy Market and only blocks from Boston Harbor, the gray granite Custom House sits dark, dank and empty, waiting for better times.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Cable Radio Searches for Subscribers
description: Even in an age of 20-song music marathons and nonstop hits, mainstream radio has too many distractions -- commercials, disk-jockey patter, reception problems -- for some listeners.

title: Guatemala Indians in a Joyful Return From Exile
description: To the din of firecrackers and welcoming chants, the first organized group of returning Guatemalan war refugees marched into the center of the capital today, four days after they crossed the border from exile camps in Mexico.

title: Dance in Review
description: New York City Ballet 'Jeu de Cartes' New York State Theater

title: Abroad at Home; If It Were Mr. Baird
description: Look at the Zoe Baird nomination story and imagine that the genders had been reversed: The nominee for Attorney General was a man, Aetna's general counsel, earning $500,000 a year. His wife was a Yale law professor; she made the child care arrangements, hiring illegal aliens after discussing it with immigration lawyers. Would the nominee have been swamped by a storm of public indignation?

title:
BASKETBALL;
The Blue Devils' Crown Receives Another Dent
description: The 3-point attempt by Byron Wells bounced on the rim, hung tantalizingly for a moment and finally fell through the basket with 3 seconds left. And by that slimmest of margins, Florida State gained what Coach Pat Kennedy called the biggest victory of his seven-year tenure, an 89-88 overtime conquest of No. 6-ranked Duke.

title: Dance in Review
description: New York City Ballet 'In Memory of . . .' New York State Theater

title: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and new issues of two- and five-year notes. The two-year issue will be auctioned tomorrow and the five-year on Wednesday.

title: Ackerley Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1.9 million related to the sale of assets in both the quarter and year.c-Net loss and included a loss of $ 22.2 million from the sale of assets in both the quarter and year.

title: Fred B. Black, 80; Lobbyist Was Part Of 1960's Scandal
description: Fred B. Black Jr., an aerospace lobbyist who became ensnared in a political scandal in the early 1960's, died Friday at a nursing home in Wheaton, Md. He was 80 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Lindberg Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included a $ 500,000 charge for the establishment of a valulation reserve against the company's former investment in its international affiliate, Lindberg do Brasil, which was sold in May.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Reeves Will Be Busy Putting Pieces in Place
description: The reports on Dan Reeves's golfing vacation in Indian Wells, Calif., indicate he has been having a good time. John Saeman, Reeves's friend and a cable-television executive from Denver, said that "he has been beating the devil out of me."

title: Ultimate Alchemy: Sludge to Gold; Big New York Export May Make Desert, and Budget, Bloom
description: Whether the cargo wanders the world endlessly on a barge, or is hauled by rail to the Midwest where armed guards refuse to accept it, and whether it travels as solid waste or in giant mounds of processed sludge, nobody wants any part of New York's monumental collection of garbage.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 24:

description: To the Editor:

description: The Economy

title: Why Dr. Kevorkian Was Called In
description: Last Wednesday a man named Jack Miller dropped his hand, thereby pulling a clip off the plastic tubing that connected a canister of carbon monoxide to a mask over his face. The gadget was yet another of the egregious Dr. Jack Kevorkian's suicide devices, and Mr. Miller was the ninth person to take advantage of his ingenuity. Eighteen minutes later Mr. Miller was dead.

title: Chelsea Clinton Can Transfer to Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: As Civil War in Angola Intensifies, Pretoria Denies Aiding Rebels
description: Almost from the moment that Angola began slipping back into civil war after failed elections in September, South Africa has been fending off charges that it was secretly aiding the Angolan rebels led by Jonas Savimbi.

description: Jackie Cain and Roy Kral The Chestnut Room Tavern on the Green

description: Otrabanda Company Downtown Art Company 64 East Fourth Street East Village

title: Health-Mor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included acquisition-related costs of $ 113,230 in the latest quarter and $ 129,600 in the year-ago quarter.

title: I.B.M. Payout Cut Seen
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to cut its common-stock dividend by tomorrow, when its directors conclude a two-day meeting. The company has paid $1.21 a share quarterly since June 1989, a payout costing about $2.5 billion a year. Last week, I.B.M. reported a 1992 loss of $4.96 billion. Frank A. Metz, the company's chief financial officer, said last month that he was worried about whether it would earn enough this year to cover its dividend payments.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Don Grolnick Sweet Basil

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 12 about a group of Saudi investors that bought a $100 million stake in Saks Fifth Avenue misstated the relationship between Investcorp, the Bahrain-based investment company that controls Saks, and Gucci S.p.A., the luxury goods retailer. Investcorp owns a 50 percent stake in Gucci; Maurizio Gucci owns the other 50 percent.

title: Tape May Help U.S. Prosecute In Beating Case
description: Ten days before a new trial of four police officers accused of beating Rodney G. King, a newly disclosed document suggests that the officers might have been punishing Mr. King for leading them on a high-speed chase.

title: California Inmates Win Better Prison AIDS Care
description: In this state's huge, troubled correctional system, the prison at Vacaville, formally known as the California Medical Facility, stands out as a special monument to misery.

title: Child Welfare Problems Started at the Top
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas A. Dorsey Is Dead at 93; Known as Father of Gospel Music
description: Thomas A. Dorsey, who was widely known as the father of gospel music, died on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 93 years old.

title: Patricia Bleznak, H. A. Silverstein
description: Patricia Bleznak, the daughter of Sally Cooper Bleznak of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Alan D. Bleznak of Penn Valley, Pa., was married yesterday to Howard Alan Silverstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Silverstein of Delray Beach, Fla. Cantor Bruce Ruben officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: 42d Street Project Remains on Track
description: While signs of 42d Street's long-planned redevelopment remain overshadowed by the area's boarded-up stores, bureaucratic delays and a lingering recession, business and government leaders say the project remains in full gear -- albeit on a smaller scale -- and that indications of a new commercial vitality are starting to emerge.

title: Corporate Bonds Shine, Despite Flood of Issues
description: When Michael H. Walsh, the chairman of Tenneco Inc., announced last week that he had a brain tumor but would continue to run the company, some corporate analysts were expecting the price of the company's bonds to drop.

title: Dance in Review
description: Kenneth Tosti 'Time Piece' Joseph Papp Public Theater/Susan Stein Shiva Theater Through Sunday

title: Review/Theater; The Ties That Bind And Bind Too Tightly
description: In "A Distance From Calcutta" the playwright P. J. Barry returns to the imaginary town of Jericho, R.I., modeled on the place of his childhood, to explore the battles of another of those families that intrigue him: families whose members find their competition with one another so engrossing they scarcely notice, until it is too late, that they may be doing irreparable damage to people outside their ranks.

title: Marshall Is Remembered as More Than a Justice
description: Those who worked closely with Justice Thurgood Marshall -- his law clerks, colleagues on the bench and fellow lawyers -- remembered him yesterday as a larger-than-life presence who left a lasting imprint on the nation, as well as on their personal lives and careers.

title: New York Post Finds a Reprieve In Investor Who May Buy Paper
description: On the brink of announcing a suspension of publication, The New York Post found temporary reprieve last night in a wealthy investor who said he might buy the embattled newspaper. The Post, meanwhile, declared that it would publish today and fight on for survival.

title: Vanity Fair Is Doing Nicely, But Out of the Spotlight
description: How does a magazine become hot? More to the point, how does a hot magazine stay hot?

title: U.S. WATCHING IRAQ FOR AIR DEFENSES
description: The United States and its allies are keeping a close eye on signs that Iraq is installing new air defenses in zones where Iraqi flights are banned, Defense Secretary Les Aspin said today.

title: Beverly Hills Fan Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CHRONICLE
description: Dr. WILLIAM T. SPECK , a 52-year-old pediatrician, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Presbyterian Hospital at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, it was announced last week by SEYMOUR MILSTEIN , chairman of the hospital's board of trustees. Dr. Speck will assume the office on Feb. 1.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A United States Senator from Hawaii, the Brooklyn-born chief rabbi of an Israeli West Bank community, and an organization of disabled Israeli war veterans will receive the 10th annual Defender of Jerusalem Awards. The $100,000 prize that will be divided among the recipients will be presented by the Jabotinsky Foundation Thursday at the Plaza Hotel. The foundation is named for Vladimir Jabotinsky, a Zionist, philosopher and mentor of many Israeli leaders.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about taxis and buses that run on natural gas and electricity misidentified Tyrone Cunningham in some editions. He is a driver for the Clean Air Cab Company of Washington.

title: E.D.S. Silent On Deal Talk
description: A spokesman for the Electronic Data Systems Corporation declined to comment yesterday on reports that its parent company, the General Motors Corporation, might sell an equity stake in E.D.S.

title: Review/Music; A Vision Sober And Clear
description: One happy result of post-Soviet-era stumblings toward free enterprise has been the Russian National Orchestra, organized three years ago by the conductor and pianist Mikhail Pletnev and recruited from Moscow's many symphonic ensembles. The Russian National has been touring North America and alighted at Carnegie Hall on Thursday and Friday nights.

title: Review/Music; Cleveland In Angry, Eccentric Concerto
description: There was something impressively economical about the way in which Christoph von Dohnanyi led the Cleveland Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Though the program included an almost aggressively eclectic work by Shulamit Ran ("Concert Piece" for piano and orchestra) along with a late-Romantic symphony overflowing with sweet and robust instrumental conversation (Dvorak's Seventh Symphony), nothing was done to excess.

title: Wright Stands Tall, But Hall Falls Short
description: Having inherited the unfortunate responsibility of defending the honor and dwindling glory of the Big East Conference -- hey, somebody had to do it -- the Seton Hall Pirates did their part today.

title: Many Legislators Reluctant To Hold Iraq Loans Inquiry
description: Dismayed by the collapse of the lengthy Iran-contra investigation, many in Congress say they are deeply reluctant to begin any major inquiry into another foreign policy morass: whether the Bush Administration covertly armed Iraq before the Persian Gulf war and later tried to cover up its involvement.

title: On the Menu, Steak Bucks Trend
description: The general manager was proud to report that Dan Quayle had once eaten in his restaurant, and so had George Bush as Vice President. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, he said, was a regular, and these days so is James Carville, the Clinton campaign strategist.

title: Notes on Justice; Who's in Charge? Bush Holdover Says He Is, but Two Clinton Men Differ
description: Without a new Attorney General, the Justice Department is being run by a kind of three-headed monster.

title: Kuwait City Journal; A Big Surprise for the G.I.'s: Back to the Desert
description: When Capt. Michael P. Maughan left Kuwait after the Persian Gulf war two years ago, he thought he had seen the last of the flat desert wasteland that had been his home for six months.

title: Television
description: NETWORK television has a new series that is an indisputable hit, one that defied expectations and made the conventional wisdom about the industry look silly.

title: CHRONICLE

The $100,000 prize that will be divided among the recipients will be presented by the Jabotinsky Foundation Thursday at the Plaza Hotel. The foundation is named for Vladimir Jabotinsky, a Zionist, philosopher and mentor of many Israeli leaders.

description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Review/Theater; A Hesitant Henry V On a Passive Course
description: When last sighted in Shakespeare, Mark Rylance was playing a pajama-clad Hamlet lolling around the castle at Elsinore like a late-rising house guest waiting for brunch to be served. This Royal Shakespeare Company production was later restaged at regional theaters in the United States. In "Henry V" (at St. Clement's), Mr. Rylance is dressed in black and is seemingly ready to meet the demands of his kingly office. But the performance is so enervated as to give the impression that the actor is still sleepwalking.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week:

title: Cuban Olympic Runner Badly Burned at Home
description: ANA QUIROT, Cuba's star middle-distance runner, was reported in critical but stable condition yesterday from extensive burns suffered in what was described as a household accident.

title: IDB Acquires New Company
description: IDB Communications Group, a small California telecommunications company that provides international long-distance service for corporations, said Friday that it had agreed to buy TRT Communications Inc. for 4.5 million IDB shares worth about $104.6 million.

title: Risk-Shy Utilities Avoid Trading Emission Credits
description: When Congress amended the Clean Air Act in 1990, backers said the law would cut $1 billion a year from the cost of reducing pollution, introducing free-market efficiencies to a command-and-control system by letting utilities trade "emissions allowances" among themselves.

The $100,000 prize that will be divided among the recipients will be presented by the Jabotinsky Foundation Thursday at the Plaza Hotel. The foundation is named for Vladimir Jabotinsky, a Zionist, philosopher and mentor of many Israeli leaders.

title: Iraq Denies Firing
description: Saying its forces are observing a cease-fire, the Government today denied a report by the Pentagon that its air defenses had fired on three American fighter planes in southern Iraq on Saturday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: He is probably the only person ever to have been appointed to the Supreme Court who would have had a place in American history before his appointment. -- JAMES O. FREEDMAN, President of Dartmouth and former clerk to Thurgood Marshall. [ B9:2. ]

title: In Marshall's Own Words
description: ON SEGREGATION "The trouble with the doctrine of separate but equal [ is that it ] assumes that two things are equal." -- Argument before the Supreme Court in Brown v. Board of Education (1954)

title: EAST EUROPE SAYS BARRIERS TO TRADE HURT ITS ECONOMIES
description: The former Communist nations of Eastern Europe say that further advances in building their free-market economies could be blocked by rising trade tensions with the European Community, by far their biggest export market.

title: Ex-Champions Haunt Skating Victors
description: This had been their week to frighten away the ghosts, to chase Brian Boitano, Katarina Witt and Kristi Yamaguchi from the stubborn American memory.

title: A First for American?
description: Japan's tradition-steeped world of sumo has gone eight months with no one considered worthy to hold its most exalted rank, and the next yokozuna (grand champion) probably won't be Japanese. The American CHAD ROWAN moved into position yesterday to become the first foreigner to gain that rank by winning his second straight tournament, in Tokyo.

title: John Corbin Eddison Development Expert, 71
description: John Corbin Eddison, an expert on economic development who was a former director of Near East Affairs for the United States Agency for International Development, died Friday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Gordon Gano The Knitting Factory

title: Georgia-Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 9,000,000 in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge of $ 55,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.c-Net lossd-Included an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 45,000,000 in the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge of $ 63,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Post Rescuer Built Wealth From $2,000
description: Steven Hoffenberg, the businessman who emerged yesterday as the latest potential savior of The New York Post, is a 48-year-old self-described workaholic who built a small credit business into a $1 billion-a-year enterprise.

title: Hepburn's Role As Ambassador Is Paid Tribute
description: They buried Audrey Hepburn here in a simple pine coffin in the village cemetery on a bluff overlooking Lake Geneva, surrounded by fields and vineyards with the Jura mountains dark blue in the background.

title: Kurt Masur to Discuss Creation of Concerts
description: The New York Philharmonic is to open a series of five monthly talks on the orchestra's relationship to New York City tonight at 6:30 in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Kurt Masur, the Philharmonic's music director, and Carlos Moseley, the managing director from 1961 to 1970, are to discuss "Selecting the Music: How a Concert Is Created."

title: Lockout at Chen's Supercomputer Company
description: Supercomputer Systems Inc., whose financial support from I.B.M. is ending, locked out technical workers at its Eau Claire, Wis., building on Saturday and today, fueling speculation that the company is close to ending operations.

title: 3 Pirates Left With Helpless Feeling
description: The statistics indicate that Seton Hall's front court did the job against North Carolina in a matchup of two of the nation's best college basketball teams. But the Pirates' backcourt performed horribly against the No. 3-ranked Tar Heels, and that proved to be the difference.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Metro Section on Tuesday about a sculpture at 77 Water Street in Manhattan misidentified it. It is "The Month of June," by George E. Adamy.

title: Thorn Apple Valley reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 11
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Bell Sports reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from loss on early extinquishment of debt of $ 298,000 in the both the quarter and 6 months and the 6 months also included a one-time gain from adoption of SFAS 109, Accounting For Income Taxes of $ 700,000, or 10 cents a share.c-Included an extraordinary tax gain of $ 549,000, or 11 cents a share, and $ 670,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.Bell Sports Corp. said net income for both the quarter and 6 months included a pre-tax charge of $ 950,000 for anticipated costs of consolidating U.S. operations.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Johnson Goes to Great Heights to Get Point Across
description: Dallas Cowboys Coach Jimmy Johnson tonight recalled a pep talk he gave to his team last week.

title: Lately, More Antiquities Can Go Home Again
description: An ancient bronze-and-silver model of a leopard, which was a shadowy presence in the art market for years before it wound up in the hands of a leading New York City art collector, is going home, to England.

title: Devils' Failure Explained In Missing Persons Report
description: There was a valid reason that the negatives overshadowed the positives by a wide margin for New Jersey on Saturday night, but the Devils offered no excuses for their 7-5 loss to the Bruins at Boston Garden.

title: Hitting the Wall And Back Again
description: Throughout his childhood, tennis has been his judge, jury, taskmaster -- and sometimes his jailer. Vincent Spadea went undefeated at 14, self-destructed at 17 and just last month experienced an 11th-hour resurrection at 18. But in the manner of a model prisoner, he has not yet had his fill of tennis. He understands the sport also represents his ticket to life's finer side.

title: Bay State Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cram Comes Out of Nowhere, Runs Off With the Miami Mile
description: When Steve Cram awoke today to participate in the elite mile portion of the American Airlines Miami Mile, he was told to expect windy, cloudy weather for the race.

title: Sybron Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 449,000 related to the sale of the Brazilian operations effective Oct. 1, 1992.On a pro forma basis, assuming the May 1992 initial public offering of shares had taken place at the beginning of the year and excluding the sale of Brazilian operations, net income would have been $ 5.2 million, or 23 cents a diluted share, compared with $ 3 million, or 10 cents.

title: Balkan Negotiators Urge an End To the Latest Fighting in Croatia
description: The leaders of talks aimed at solving the hostilities in Bosnia and Herzegovina spent much of the day urging an end to the fighting that has erupted in neighboring Croatia, where peace was achieved just over a year ago.

title: Carjacking Suspect Killed
description: A police officer fatally shot a suspected carjacker and another suspect was arrested after a chase by car and on foot in Crown Heights late Saturday, the police said yesterday. Christopher Stephenson, 19, of 662 East 95th Street in Brooklyn, was armed with a fully loaded .45-caliber automatic when he was shot in the side of the lower back near Union Street and Kingston Avenue.

title: A Roller-Coaster Day At The New York Post
description: From midmorning to midafternoon, hundreds of New York Post workers voted to cut their paychecks -- meaning that for the next month they would work four days for three days' pay. They worried that a "no" vote would mean no more jobs and a "yes" vote would only buy time until the money ran out once and for all.

title: Pascual Perez Was Hard to Hit, but Now He's Just Hard to Find
description: "Pascual Perez, please."

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. WILLIAM T. SPECK , a 52-year-old pediatrician, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Presbyterian Hospital at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, it was announced last week by SEYMOUR MILSTEIN , chairman of the hospital's board of trustees. Dr. Speck will assume the office on Feb. 1.

title: Review/Rock; Throwing a Tantrum That Speaks for Youth
description: One of rock music's uses is to proclaim what listeners can't muster the courage or the words to say themselves. In songs that articulate the frustrated attempts of the young to claim a space in the world, the music's clamor and blast is as important as whatever fragmented lyrics break through. The sound of sentences forming and falling apart draws youths to rock, because that sound is so much like their daily attempts at self-expression.

title: Those Fighting Illness Give to Neediest
description: Pain dominates their lives. They shuttle in and out of hospitals. They are forever wondering whether they have the strength to make it through the day. But even as they contend with serious illnesses that have left them weak and despondent, they are thinking about others who are also suffering.

title: Books of The Times; Fear, Loathing and Fun On the Thompson Trail
description: Hunter The Strange and Savage Life of Hunter S. Thompson By E. Jean Carroll

title: 4 Finalists Vie In Reebok Review
description: Reebok International Ltd. said that it had narrowed to four finalists a review on its Boks footwear account, handled for the last year by Toth Inc. in Carlisle, Mass. In addition to Toth, the finalists are three New York-based shops: Ammirati & Puris; Chiat/Day, which handles the company's Reebok brand, and Kirshenbaum & Bond. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated they could reach $10 million.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Agreed to terms with Mike Kingery, outfielder, on a minor-league contract. Basketball National Basketball Association INDIANA PACERS -- Placed Kenny Williams, forward, on the injured list. Activated LaSalle Thompson, forward, from the injured list.

title: Pentagon Chief Warns Clinton On Gay Policy
description: Defense Secretary Les Aspin has advised President Clinton in a confidential memorandum that a majority of Congress, in addition to top military leaders, would oppose any immediate attempt by the Administration to lift the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces.

title: High School In Rare Link With College
description: A few years ago, while dabbling in some fund raising for public schools, Donald Schupak, Syracuse University class of 1964, was taught a lesson by a savvy Harlem principal: an entire generation of unmotivated, unfocused and disenfranchised students was being lost in large, anonymous New York City high schools.

title: BENTSEN SUGGESTS BROAD ENERGY TAX WILL BE PROPOSED
description: Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen suggested today that the Clinton Administration would propose a tax on all forms of energy to help lower the budget deficit and encourage conservation.

title: Patents
description: THE PARHELION CORPORATION is using some of the latest tools of molecular biology to develop vaccines that are safer or more effective than existing ones.

He is smart, cares about the world outside of basketball and is extremely friendly. And talking to him these days, one might not notice that Rumeal Robinson is fighting for his basketball life. Again.

Holik Breaks Thumb
description: The Devils announced yesterday that forward BOBBY HOLIK would be out six to eight weeks because of a broken left thumb. Holik, 22, played with a swollen thumb Saturday night in Boston as the Devils lost to the Bruins. His thumb was apparently broken Friday night in the victory at home over Montreal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons Lose Another Charles Barkley and Kevin Johnson each scored 24 points last night as the Phoenix Suns beat Detroit, 121-119, at Auburn Hills, Mich., handing the Pistons their sixth straight loss. The Pistons nearly overcame a 16-point Phoenix lead in the final seven minutes, but Terry Mills's 3-pointer spun out as the final buzzer sounded. Detroit is now 0-10 in games in which Dennis Rodman didn't play. He missed last night's game with a strained calf muscle. The Suns led by 109-93 with 6 minutes 45 seconds left, but had to fight off a furious Piston rally to hang on for the victory. The Pistons went on a 23-10 run, and Gerald Glass's tip-in with 35 seconds to play pulled them within 119-116. Kevin Johnson made one of two free throws with 14.8 seconds left, but Joe Dumars hit a 3-pointer with 7 seconds left to make it a 1-point game. Johnson was fouled again, and again made one free throw, giving Detroit a chance to go for the victory, but Mills's shot just missed. (AP) Hawks 117, Kings 106: Dominique Wilkins scored 38 points and Kevin Willis had 30 points and 17 rebounds as the Hawks rallied in the third period to beat Sacramento at Atlanta. Wilkins, scoring at least 30 points for the fourth time in five games, hit a fallaway jump shot with 4:07 to play in the third to give Atlanta a 73-72 lead it never relinquished. The victory was the 100th for Bob Weiss as coach of the Hawks and was Atlanta's seventh in its last 10 games. (AP) N.H.L. Canadiens Beat Bruins Rookie Ed Ronan scored 14 seconds into overtime, beating Boston goaltender John Blue to give the Canadiens a 3-2 victory over the Bruins at Montreal last night. Boston's Adam Oates forced overtime with his 30th goal of the season by beating Patrick Roy on a rebound with 42 seconds remaining in the third period after Blue had been pulled for an extra skater. Ronan, a native of Boston, drove toward the Bruins' net on the decisive play, putting the puck behind Blue for only his fourth goal in 37 games this season. The game featured a missed penalty shot by Montreal's Denis Savard, 2 minutes 34 seconds into the second period. (AP)

title: Grossman Given Less to Do

The buyer is a group led by Invest S.p.A., a merchant bank. Pirelli also is part of the group and will hold 12 percent of Superga.

description: Allegations of "possible sexual misconduct" involving one or more members of the Portland Trail Blazers are being investigated by the Salt Lake City police, according to a department spokesman.

title: Independence Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4,378,000, or 39 cents a share, which reflects adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 109, Accounting for Income Taxes.The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Alza Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $ 101.3 million for the purchase of in-process research and development related to the acquisition of Bio-Electro Systems Inc. common stock and the restructuring of its arrangements with On-Site Therapeutics for both the quarter and year.

title: INVESTORS' SUITS AGAINST PHILIPS ELECTRONICS DISMISSED
description: Five securities fraud lawsuits filed by investors against Philips Electronics N.V. and its officers were dismissed yesterday. Judge Thomas Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan agreed to throw out the suits after the investors said they were not going to win. The investors, who bought Philips securities between Feb. 28 and June 16, said the company's officers had failed to warn about the disappointing prospects for 1992 earnings. On June 17, Philips's stock plunged after the company said that its 1992 sales would fall below expectations.

title: Corning Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 6,600,000, or 3 cents a share, and $ 7,700,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a charge of $ 286,600,000 from the adoption of FASB 106 and FASB 109.c-Net incomeLatest quarter's income from continuing operations of $ 34,400,000, or 18 cents a share, included a charge of $ 32.1 million, after tax and minority interest, for the restructing of operations in Brazil, a $ 13.2 million reduction in equity earnings to reflect its share of a restructuring charge recorded by Dow Corning Corp., and $ 5.1 million in increased ongoing postretirement benefit expense from the adoption of FASB 106.Fiscal 1993's income from continuing operations of $ 266,300,000, or $ 1.40 a share, included a charge of $ 32.1 million, after tax and minority interest, for the restructing of operations in Brazil, a $ 37.7 million reduction in equity earnings to reflect its share of a restructuring charge recorded by Dow Corning Corp. and costs associated with breast implant products, and $ 21.3 million in increased ongoing postretirement benefit expense from the adoption of FASB 106.

title: UF Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' per share earnings and shares outstanding were not applicable; the company converted to a stock company from a mutual company on Oct. 30, 1991.

title: Ashland Coal Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Boulevard Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,826,000 from adoption of SFAS 109.c-Net lossThe bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Clinton Says He Has Made No Decision on Energy Tax
description: As lawmakers and industry officials responded unenthusiastically to suggestions of a new energy tax, President Clinton said today that he had not yet decided whether to support the idea.

title: North Side Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING
description: THOUGH yellow power ties, "Don't Worry, Be Happy" and hostile takeovers are unlikely to return anytime soon, one aspect of the 1980's is making a comeback: a Super Bowl that marketers are clamoring to sponsor.

title: Frank Freidel, Biographer of F.D.R., Is Dead at 76
description: Frank Freidel, a noted biographer of President Franklin D. Roosevelt who taught for 26 years at Harvard, died yesterday in the university's Stillman Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 76 and lived in Belmont, Mass.

title: Public Service Co. of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax loss of $ 8.4 million from sale of properties and an after-tax loss of $ 16.8 million from its Synhytech project.

title: It's Goodbye Hirsch, and Hello Richter
description: The Rangers' convoluted goaltending plot, which thickened into a three-way drama recently when rookie Corey Hirsch was promoted from Binghamton and incumbent Mike Richter was demoted, thinned yesterday.

title: Kissinger Averted a Distortion of History
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Attacks Rebels in Somalia; Marine Is Slain Later
description: United States-led forces today attacked rebel troops who were said to be advancing toward the southern city of Kismayu, the first use of military intervention to enforce a cease-fire in this shattered country, American officials said. In Mogadishu tonight, an American marine was shot and killed while on patrol, the Pentagon said.

title: Howard University Journal; Where Marshall Blazed, Students Take Up Torch
description: Most of today's students at the Howard University Law School had not even been born when Thurgood Marshall was making history. So there was no outpouring of grief by his bronze bust today. It stood alone in a windowed corridor of his alma mater.

title: Musicians On Strike: The Causes And Effects
description: When the negotiating committee from Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians ended a tense 10-hour meeting by announcing its decision to strike, just before midnight on Friday, Joseph Rosenthal was aghast. Mr. Rosenthal, the lawyer representing the nine orchestras that are bargaining as a consortium with the freelance musicians who fill their ranks, told his adversaries, "In 25 years of labor negotiations, I have never before seen a strike called after only four meetings and before the parties had really defined their positions or reached an impasse." But union spokesmen said that both sides had presented their positions and that an impasse had clearly been reached.

title: Chesapeake Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 3,400,000 for reorganization of Finess consumer products business, costs associated with sale of wood treating business and write-off of older equipment replaced by the start-up of a new recovery boiler at the West Point, Va., mill in the quarter and $ 9,665,000 for adoption of SFAS 106 and SFAS 109 in the year.

title: Atlanfed Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUPER BOWL XXVII: TV Sports; The Networks Leave Room for Dessert
description: For NBC, the Super Bowl is like a luscious creme brulee after a long, dyspeptic dinner. Having lost about $100 million (including $40 million this season) on its National Football League contract, NBC heads to Pasadena for its first Super Bowl since 1989 in the hope of saving a smidgen of financial face. NBC paid $752 million in 1990 for four years of N.F.L. games, the lowest outlay of the three networks (ABC paid $900 million and CBS paid $1.06 billion). According to network insiders, NBC has valued the Super Bowl at $40 million. There is no N.F.L.-specified Super Bowl rights fee, and a network can allocate its Super Bowl fee in any way it wishes.

title: Gregorian Chant and 60's Rock In a Dance That Spans Centuries
description: The audience pushes back into the theater. There are the usual rustling of programs and hurried attempts at finishing intermission conversations. Then the lights go down, and there is that vividly anticipatory silence before the dance begins.

title: U.S. Robotics reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Hutchinson Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: John Corbin Eddison, Development Expert, 73
description: John Corbin Eddison, an expert on economic development who was a former director of Near East Affairs for the United States Agency for International Development, died Friday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: River Life Through U.S. Broadly Degraded
description: TWO decades of Federal controls have sharply reduced the vast outflows of sewage and industrial chemicals into America's rivers and streams, yet the life they contain may be in deeper trouble than ever.

title: Pact for Polonia
description: Outfielder LUIS POLONIA and the California Angels split the $850,000 difference between the figures they submitted to an arbitrator. Polonia, who earned $1.65 million last season, agreed with the team on a $2,475,000 contract yesterday.

title: Novacare Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $ 3,989,000 for merger and other non-recurring expenses.

title: BELLSOUTH CO. (N)
description: Despite an increase in quarterly revenue for cellular telephone service, the BellSouth Corporation's earnings were hurt by a sharp rise in operating expenses. Such costs rose 7.5 percent in the fourth quarter, to $3.2 billion, from $2.98 billion a year earlier. Wireless communications revenue for cellular and paging devices rose 44 percent, to $334 million. Local-service revenue rose 10 percent, to $1.59 billion. As a result, Bell South's fourth-quarter earnings dropped 8.7 percent, to $353.4 million, or 72 cents a share.

title: Jones Laterals to Johnson, Who Laterals to Jones
description: The current Dallas Cowboys are about oil and money, about plans first hatched in Jerry Jones's University of Arkansas dormitory room. They are about Coach Jimmy Johnson's platinum hair and his supposedly superior 162 I.Q. They are about young, unflappable players who see the Super Bowl as just another television game of the week.

title: Stanford Telecommunications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Pact Is Set to Remain Until the Ball Drops
description: The collective bargaining agreement between major league club owners and players is scheduled to expire on Dec. 31, and Donald Fehr, the players' chief negotiator, indicated yesterday that the date will not change.

title: Chess
description: Nigel Short bounced back into the lead in the final world championship candidates' match by winning Games 9 and 10 from Jan Timman Saturday and yesterday in San Lorenzo de El Escorial, Spain. The 28-year-old English grandmaster had earlier drawn Game 8 and now has 6 points to his 41-year-old Dutch opponent's 4.

title: Quirot Gives Birth
description: The Olympic runner ANA FIDELIA QUIROT, who is hospitalized with severe burns, has given birth to a baby girl, doctors said yesterday.

title: Review/Fashion; In Lacroix's Hands, Couture Still Dazzles
description: The answer was evident at the Christian Lacroix show, one of the first of the spring-summer haute couture openings over the weekend: sufficient talent makes many solutions possible. The question, which dominates conversations with couturiers, their backers and clients, is, "Is couture viable?"

title: Cedar Fair reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.Latest results included operations of Dorney Park and Wildwater Kingdom since its purchase on July 21, 1992.

title: A Chairman Stays Put
description: The search by American Express for new leadership ended yesterday when it announced that its chairman would remain and that he would also head the troubled Shearson Lehman Brothers brokerage subsidiary, even though the company's stock has declined under his stewardship.

title: Mexico Fights to Stop U.S. Execution
description: In the decade since Ramon Montoya was convicted of murdering a Dallas policeman, most of his relatives have stopped visiting, his name has faded from the newspapers, and opponents of capital punishment have moved on to other cases.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 DETROIT'S NEW ASSAULT

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Continental Bank N.A., Chicago, is offering $100 million of 7.875 percent subordinated bank notes due in 2003 at 99.868 to yield 7.894 percent through Lehman Brothers. Noncallable, the notes are rated Ba-2 by Moody's Investors Service, B- by Standard & Poor's and Bbb by Duff & Phelps.

title: Detroit to Seek Punitive Damages On Car Imports
description: In a clear test of the Clinton Administration's attitude on trade policies, the Big Three auto makers have told Federal trade officials that they intend to seek punitive duties on all imported cars, four people involved in the cases said today.

title: Inter-Tel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 4,841,000 in the quarter and $ 5,148,000 in the year.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: RABIN DOESN'T LIKE FORMAT OF TALKS
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin today criticized the basic format of the Middle East peace talks as "not a successful one" but said it would be "a waste of time" for Israel to try changing it.

title: Tokyo Journal; Sumo Bows and Opens Sacred Door to U.S. Star
description: Legend has it that 3,000 years ago, two gods took their fight for control of the Japanese islands to the sumo ring. With such a heritage, it is no wonder that sumo wrestling has remained the quintessential Japanese sport.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: SEXUALITY AND THE MENTALLY RETARDED

title: ACC TO SELL CELLULAR BUSINESS FOR $43.5 MILLION
description: In a move to concentrate on its long-distance operations, the ACC Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell the Danbury Cellular Telephone Company, which serves more than 4,200 subscribers in central Kentucky, to a unit of the Horizon Cellular Telephone Company for $43.5 million in cash. Horizon, based in Doylestown, Pa., owns and operates cellular telephone systems, principally in rural areas in the United States. ACC, based in Rochester, which provides long-distance telephone service throughout the Northeast, is the second-largest long-distance reseller in Canada.

title: SHIFT OF SPENDING SEEN AS A BENEFIT
description: The Federal Government could generate more than 12,000 jobs by shifting $3 billion from military industries to state and local jurisdictions, according to a Government study released today.

title: Putnam Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1991 year's per share earnings included charge of 44 cents a share from the cumulative effect of accounting change for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

title: Gay Couples Also Need Economic Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The music will be of a different sort at a fashion show today: writers, editors, buyers and browsers who turn up to see NICK HILTON'S fall '93 men's wear collection at Nell's on West 14th Street will hear songs by Nick Hilton.

title: Laclede Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects special second-quarter non-cash charges of $ 14.5 million before taxes for restructuring of wire operations, and $ 4.2 million before taxes for estimated environmental costs related to the processing of electric arc furnace dust.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Olympia & York Liquidation Plan Advances
description: The unsecured creditors of bankrupt Olympia & York Developments Ltd. today overwhelmingly approved an orderly liquidation of the Canadian operations of what was once the world's biggest property development company.

title: Crompton & Knowles reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt of $ 3,000,000 in the quarter and $ 8,800,000 in the year which included charge of $ 3,000,000 from early extinguishment of debt, and charge of $ 5,800,000 for adoption of Statement of Fiscal Accounting Standards 106.

title: NS Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Parkvale Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bystander Is Killed In Domestic Dispute
description: A bystander was shot to death during an apparent domestic dispute in Brooklyn's Borough Park last night when a man fired a shotgun at his girlfriend and hit someone else, the police said.

title: Century Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 20-Year Term for Woman In Death of Exxon Chief
description: Irene J. Seale was sentenced to 20 years in prison today for her part in the fatal kidnapping last year of a top Exxon executive, Sidney J. Reso. The court rejected her argument that she was a battered wife who was forced into the crime by her husband, Arthur, but recognized her quick and full cooperation with law-enforcement officials after her capture.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADT SECURITY SYSTEMS INC., Parsippany, N.J., a unit of ADT Ltd., named Karl E. Guerra senior vice president for marketing and technology.

title: Amplicon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: A Vision That Goes Beyond 100 Yards
description: Solomon Wilcots offered the most memorable line about the riots in the Overtown section of Miami that jolted the National Football League and its annual January bash, this one Super Bowl XXIII in 1989 that featured the San Francisco 49ers and the Cincinnati Bengals. Wilcots, now a Pittsburgh Steelers safety but then with the Bengals, said: "We went to the movies to see 'Mississippi Burning.' We came out and we saw Miami burning."

title: Rally Drops Long Bond Yield to 6-Year Low
description: The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to its lowest level in six years yesterday in a bond-market rally touched off by comments of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bensten over the weekend that raised hopes of deficit reduction.

title: By Design; Beating Up on the Hat
description: The hat is a hit here. The Basque beret that so many women (as well as men) were wearing last fall must have whetted an appetite for the real thing. Now, one sees young women everywhere with some sort of brimmed hat plunked firmly on their heads. Most hats are variations of a small brimmed mannish fedora. Velvet is the favorite fabric, and black, of course, the preferred color. But the most important thing is that the hat look a bit beat up -- as if one had sat on it by mistake. Such mistreatment gives it the properly degage look.

title: Biosphere Gets Pure Oxygen to Combat Health Woes
description: EAGER to avoid a medical emergency, leaders of Biosphere 2 in Arizona have begun pumping tons of pure oxygen into the miniature glass-enclosed world inhabited by eight humans. Oxygen levels have risen from 14.5 percent to 17.5 percent and at the operation's end will stand at about 19 percent, still shy of the 21 percent found at sea level.

title: Ashland Oil reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $ 267,442,000 from an accounting adjustment.The company said 1991 figures have been restated to reflect the adoption of FAS 106 and 109, effective Oct. 1, 1991.Revenue represented total revenues including exercise taxes.

title: In New Climate of Freedom, Few Russian Newspapers Thrive
description: At a time when subscriptions to the Russian press are down by 50 percent and most major newspapers are engaged in an unseemly scramble for government handouts, the advertising department at Moskovsky Komsomolets is furiously busy. Advertisers who want to appear in the paper's daily four-page spread have to wait for more than a month, while the line to place classifieds spills out of the cramped third-floor offices and into the stairwell.

title: Pacific Bell Switch Deal Biggest Ever
description: Pacific Bell, California's main telephone company, said yesterday that it was undertaking an ambitious $1 billion plan to further modernize its local telephone service by 1997.

title: Carbon Monoxide Gas Is Used by Brain Cells As a Neurotransmitter
description: THE simple gas carbon monoxide is used by nerve cells to signal each other, researchers have found in a discovery that could open the way to a new understanding of how the brain operates.

title: Florida Progress Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 2.4 million from discontinued operations in the quarter and year.Florida Progress said that it took a one-time, retroactive depreciation expense reduction that increased 1992 earnings by $ 5.6 million, as a result of a settlement involving base rates for wholesale customers.

title: Ear Shot May Equal 10 Days of Oral Drug
description: A SINGLE injection of a drug often used to treat pneumonia and meningitis also cures childhood ear infections and is as effective as 10 days of an oral medication, a new study says.

title: Foundation Health reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 12.4 million and corresponding tax effects related to the purchases in October of Century MediCorp Inc. and Occupational Health Services.Year-ago periods' earnings were restated to reflect the purchases of Century and Occupational Health Services. Each has been accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Behind the premiere of a new concerto by NED ROREM next week is the tale of a half-century-old friendship between the composer and GARY GRAFFMAN, the pianist.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bosnia's Brutal Camps
description: President Clinton inherited many problems but none more brutal than this: the 70,000 Bosnians who languish in 135 Serb-run concentration camps. Serbian officials promised five months ago to close the camps and release the detainees. They haven't. Prisoners have been murdered; others suffer bitter winter winds, short rations and torture.

title: Variety Is The Spice Of Success For Bills
description: When Ted Marchibroda resigned as the Bills' offensive coordinator to become the Indianapolis Colts' head coach, everyone thought Buffalo's potent offense, characterized by the no-huddle scheme and prolific point production, would languish.

title: NYNEX TO BEGIN BUYBACK OF 8 MILLION SHARES
description: The Nynex Corporation today will begin to repurchase up to eight million of its common shares over a period of as long as 10 years. The buyback is related to Nynex's employee stock option plans. Nynex will also begin a separate repurchase program of 2.6 million common shares this year in connection with its employee savings, dividend reinvestment and stock purchase plans. Nynex, a regional Bell telephone company in New York and New England, has 207 million common shares outstanding. Its stock closed yesterday at $85.125, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rebels Lose Liberian Airport
description: West African peace enforcers have captured Liberia's main airport from rebels, soldiers from the multinational intervention force said today. There was no immediate confirmation from the headquarters of the six-nation West African army in Monrovia, the capital. But the rebel radio controlled by Charles Taylor, the guerrilla leader, also reported that the multinational force had seized Roberts Field International Airport, 28 miles outside Monrovia, on Saturday.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net loss and included restructuring charges of $ 283 million in the quarter and year, for timberlands and wood products, pulp and paper products, real estate, corporate and other segments; the year also included a charge of $ 61 million for accounting changes.

title: Electromagnetism Is Effective for Fractures
description: To the Editor:

title: Biotechnology Joint Venture
description: A New York biotechnology company will announce today that it has entered a strategic alliance with a Japanese pharmaceutical company to develop compounds that stimulate the growth of blood cells.

title: Review/Music; An Austrian Baritone Makes New York Debut In All-German Recital
description: By the time the Austrian baritone Wolfgang Holzmair finished singing the Schubert selections in his New York debut recital at the Frick Museum on Sunday afternoon, it was clear that his is a remarkable voice and a remarkable talent. The art of the lied is an art of compression: each vowel is an expression of deep sentiment; each vocal leap bears the weight of an operatic plot. And that was how, in these songs, Mr. Holzmair treated Schubert.

title: On My Mind; General Powell and The Gays
description: The President knows he will catch big trouble for it, but makes up his mind. He orders the armed forces to treat certain people exactly like all other Americans -- full duties in combat, full rights at all times.

title: Review/Film; A Village's Pogrom and Its Wider Resonances
description: "Get Thee Out," the new Russian film opening today at the Walter Reade Theater, examines anti-Semitism in czarist Russia, the exact time being unspecified though it seems to be around the turn of the century. It's the first feature to be directed by Dimitri Astrakhan, a St. Petersburg theater director who was born in 1957 and is himself a Jew.

title: Science vs. Women -- A Radical Solution
description: Science, like all human activity, has its individual cultural milieu. The culture of science evolved in a period when it was being practiced exclusively by men, and that has greatly influenced the outcome. It is a men's game and it continues to be played by men's rules.

title: Rollins Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest year's share earnings reflected 3-for-2 stock split on Dec. 10.

title: Newhall Land & Farming Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Holman's Run at Mile
description: STEVE HOLMAN, the latest in a long line of potentially great American milers, has studied JIM RYUN, MARTY LIQUOURI and others who have turned his 22-year-old life into a bundle of expectations.

title: Books of The Times; Groping for the Future as the Modern Age Ends
description: The End of the 20th Century And the End of the Modern Age By John Lukacs

title: Sex Adds to Fears of Parents of Retarded
description: A graying mother in Brooklyn, no stranger to worry, finds herself more troubled than usual in recent months. Every morning, she buys an armful of newspapers and reads whatever they offer about the ongoing trial across two rivers in Glen Ridge, N.J., a trial that is now in its 15th week.

title: Abington Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Excerpts From the Justices' Decision on State Prisoners Facing Execution
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in Herrera v. Collins, holding that a state prisoner facing execution for a murder he claims not to have committed is not ordinarily entitled to have that claim reviewed in Federal court. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the 6-to-3 majority opinion, which was joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy, Antonin Scalia, and Clarence Thomas; Justice Byron R. White did not sign the opinion but concurred in the result. Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote a dissenting opinion that was joined by Justices John Paul Stevens and David H. Souter. FROM THE OPINION By Chief Justice Rehnquist

title: Armor All Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title:
HORSE RACING;
Delahoussaye Is Galloping Toward Winner's Spotlight
description: There are monks who call more attention to themselves than Eddie Delahoussaye, who just might be the best jockey you've never really noticed. Delahoussaye prefers to fit into the background like Zelig, always there for the big events but trying to blend in. If he were in a school play, he would be the tree. Crises -- such as the care of his 17-year-old daughter, who is handicapped -- are handled with quiet strength. If Delahoussaye had a motto, it would be "Deal With It."

title: Major Oil Concerns Post Strong Profits in Quarter
description: Wall Street rediscovered oil today, as investors rushed to acquire stocks of major oil companies.

title: Gay Couples Also Need Economic Benefits; Clinton Should Proceed
description: To the Editor:

title: Accord Made For Savings In Trash Jobs
description: The Dinkins administration reached an agreement yesterday with the sanitation workers union to give workers at least one-third of any money saved through longer trash-pickup routes and other measures to increase productivity.

title: Christopher Vowing Change In Selection of Ambassadors
description: Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher made his debut before State Department employees today, pledging that the Clinton Administration would not appoint ambassadors solely because of their political connections and assuring them that he would bring career Foreign Service officers back into the State Department's decision-making.

title: No Headline
description: "She's better at organizing and leading people from a complex beginning to a certain end than anybody I've ever worked with in my life." -- PRESIDENT CLINTON on Hillary Rodham Clinton, whom he named to head a health-care task force. [ A1:5. ]

title: Thompson Opens An Office in Vietnam
description: In anticipation of the lifting of America's trade embargo with Vietnam, the J. Walter Thompson Company said it had opened a representative office in Hanoi and formed an agreement with that country's national advertising agency, Vinexad, which has offices in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.

title: Accounts
description: * Pofolks Inc., Nashville, to Meridian Communications, Lexington, Ky., to handle the family-style restaurant chain's advertising, marketing and public relations account, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $3.5 million to $4 million. * Riser Foods Inc., Cleveland, to Excel Media Services, Cleveland, to handle the Stop-n-Shop supermarket chain's media services, previously at Vitt Media International Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: It's Meadowlands North, as Parcells Hires Perkins
description: While Dan Reeves was apparently getting ready yesterday to sign on as the new Giants coach, two former Giants coaches were agreeing on a reunion in New England.

title: Tandycrafts Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Challenger to Florio Will Pay Back Taxes for Illegal Aliens
description: Christine Todd Whitman will pay back taxes totaling about $25,000 for two illegal aliens she employed to care for her children for about four years, according to a supporter involved in settling the matter.

title: Reginald Lewis, Financier, Is Honored at Service
description: Speakers from the many walks of life touched by Reginald Francis Lewis, who died last Tuesday at 50, gathered yesterday to honor the Wall Street lawyer and financier. Mr. Lewis, a resident of New York City and Paris, died of a cerebral hemorrhage related to cancer.

title: After Cold War, World's Space Plans Seek a More Down-to-Earth Basis
description: THE exploration of space, one of the triumphs of the 20th century, is undergoing a global retrenchment and restructuring that will leave it less showy, more substantive and more dependent on international cooperation and teamwork, experts say.

title: Ex-Communists Keep Key Posts in Slovenia
description: Slovenia got a new coalition Government today, approved by the 90-member Parliament constituted by national elections last month.

title: E. W. Kenworthy, 83, a Reporter Who Covered Capital With Flair
description: E. W. Kenworthy, a Washington correspondent for The New York Times who wrote about government and politics with flair and erudition for 20 years, died today at his home here. He was 83.

title: Metro-Richelieu reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 19
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Television; Palestinian Perspective On West Bank Life
description: "Journey to the Occupied Lands" gives a Palestinian-eye view of life under military occupation. Farmers tell Michael Ambrosino, the producer and reporter of the 90-minute documentary, of having their property confiscated for military purposes or for the benefit of Jewish settlers, and of enduring daily harassment by the authorities.

title: Hillary Clinton To Head Panel On Health Care
description: President Clinton today appointed his wife, Hillary, to head a committee to prepare legislation for overhauling the nation's health-care system. It is the most powerful official post ever assigned to a First Lady.

title: The Basement Sacked Talley
description: Either Darryl Talley is a great storyteller, or he is incredibly accident-prone.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the relocation of the May Department Stores Company's merchandising unit misidentified the chief executive of May Merchandising, who has since retired. He was Kenneth Kolker.

title: Going Undercover in the Computer Underworld
description: He patrols the back alleys of cyberspace at the edge of the electronic frontier. Traveling on beams of electrons, he is invisible, formless -- the ultimate undercover agent.

title: Political Memo; Re-examining the Fine Print On Clinton's Tax Promises
description: At a time when the public has repeatedly shown its distaste for the maneuvers and machinations of politics, President Clinton's White House is banking on a five-word loophole to save it from voter outrage should Mr. Clinton propose a broad-based energy tax.

title: Schwarz to Replace Muti
description: Gerard Schwarz is to replace Riccardo Muti, who has the flu, in the Philadelphia Orchestra concert on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall. The program remains unchanged: the New York premiere of Bernard Rands's "Canti dell'Eclissi," with the bass Thomas Paul as soloist; Stravinsky's "Monumentum pro Gesualdo di Venosa," and Brahms's Serenade No. 1 in D. Remaining tickets are $14 to $65. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Grumman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations from projected claims for hurricane damage incurred by the company's reinsurance subsidiary, Paumancok Insurance Co., which is being discontinued and offered for sale, of $ 46,335,000 and $ 45,035,000 in the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an extraordinary charge of $ 198,000,000 from cummulative effect in change in accounting for postretirement benefits.c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,369,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 4,166,000, or 13 cents a share.
